column5: Modeling Instruction in an Algebra-Based Lecture Environment
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: During the past few years, Modeling Instruction materials and activities have been adapted for an algebra-based introductory course in a "lecture" environment (non-moveable chairs and tables). Typical enrollment for this class is approx. 90 students. The presentation will highlight some of the pros and cons associated with this process, some of the hands-on activities that were used, and the preliminary results of the effectiveness of this adaptation on student learning. (A sample of course materials, worksheets, and hands-on activities will be presented during a poster session at this meeting.)

column5: An Investigation of the Effectiveness of Different Recitation Teaching Methods*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: We will present preliminary results of an investigation which compares student performance for four different recitation class teaching methods. This investigation is part of a larger project that involves adapting and implementing the "Tutorials in Introductory Physics 1" in the recitation classes of our introductory calculus-based physics courses. As part of this study, students attended a special extra credit recitation class which was not a part of the regular course. This special recitation covered the tutorial "Changes in Energy and Momentum." The topic was taught using four different teaching techniques which differed in the level of inquiry and amount of active engagement by the students and instructors. A total of 273 students participated and each was assigned to one of eight sessions, with each method used in two separate sessions. Student performance was evaluated through pre-tests and post-tests given at the sessions as well as a post-test on the final exam.
column19: * Supported by NSF grant #DUE-0126919 1. L.C. McDermott, P.S. Shaffer and the Physics Education Group at the University of Washington, Tutorials in Introductory Physics, First Ed. (Prentice Hall, 2002).

column5: Rolling Spherical Rare Earth Magnets on Conductors and Non-Conductors
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Alois Adams, Univ. of Arkansas, Little Rock
column18: Spherical rare earth magnets can be modeled quite accurately by a pure magnetic dipole. Measurements of the magnetic field near a 3/4-inch magnet and interactions between two such magnets are consistent with predictions based on the pure dipole model, with a magnetic dipole of approximately 3.5 Am2. Their spherical shape, combined with their relatively large magnetic fields (order of 10,000 Gauss at their surface), opens up new possibilities in pedagogy, research in dipole-dipole interactions, and research in physics education. Rolling rare earth spherical magnets show noticeable effects due to interactions with the earth's magnetic field. In this presentation several rolling experiments will be described and analyzed: a magnet rolling on a flat non-conductor, a magnet rolling on a flat non-magnetic metallic surface, a magnet rolling on a non-conducting incline, and a magnet rolling on a non-magnetic metallic incline. Interactions with the earth's magnetic field and Lenz's Law will be used to analyze the motion.

column5: Student Learning in Physics for Elementary Teachers (PET) Curriculum
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Paul W Zitzewitz, Univ. of Michigan, Dearborn
column18: We have taught the 2004/2005 version of PET to approximately 80 students, both graduate and undergraduate, at the Univ. of Michigan-Dearborn. Graduate students were mostly in-service K-8 teachers, undergraduates were elementary education students taking it as the required inquiry-learning physical science course. The full curriculum was not taught due to lack of classroom time; the graduate course met for 42 hours, the undergraduate course for 56. All students are accustomed to inquiry learning as they take six such courses in the sciences. The PET diagnostic exam that covered topics both included in the shortened course and not included was given as a pre-/post-test. For the graduate offering the average of the Hake gains of students on the questions addressed by the course (four out of nine) was 82%. Gains for the undergraduate offerings will be presented. Informal student response has been very positive; detailed analysis will be presented.

column5: Identifying Student Difficulties with Kinematics in the Introductory Physics Laboratory*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column17: Luanna G Ortiz, Stephen E Kanim, Michael E Loverude
column18: We have been investigating student understanding of kinematics in physics laboratory courses at several universities. At Arizona State University the focus of the research has been student performance on problems involving two-dimensional motion after completing a lab on projectile motion. In this presentation we will describe prevalent reasoning difficulties that appear to influence student predictions about the motion of a projectile. Results from individual student interviews and written questions will be presented. This research will inform the development of laboratory materials for use in the algebra-based physics course. The preliminary edition of the lab curriculum is under development, and will ultimately include fifteen labs on mechanics, including some that are a direct outgrowth of

column5: Effectiveness of Student Magnetism Kits
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Twenty-four student magnetism, low-cost ($25/kit) kits were developed last summer for use in the algebra-based introductory course where Modeling instruction is being implemented. (The kits were first show-cased during the Winter '05 meeting.) The kits were finally put through their paces with a group of 72 students. Results of the activities associated with the kits, as well as the recently developed Magnetism unit, will be presented. Pre-test and post-test results on a self-generated magnetism diagnostic will be discussed. One of the kits and sample course materials can be examined during the scheduled time for presenters.

column5: Developing an Inquiry-Based Physical Science Course for Pre-Service Elementary Teachers*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Zdeslav Hrepic, Fort Hays State Univ.
column17: Paul Adams, Jason Zeller, Nancy Talbott, Germaine Taggart
column18: Pre-service elementary teachers should experience science through inquiry in order to be effective in teaching science. In addition, inquiry as a mode of teaching is mandated by Kansas and National Science Education Standards. As a result of the No Child Left Behind Act, teachers also need to be prepared to include basic skills in reading and mathematics in all instruction. To address these issues Fort Hays State University (FHSU) is adapting and extending the NSF-developed teacher enhancement materials Operation Primary Physical Science (OPPS) for use in a physical science course for preservice elementary teachers. We will present main features of OPPS, demonstrate its effectiveness as shown through workshops with in-service teachers and discuss results that we have collected with students enrolled in the adapted course since the beginning of the Fall 2004 semester.
column19: *Supported in part by NSF grants DUE-0311042 and DUE-0088818 1. Lanee Young, Fort Hays State University, is also an author of this paper.

column5: Dialogues Concerning Two Interpretations of Inquiry
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: We present a videotaped moment from an inquiry-based college physics course. In this moment several students suggested to the instructor that he should replace "weight" with "mass" in a density formula he wrote on the board. In responding to the students the instructor claimed making a distinction between mass and weight was not relevant to what the class was engaged in trying to understand. The authors have different ideas about whether the response was an appropriate one. In subsequent discussions it became apparent we were making different assumptions about what was important in that instructional moment. This difference gets at important issues associated with inquiry teaching and learning. What is at the core of what we are, or should be, teaching students? Is inquiry a pedagogical approach or an agenda? We present both sides of the dialogue in an effort to raise questions we feel physics educators should consider.

column5: TIR or ReTIRe?
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Michael D Wolter, Muncie Central H.S.
column18: The Physics Teacher Education Coalition has implemented a national model for improving the instruction of pre-service physics and science teachers and for improving the retention of in-service teachers. The key component of this project is a Teacher in Residence (TIR) that leaves their classroom for one year to become part of a university community dedicated to teacher education. What happens to the TIR as they leave and then return to their classroom one year later? A personal overview will be provided.

column5: New-Information Problem
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column17: Lei Bao, Neville W Reay, Jing Wang
column18: An important skill in problem solving is the ability to synthesize the available information for a solution of the problem. The training of such skills often involves giving students problems and information that they haven't encountered in their previous learning experiences. To this end, we designed a new type of problems, the New-Information problems, which has many features similar to the well known context-rich problems. In addition to rich contexts, the New-Information problems also provide new knowledge pieces that the students have never seen before. Students need to combine their previous knowledge and the new knowledge in order to solve a problem. In this poster, we will discuss the research and implementation of this type of problems in physics courses.

column5: Statistical Analysis of Students' Voting Data in an E&M; Course
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column17: Lei Bao, Neville W. Reay, Jing Wang
column18: Voting Machine (VM), an in-class polling system was used as a lecture instrument to teach students in an introductory mechanics and electromagnetism class in Ohio state University. We developed a method of three-question sequence as formative assessment tool to facilitate students working through their conceptual change processes. In this poster, we will discuss statistical analysis of students' data on voting machine questions and exams.

column5: Computer-Mediated Collaboration in an Inquiry-Based Laboratory*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Recent changes by our College of Education required the creation of an inquiry-based science course for education majors. Our department volunteered to create such a course adapted from existing inquiry-based materials. To reduce the faculty time-load of this course and (hopefully) improve instruction, laboratory manuals and student laboratory notebooks were replaced by a web-browser based system. Students read experimental procedures, questions, problems, etc---displayed as webpages; perform hands-on experiments with simple equipment; and record their results, answers, comments, ideas, etc---in blank fields provided on the same web pages. Collaboration is encouraged by allowing students to view the work of other students (but only after they have done the work themselves) and to hold ongoing discussions by writing additional questions, comments, and replies. We will describe the details of this system as well as student and instructor perceptions of the course and ideas for future improvements.
column19: *Funded in part by Information Technology grants from the State of Kansas and from Wichita State Univ.

column5: Teaching Scientific Methods Using Peer Review
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Timothy J Moran, Bowling Green State Univ.
column18: A class centered on student design of experiments and peer review of the resulting reports is described. Thirteen students in an honors seminar section of an introductory physics class designed experiments to test various types of paranormal phenomena. Each experimental report was evaluated and ranked by several other students. To give students experience in interpreting controversial results, they were first instructed to slant their experimental reports toward either a paranormal interpretation or a non-paranormal interpretation. Then students evaluated each others' reports using a commentary and ranking form. Student satisfaction was high, even after students received both written and verbal criticism from peers. Survey and interview data obtained after the class indicated an increase in student confidence in their ability to evaluate media science reports.

column5: TIR's Can Retain Physics Teachers
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: The Physics Teacher Education Coalition has implemented a national model for improving the instruction of pre-service physics and science teachers and for improving the retention of in-service teachers. The key component of this project is the Teacher in Residence (TIR). One of the responsibilities of the TIR is to provide conceptual mentoring to novice in-service physics/science teachers. The ultimate goal of this mentoring is to improve the retention rate of novice physics teachers. Data supporting the success of the TIR mentoring model and its impact on retention will be provided.

column5: The Effect of Test Types on Sex-Based Performance Difference*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Mark McKinnon, Univ. of California, Davis
column18: Research over the last few decades has shown that, in general, females and males are cognitive equals. Yet, for the most part, males still out-perform females in science classes. We have observed more than ten thousand students over the past decade in the UC Davis Introductory Physics course, a program radically restructured away from a traditional class. The sex-based difference in test scores is considerably smaller than in UC Davis' previously taught traditional physics course. However, some performance differences remain. We present findings that show that the types of test items (problem solving, qualitative analysis, graphical generation and interpretation, etc.) affect sex based performance differences.

column5: Physics Education in Brazil
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: The Brazilian Law about Science Education, teachers' employment relationship and daily reality in both, private and public schools will be briefly analyzed in order to give audience members the necessary understanding about the state of Physics Education in Brazil. The curriculum, classroom practice, and assessment of physics will be discussed and analyzed taking into consideration how college entrance exams shape the entire educational process. The perspective adopted will be based on my own experience as a physics teacher for 11 years in private schools in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Alexandre Frohlich attended College at the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro where he earned a Bachelor's Degree and a Teaching Certification. From 1991 to 2002 Frohlich taught physics in college preparatory private schools. From 2002 to 2004 he attended graduate school at the University of Missouri-Rolla earning a Masters of Science Degree. Presently he is a faculty member of Missouri Military Academy

column5: Cold Science: Astronomy from the South Pole
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: From the very bottom of the Earth a band of intrepid astrophysicists have been exploring the wonders of the universe. Braving temperatures below -100 F (200 Kelvin) during the six months of continuous darkness, they have built and operated a series of telescopes and instruments to study the big bang, neutrinos, and star formation. Pack your bags (and your parkas) and let me take you on a journey to the bottom of the world. As I describe the discoveries we've made on the frontiers of astronomy, I'll also give you a feeling for what it is like to live on one of the last frontiers of the Earth.

column5: Three-Dimensional Simulations: The Photoelectric Effect and Young's Experiment with Photons
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column17: Peter J Gilbert, Karolina A Sarnowska, Taha Mzoughi
column18: WebTOP (http://webtop.msstate.edu) is a web-based, three-dimensional, interactive software package designed to help teachers teach optics and students learn optics. In this talk the two newest WebTOP modules are showcased. In the Photoelectric Effect module, a beam of light is incident upon a metal plate, and the ejected photoelectrons travel towards a second plate. The user can change the wavelength and intensity of the light, the work function of the metal, and the potential difference across the plates. In the Two Slit-Photons module a beam of light is incident upon two slits, and the arrival of the individual photons at an observation screen are depicted. The user can change the wavelength of the light, the number of photons per second incident upon the slits, the duration of the experiment, and the width and separation of the slits. (WebTOP is sponsored in part by NSF grant DUE 0231217.)

column5: TIR's Belong on University Campuses
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: The Physics Teacher Education Coalition has implemented a national model for improving the instruction of pre-service physics and science teachers and for improving the retention of in-service teachers. The key component of this project is the Teacher in Residence (TIR). One of the responsibilities of the TIR is to facilitate the long-term collaboration between the physics department, the science education department, the general education department, and the public schools. Data supporting the importance of the TIR to the university and their impact on the level of collaboration will be provided.

column5: Video Analysis Using Visual Basic in Excel
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Justin L Kay, Brigham Young Univ - Idaho
column18: Frame by frame video analysis can be a useful tool for both measuring and understanding motion. Microsoft Excel and Visual Basic macros have the power to do this but are sometimes so complex that they are hard to manipulate. In this presentation, methods of constructing the analysis software will be described and a documented program will be given. This will make it possible to use video analysis programs for a variety of undergraduate physics labs.

column5: Earth Science Issues Confronting Utahns over the Next Decade*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Rick G Allis, Utah Geological Survey
column18: Utah is resource-rich, but continued growth will put extra pressure on competing land uses. We have demands for more energy supplies (coal, oil, and gas), increased groundwater supplies, urban expansion into hazardous locations, as well as a need to protect our spectacular environment. In 2001, production of natural gas became Utah's leading geologic commodity, replacing coal and copper, which have underpinned Utah's economy through most of the twentieth century. Sixty percent of Utah's public supply of water is from groundwater, and increasing consumption is challenging the definition of sustainable yield from our strategic aquifers. Consumption patterns of both energy and water are going to have to change in the years ahead. Increased conservation, energy efficiency practices, use of alternative or non-traditional energy sources, and new technologies for cleaner coal combustion and carbon sequestration are issues that we will all have to grapple with.

column5: Improving Learning and Measuring Success of Underrepresented Groups in Physics
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: The Extended Physics program at Rutgers University has been successfully improving the learning and degree completion of students from groups underrepresented in STEM majors (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) for over 15 years. I will discuss the main reasons that women and some ethnic minority groups are underrepresented and how we can help, emphasizing the importance of discipline-specific reforms in attaining equitable representation in STEM professions. I will also discuss the more fundamental questions of how we define success in our physics courses and whether our assessment instruments are measuring this success.

column5: Professional Development Courses for K-12 Teachers: Residence and Distance Learning
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Stephen T Thornton, Univ. of Virginia
column18: We continue developing physical science/physics courses for K-12 teachers, including residence and distance learning courses required for our Master of Arts in Physics Education (MAPE) degree. We now have 17 graduate 600-level courses expressly designed for K-12 teachers, 14 of which are regularly taught. Many of our students (teachers) seek increased content, physics endorsement, and recertification, and a growing number are seeking our MAPE degree. Seven of the courses are taught every year via distance learning. For details see our website at http://www.k12.phys.virginia.edu. Two new courses for K-6 teachers on physical science begin in September 2005 by distance learning. We have various methods by which we present distance-learning courses, but most utilize videotaped lectures of our most popular undergraduate courses that are edited and copied on CDs for home viewing. Homework and exams are given on WebAssign. We will summarize our courses and present enrollment and graduation data.

column5: The Haunted Physics Laboratory as an Outreach Opportunity
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Frontier Physics, the outreach arm of the Department of Physics at Northern Illinois University, has developed a Haunted Physics Laboratory that draws hundreds of people each fall. We use the Halloween/Haunted theme to draw families to campus and hands-on physics activities to increase their knowledge of and enthusiasm for physics. The Haunted Lab has come a long way from our first just 2 years ago, put together with duct tape and apparatus rods. Last year we utilized a grant from AAPT's Bauder Fund to construct more durable exhibits. This summer we are utilizing a WYP Physics on the Road Grant from the American Physical Society and student workers to convert the Haunted Lab to a traveling exhibit that will visit 3-4 community college campuses this fall in addition to our NIU program. I will share some of our favorite exhibits and construction techniques. For more information, visit http://www.physics.niu.edu/frontier

column5: High School Research for Everybody Using Project-Based Learning
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Bruce Oldaker, Rye Country Day School
column18: We report on a new system of high school-based research in the U.S. that can lead to participation in an international physics competition. This system has been developed extgensively in Eastern Europe, the countries of the Former Soviet Union, and a few others. The culmination of this system is the International Young Physicists Tournament (IYPT) each summer. The differences between the IYPT and the more famous IPhO will be addressed in the preceeding talk. Our planned implementation of the IYPT research system for the U.S. envisions not only the annual selection and preparation of the U.S. team for the IYPT, but use of IYPT methodologies for U.S. high school physics teachers and students, particularly those schools that emply project-based learning.

column5: Learning the "Game" of Science
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: David Maloney, Indiana Univ.-Purdue Univ. - Fort Wayne
column18: One of the often stated goals of science courses is to help students get an idea of the "nature of science" and what distinguishes it from other fields of study. This talk will describe a technique, suggested by a statement in the first volume of the Feynman Lectures, for using abstract strategy games to help the students gain insights to how science works. The technique is quite flexible and can be adjusted to be simple, taking a class period or less, or to be more challenging where several periods are needed. Different aspects of the nature of science can also be highlighted by what game is used and how the activity is structured.

column5: Technology for Peer Instruction I
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: The Interactive Learning Toolkit (ILT) is a tool to implement innovative teaching ideas such as Peer Instruction and Just in Time Teaching, and to monitor students' learning. It incorporates a large Concept Test (CT) database and provides the opportunity to easily integrate CTs into lectures. This talk will discuss the integration of the content management of the ILT with the Interactive Classroom features of BQ, a software developed at Erskine College. Student responses using IR clickers, wireless laptops, PDAs and cell phones are combined to give the instructor immediate feedback on student understanding. The ILT provides a statistical analysis of all student responses as well as of individual student data. The first step of the integration has been tested in a large introductory physics course at Harvard University. Results of this test are presented and future integration steps will be discussed.

column5: The Interactive Web: Learning by Doing, or Just Doing?*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: There's no question that the web has become a powerful tool in informal education, providing learners with unprecedented access to information. But over the last few years the web has learned a new trick: it has become interactive. Web visitors can explore environments, play games, and run simulations. This is of tremendous interest to the informal education world. After all, a tenet of science centers is that interactive experiences are key components of effective learning. Ergo, the interactive web is now in some ways comparable to science centers. But is it? Can the lessons of the museum world be extended to the web? Who are the audiences? What and how do they learn? And how are we going to find out? This talk will summarize some of the research and evaluation programs that are attempting to address these questions.

column5: Modeling Students' Conceptual Understanding of Scientific Phenomena
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Rebecca Lindell, Southern Illinois Univ. Edwardsville
column18: Often the most difficult concepts to teach, are the ones where many students enter the classroom with an unscientific understanding of the phenomenon. According to cognitive scientists to promote conceptual change between an alternative understanding and scientific understanding, researchers need to first have a through understanding of the different schemas individuals possess, as well as how deeply rooted and how structured these schemas are. To obtain this deep understanding concerning one phenomenon, lunar phases, the Lunar Phases Concept Inventory (LPCI) was administered to thousands of college students across the U.S. and Canada before and after instruction on lunar phases. By applying the theories of Model Analysis, Ordering, Knowledge Spaces and Artificial Neural Networks to the LPCI national database, we are in the process of modeling the structure of students' schemas, how consistently these schema are utilized, as well as the prerequisite relations among the different parts of the schemas.

column5: A New Twist on Uniform Circular Motion
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Circular motion is one of the important concepts explored in introductory physics courses, yet students don't always completely understand their measurements nor the implications of and connections between those measurements. We wanted to have the students actually designing the experiment---within some guidelines. We suggested a functional relationship between the theoretical quantities of acceleration and speed, gave the students some information about the apparatus and about some of the final data we wanted to see, then let them go. What I'll share with you are the pre-lab and lab instruction sheets that we developed, our goals for student learning of content as well as student development in terms of independent thinking and some general observations gleaned from their lab notebooks.

column5: Algebra for All?: A Small-College Strategy
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: A strategy, in which all STEM students first take an algebra-based physics sequence, is being tested. Students who would normally take calculus-based physics take an additional course, Calculus Applications in Physics, during the 2nd-half of each semester. The model is based on the IB and GCE strategies, in which STEM students usually complete a rigorous algebra-based physics sequence before university. This structure allows us to separate the concept-driven physics course from the mathematically driven calculus applications, and gives students more focused time to cover discipline-appropriate material. This model makes more efficient use of a limited number of available teaching hours, and is particularly suited to small college environments with low enrollment. We will be presenting an overview of the course sequencing, showing how physics, calculus, and calculus-applications mesh together into one sequence, with preliminary observations from the first year. Samples of IB work will be included as an exemplary algebra-based sequence.

column5: Technology for Peer Instruction II
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: The BQ program (http://www.erskine.edu/bq) has been expanded to make this free software more flexible. It has been used for In-Class polling for Peer Instruction in a large physics class at Harvard University (see "Technology for Peer Instruction I"). My presentation will give some details about the components of BQ which were used to obtain data, display responses, and transfer these responses into the ILT (Interactive Learning Toolkits) database. I will include information about how the responses were received and handled as students used a mixture of IR keypads (PRS remotes), WiFi enabled laptops, and cell phones. The results of this project will be described along with plans for future development.

column5: Differences Between American and Korean Students in Understanding Kinematics Graphs
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Tae Sun Kim, North Carolina State Univ.
column18: Line graphs are an efficient tool for making sense of information. They are used as an integral part of communicating information in many contexts, especially kinematics courses. Line graphs are an efficient tool for making sense of information. They are used as an integral part of communicating information in many contexts, especially kinematics courses. One of the purposes (Beichner, 1994) of the Test of Understanding Graphs in Kinematics (TUG-K) was to uncover student problems with interpreting kinematics. The TUG-K was given to Korean high and college students in 2004. The study provided if there is a difference between the original American data of the TUG-K and the new Korean data. The purpose of this research was to investigate whether or not there is a significant difference in viewing kinematics graphs according to some elements such as culture.

column5: Relationships of Graphing Abilities to Process Skills and Academic Achievement
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Tae Sun Kim, North Carolina State Univ.
column18: Graphs are applied daily in many different areas to deliver information and to analyze data. One hundred and forty-eight ordinary high school students were selected, and their graphing abilities and science process skills were tested through TOGS (Test of Graphing Skills in science) and TSPS (Test of Science Process Skills). The tests were presented in common language avoiding any scientific concept. The relationship between two skills was analyzed. Also, the students' academic achievements in science were evaluated in two parts; written test results and performance outcomes, were compared with graphing skills in order to find a relationship. The existence of a correlation between graphing ability and science process skill was proven. It can also be concluded that improving graphing ability will greatly support the students with their science study, and therefore organized efforts and efficient educational methods should be developed in order to overcome the insufficient graphing ability among our high school students.

column5: How Different "Levels" of Course Reform Affect FCI/MPEX2 Gains
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: For the past three years, the University of Maryland has used epistemologically focused tutorials in its introductory physics courses. However, the degree to which our courses are otherwise "reformed" depends on a number of factors, such as homework assignments, exams, and the professor's and the teaching assistants' commitment to and experience with active-learning methods. These factors, but not the tutorials themselves, have varied substantially over the past three years while the student population has stayed the same. We've used the MPEX2 and the FCI to assess epistemological and conceptual gains resulting from these different instantiations of the course. We notice more variability in epistemological gains than in conceptual gains.

column5: JiTT and Peer Instruction from the Very First Day
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: This past fall I began my first teaching position at a small liberal arts college. Starting with my very first class, I began to incorporate JiTT (Just-in-time-teaching) and Peer Instruction into my teaching. I've had many successes, a few failures, and a number of unexpected and humorous experiences. Would I do it again? Yes! Would I do some things differently? Certainly!

column5: Computational Cognitive Analysis of Student Learning in Electric Charge Distribution*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Computational modeling of cognitive processes has been around for a long time. In our previous research, we have developed a neural network system to study student learning in electric charge distribution. The learning behavior of the network reveals many similarities to student learning. For example, the network creates locally usable rules that can be mapped to specific student difficulties. Built on this research, we further investigate the cognitive structures underlying student difficulties. In this poster, we will discuss the new results and future development.

column5: WebTOP Tutorials
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: WebTOP is a web-based, interactive computer graphics system for Teaching and Learning Optics and Waves. It contains nineteen modules that enable investigation of topics in wave and optics in a 3-D environment. As part of a CCLI grant project, colleagues from seven other institutions are developing a set of WebTOP-based guided tutorials. These tutorials will take students through the material step by step, providing visual examples and inquiry-type exercises. The poster will demonstrate some of these tutorials. For further information about the tutorials and WebTOP, you may wish to visit the WebTOP website at http://webtop.msstate.edu.

column5: Textbook Effectiveness: $100 Paperweights, or How To Read a Book
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Richard Zajac, Kansas State Univ., Salina
column18: Methods of active-learning and discovery-inquiry are time consuming and require that students take responsibility for additional learning outside the classroom. This is hindered by a widespread reluctance on the part of the students to read from their expensive textbooks beyond cursory skimming for equations. Brief but relentless daily reading quizzes were implemented in all physics lecture groups over several semesters to serve as both a tool for investigation and as a possible intervention. The data thus collected can be compared with multiple measures of student performance both in class and on standardized tests. This analysis reveals several disturbing patterns, especially given the recent emphasis on reading/writing skills. The implications for our students are discussed, as well as ramifications for course and curriculum development.

column5: The CHEPREO Project: Building a Learning Community Around HEP*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column17: Elliot D Brown, Pete Markowitz, George O'Brien
column18: The Inter-Regional Grid-enabled Center for High-Energy Physics Research Education and Outreach (CHEPREO) is a NSF-supported project that is building a learning community centered around high energy physics, grid computing, and high speed networking. CHEPREO's goal is to generate excitment about physics and science in general, support inquiry-based instructional methods in the classroom, and increase physics enrollment at both the high school and college level. These changes are affected through our community of high school students and teachers, undergraduate and graduate students, and university faculty in diverse South Florida. CHEPREO's efforts are based on physics modeling, QuarkNet, and Treisman-based study groups, integrating these programs into a high energy physics-based research program supplemented by newly developed materials. An overall description and results from the first two years will be presented along with a look towards future growth.

column5: The CHEPREO Project: Evaluation Results from a New Learning Community*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column17: Laird Kramer, Pete Markowitz, George O'Brien
column18: The Inter-Regional Grid-enabled Center for High-Energy Physics Research Education and Outreach (CHEPREO) is a NSF-supported project that is building a learning community centered around high energy physics, grid computing, and high speed networking. The CHEPREO community includes high school students and teachers, undergraduate and graduate students, and university faculty incorporating physics modeling instruction, QuarkNet, and Treisman-based study groups into a high energy physics-based research program. Initial success has been demonstrated both in terms of the community interactions as well as quantified through national instruments. We will report on results from the high school students, teachers, and undergraduates involved in the project's first 18 months of operation.

column5: The International Young Physicists Tournament - Project-Based Competition
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: We report on the International Young Physicists Tournament (IYPT), contrast the IYPT with the more-famous International Physics Olympiad (IPhO), and describe the role both competitions play as part of the World Federation of Physics Competitions (WFPhC). Although the goals of the Tournament and the Olympiad are similar they are achieved using extremely different methodologies and have received very different participation in the U.S. Both competitions can be used to improve physics education, however we will show that the Tournament and its methodologies provide greater access for U.S. students and teachers. The following talk will address U.S. implementation of the IYPT.

column5: Photons from Scintillating Optical Fibers: A New Undergraduate Capstone Experience
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: David Kaplan, Southern Illinois Univ. Edwardsville
column18: One of the issues in physics education involves providing research experience with signals from small numbers of photons and electrons, fluctuations and the quantum limit. Scintillating fibers, which produce their own photons when traversed by charged particles, provide excellent capstone projects in photon counting that pedagogically tie together concepts from several areas of physics. Flat planar ribbons of parallel-running scintillating fibers are used as position-sensing detectors for charged particles in a variety of fields of interest to students, including cosmic ray astrophysics, particle physics and medical physics. For high resolution, the fibers are very narrow, and hence produce relatively few photons per traversal, which are read out via (Einstein's) photoelectric effect. Scintillating fiber capstone projects have been developed in which students can distinguish, in integer units, photon signals corresponding to up to about ten photoelectrons. In this talk I will describe some recent and planned scintillating fiber-based capstone projects.

column5: Hands-On Inquiry in Pre-Service Elementary Teachers Science Content Courses
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Paul Ashcraft, Clarion Univ. of Pennsylvania
column18: Student performance on exams of a university physical science class linked with a mathematics class designed for elementary education majors was compared to a similar class whose students were a mixture of non-science majors and education majors. The linked class met in a laboratory setting and engaged in hands-on, inquiry activities dealing with nuclear physics during the second four-week section of the class. Student performance on exams is compared with that of the third section dealing with electricity and magnetism, taught in a more didactic and traditional manner. Additionally, student performance between the two classes was examined both when the two classes had similar instruction and when different teaching methods were employed. While there were no statistically significant differences on second exam, there were statistically significant differences on the third exam. Qualitative evidence suggests that the inquiry-based teaching methods helped the elementary education majors construct scientific conceptions.

column5: Video Demonstrations for an Upper-Division Optics Course*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: M. Takeshi Nakata, Brigham Young Univ.
column18: We filmed students performing 18 laboratory exercises used in an advance undergraduate optics course. The videos instruct how to use the lab equipment and illustrate the physical phenomena under study. The videos are often shown in class to prepare students for the exercises, which are integrated into traditional homework sets. The advanced familiarity with the equipment and the expectation of results to be achieved helps students to avoid frustrations and pitfalls that can add inordinate time to completing assignments. The videos were taped and edited on consumer-grade electronics. They are accessible at http://www.optics.byu.edu.

column5: Simple Methods To Study the Hierarchical Structure of Physics Knowledge
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Must students understand acceleration before they can understand force? Must they understand electric field before electric potential? The answers to these questions involve an understanding of the hierarchical structure of physics knowledge, and play an important role in how to best teach physics. In order to better understand the hierarchical structure of student understanding, a simple but statistically rigorous method for analyzing student performance on typical physics exam questions is reviewed. In an example application, it is found that the ability to do force diagrams and algorithmic problems involving force are not independent of each other. In particular, proficiency in force diagrams is a good predictor of proficiency in related numerical problems; however, the converse is not true. This suggests that understanding force diagrams is sufficient but not necessary for understanding how to do algorithmic problems involving force. This result also depends on whether the acceleration and/or velocity is zero.

column5: Bringing the Excitement of Physics to Community: UBC Public Outreach
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Marina Milner-Bolotin, Univ. of British Columbia
column17: Valery Milner, Andrzej Kotlicki, Chris Waltham, Donald Witt
column18: What is the right time to bring the excitement of physics to children and inspire their interest in science? At the University of British Columbia (UBC), we believe that elementary as well as high school students can benefit significantly from such an exposure. Faculty members, graduate and undergraduate students at UBC organize various outreach events to bring physics to children of all ages and to their families: Faraday Christmas Lectures, Open Houses, Summer Science Camps, physics lessons and demo shows at local elementary and high schools, Science Fairs, Physics Olympics and High School Contests, Public Nights at our Observatory, guided tours of Canada's National Lab for particle and nuclear physics (TRIUMF) and many more, public physics lectures and many more. Visit http://www.physics.ubc.ca/links/outreach.php and http://www.triumf.info/ and http://www.physics.ubc.ca/~milnerm/Faraday/ to learn more.

column5: Immersion Science
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Change in technology that affects the public generally outpaces change in high school physics curricula. As a consequence, it becomes increasingly difficult to teach young people how to become educated consumers and voters and for them to believe they can have an interesting career in science and technology. I will discuss the successes and failures of efforts to immerse high school students in technology-rich environments beyond what would usually be considered practical given their prerequisite knowledge, specifically in electronics and optics.

column5: Student Understanding of Basic Concepts in Quantum Mechanics
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: There is evidence that many students who leave an introductory quantum mechanics course fail to recognize some fundamental ways in which quantum mechanics differs from classical mechanics. Frequently they fail to differentiate sufficiently between time-independent and time-dependent states and are unable to relate classical and quantum mechanical descriptions of systems. Some errors seem to have their roots in difficulties with probability and classical mechanics. Others reflect a failure to relate the mathematical formalism to the real world. Specific difficulties will be illustrated by examples from research and implications for instruction will be discussed.

column5: Broadening Middle-School Student Images of Science and Scientists
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Diandra L Leslie-Pelecky, Univ. of Nebraska
column17: Angela Zabawa, David Schmitter, Gayle Buck
column18: One factor influencing K-12 students' decisions to study science is their perceptions of science and scientists. The "mad scientist" stereotype is alive and well---and not an image most kids want to identify with. Project Fulcrum is a NSF program that teams science graduate students with middle-school teachers. The Image of Science and Scientists project is designed to challenge and broaden student stereotypes. Teams base their projects on classroom specific information they gather. All the activities involved scientist visits; however, the implementation and activities surrounding the visits were tailored to specific needs. For example, students at one school wrote that "all scientists do is work," so the team had students investigate the visiting scientists' hobbies and other outside interests. Most assessments focused on comparing students and scientist characteristics to emphasize the similarities.

column5: E&M; Test Results from Alternative Certification Program Summer Physics Academy
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Marie F Plumb, Jamestown Comm. College
column18: The physics department at Buffalo State College together with the college's Center for Excellence in Urban and Rural Education was awarded an NSF grant to increase the number of highly qualified science teachers. As part of this initiative, an alternative certification program for those seeking career changes or a second certification has been established. Part of the certification process involves a Summer Physics Academy. Academy courses, which can also be part of a Master of Science Education degree, combine content and pedagogy during intense three week sessions. Results of pre- and post-testing from a summer E&M; session will be discussed.

column5: Student Difficulties with Wave Representations and their Applications
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Many students have difficulty with basic wave representations and struggle to explain even simple phenomena after completing a full year of introductory calculus-based physics. At The Ohio State University, we have given a wave questionnaire, pre- and post-wave diagnostic questions, and have held extensive post-instruction interviews with students in order to better understand the nature of student difficulty with regards to wave representations. Students have difficulty defining the features of their representations, and although they can use these representations to depict certain phenomenon, they are often unable to apply them to explain the details. In addition, students can often answer exam questions requiring the application of formulas but often can not answer simple questions which can be reasoned directly from the properties of waves. Detailed findings from this study will be presented along with suggestions as to how we can use this knowledge to improve instruction.

column5: Implementing ISLE Laboratories at The Ohio State University
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: During the past academic year, Investigative Science Learning Environment (ISLE) labs were tested in some sections of the calculus-based introductory physics course at The Ohio State University (OSU). The ISLE labs have been developed by the PAER Group at Rutgers University and implemented at Rutgers and at California State University, Chico. A look at the motivation for switching to ISLE labs and an initial report on the success of the implementation was presented at the Winter 2005 AAPT conference. Adjustments have since been made including focusing on specific assessment tasks to refine our implementation. The labs have now been successfully adapted to fit the OSU introductory physics courses. This talk will focus on assessing the implementation of ISLE labs at OSU, including diagnostic tests, attitude surveys, and feedback obtained from a Q-type instrument.

column5: Bolometers, Millimeter Waves, and the Cosmic Microwave Background
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Miikka M Kangas, Univ. of California, Santa Barbara
column18: As we speak, various instruments are taking data to help pin down the values of fundamental cosmological constants. Bolometric technology and millimeter-wave instruments will play a key role in the determination of the cosmology of the Universe. With the recent WMAP satellite and other results, many parameters have been determined for the first time, but some key questions remain. The discovery of Tensor modes in the polarization of the Cosmic Microwave Background will reveal many of the remaining hidden secrets.

column5: The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Bargain Under Siege
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Melba Phillips' many interests included the search for peace in our time. Perhaps the most crucial tool towards that end is the non-proliferation regime whose cornerstone is the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty which came into force in 1970. This treaty enshrines a complex bargain: non-nuclear weapons states agree not to acquire nuclear weapons, and the five designated nuclear weapons states agree not to transfer nuclear weapons nor the tools and know-how to make nuclear weapons to non-nuclear weapons states. To lessen the discriminatory impact of that treaty, all states are granted the "inalienable right" to the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, and the nuclear weapons states agree to de-emphasize nuclear weapons in international relations, working in good faith to their eventual elimination. All countries in the world other than Israel, India, Pakistan, and now North Korea adhere to that Treaty. Today, the non-proliferation regime is under siege since some non-nuclear weapons states appear to harbor nuclear weapons ambitions under the guise of peaceful nuclear power, while the nuclear weapons states---in particular, the United States---have failed in abandoning their continuing emphasis on nuclear weapons. Possible solutions to relieve this crisis will be discussed.

column5: Mathematical Conflict in Physics: Computation vs. Representation
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Eugene Torigoe, Univ. of Illinois Urbana-Champaign
column18: In introductory physics the algebraic equations are thought of in two different ways. The first is representational and the second is computational. In the first mode we represent a relationship between variables, and the latter mode we calculate the numeric value of a particular quantity. Physics experts view these two modes as strongly interconnected, and are very adept at coordinating between these two different uses of the equations. We have found evidence that novice physics students, on the other hand, have great difficulty coordinating between these two modes of thinking. Some students even seem to have conflicting methods for computation and representation. We will present some of our data about the mathematical conflict and describe our work to further understand its causes.

column5: Watching Einstein's Glass Train: Animations That Illustrate Special Relativity
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: In this Year of Physics, honoring and celebrating the centenary of Einstein's miraculous year, it is entirely appropriate that we consider ways to communicate the theory of Special Relativity to the general public. I present a series of animations that were developed for this purpose and will be publicly available. They effectively convey the fundamental ideas of Special Relativity. The visual animated medium is ideal to communicate the counterintuitive results of the theory. The first few animations illustrate the basic concepts of an "event" and an "interval." Building on these initial ideas, animations of an Einstein Train follow, showing the perspective of observers in different reference frames as they observe a beam of light. The relativity of time is illustrated using light beams along with Einstein Clocks ticking away the seconds. Finally, several animations show the relativity of simultaneity.

column18: Writing assignments are commonly used to assess student knowledge in both introductory and upper-level physics classes. Such assignments range from the traditional long lab report to short answer worksheets common in activity-based classes. It is believed that the process of writing can increase student comprehension. I will present the results of two studies on student writing. We are now interviewing students to investigate their motivation and attitudes toward writing, and a preliminary description of this project will be described.

Some assignments are distributed as handouts with supporting software and videos provided on disks or servers. Others are accessed through an experimental online system created for the project. Most are also being adapted for use in WebAssign. We are doing a formative assessment to answer two questions. First, do the technical aspects work: Do students understand the questions, what they need to do, and how to use the tools? We are using a variety of methods, such as giving assignments in classroom settings under observation by project staff. Students and instructors also provide written and oral feedback. Second, does this homework help students understand the physics being taught? We are using pre/post questions within the assignment, follow-up exam questions, and analyses of the students' homework answers, including essay questions.

column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT

The goal for this project is to improve undergraduate education and preservice teacher preparation. However, a number of obstacles have been discovered which complicate the realization of this goal. In this talk, I will present data concerning persistent and potentially harmful (or beneficial) differences in teaching styles among a sample of physics graduate teaching assistants, and the success of efforts that have been made to standardize the conditions in their classrooms.

column5: Einstein's Meanders
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Everyone is familiar with the sinuous meandering of rivers. This talk will review Einstein's treatment of the fluid dynamics of river meanders. Its simplicity and elegance illustrates his belief that "the whole of science is nothing more than a refinement of everyday thinking."

column18: Cooperative Problem Solving labs have been part of introductory physics courses at the University of Minnesota since the late 1980s. Tools exist for digital video capture and motion analysis (VideoRECORDER and VideoTOOL), measuring time-varying potential differences (FaradayPROBE), and measuring magnetic fields (HallPROBE). The Ohio State University constituted a clicker committee that researched this problem, recommended standardizing on a single type of clicker and associated software and suggested pilot studies that could lead to selection of a single manufacturer. Nor does it match the requirements for temporary or permanent deep geologic storage of spent nuclear fuel, as designated by Congress years later in the Nuclear Waste Policy Act. Yet, if the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission approves the license, this "temporary" storage facility in Skull Valley could become the de-facto permanent storage site for commercial high-level nuclear waste. Impacts of the NRC license decision reach far beyond Skull Valley and the State of Utah. Communities across the U.S. along the spent nuclear fuel transportation routes are unaware of the planned shipments. Spent nuclear fuel rods should be stored at the power plants where they are generated, and transported only when the federal government has licensed and opened a permanent facility for spent nuclear fuel.

In each of these two environments, students solved largely isomorphic homework problems in four different representational formats (mathematical, verbal, graphical, pictoral). We also gave students quizzes where they could choose between these problem formats. A control group received random-format quizzes. The two classes differed significantly in their performance. These difficulties can be exacerbated by the choice of physical process presented to the students.

It also predicts that some students might use language as their primary representation when reasoning about heat in thermodynamic systems. We present the results of an interview study that aimed to test these predictions. The interview questions were devised by David Meltzer.

column5: Teaching "Work-Energy" Topic in Physics Laboratory
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: The concept of energy appears throughout every area of physics and is the cornerstone of the fundamental law of nature, the law of conservation of energy. We propose a list of designed experiments that could be presented at the laboratory class in the first semester of college and university physics courses to study various forms of energy and their transformation from one form into another. The first two experiments deal with determination of the kinetic and gravitational potential energies of the object and experimental test of the principle of conservation of mechanical energy in the gravitational field of the Earth when the object is falling or moving on inclined air track. The third experiment is designed to verify the principle of conservation of mechanical energy for spring force only. In the fourth experiment students verify the conservation of energy when both conservative forces, the force of gravity and the spring force, are acting. Two other experiments are designed for an empirical test of the work-kinetic energy and work-energy theorems when the nonconservative force is acting. All experiments are computer-based but also can be performed in a traditional way. The objectives of all experiments are to show the real action of physics laws, help students better understand and visualize the subject of the lecture.

column18: Recently we have begun a research program to study teaching and learning in upper-level thermal physics courses. These courses are normally taken by third- and fourth-year undergraduate physics majors, and may include first-year graduate students. One serendipitous aspect of this project involves exploring student functional understanding of mathematical concepts when applied to situations in thermal physics. Here we report on preliminary findings associated with the Maxwell relations, which equate mixed second partial derivatives (i.e., the result of differentiating a quantity successively with respect to two different variables, each of which are held constant during the other differentiation) of various state functions. Our results indicate that although students are able to perform partial differentiation easily, many students have difficulties understanding either the mathematical or the physical significance of the Maxwell relations.

column5: Using the iCARE for Monitoring Cognitive Conflicts and Anxiety*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Cognitive conflict has long been recognized as a factor that could facilitate student learning. Cognitive conflict, however, can cause some students to have high levels of anxiety during their learning, which, when not properly addressed, can have negative effects to students' motivations and performance. Therefore, instructors need to be informed about the impacts of introducing cognitive conflicts in their instruction. To do so, we need a quantitative instrument that can help identify the existence and features of cognitive conflicts and the anxiety caused. We have developed an easy to use instrument, the in-class Conflict and Anxiety Recognition Evaluation (iCARE), for monitoring the status of students' cognitive conflicts and anxiety in the context of Physics by Inquiry classes. In this talk, we present examples to show the types of information that can be obtained with iCARE in PBI classes and discuss how instructors can use such an instrument in their instruction.

column5: Measuring the Strength of Instructional Reform and Its Impact on Students*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Calls for reform have shaped the way preservice teachers are trained. Training increasingly emphasizes engagement and inquiry. But how effective are preservice teachers' experiences at influencing the pedagogical techniques they eventually use in their classrooms? If training results in an increased use of student-centered techniques, what is the effect on students? This session describes an instrument used to measure the degree to which a lesson is reformed, describe how this instrument was used to determine the effectiveness of a teacher training program, and explain how a study was performed to assess the performance of program graduates and the achievement of their students. Results suggest that teachers who are trained with reformed techniques use these techniques in their classrooms. The use of reformed pedagogy results in advanced student achievement in understanding the nature of science, reasoning skills, content, and attitude. Repeated preservice exposure to reformed pedagogy strongly predicts overall student achievement.

column5: Students' Cognitive Conflicts and Conceptual Change in PBI Classes*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: For more than two decades, many studies in science education have shown the importance of cognitive conflict as a teaching strategy for conceptual change. With proper context settings, instructors need to guide students to explicitly recognize cognitive conflicts among students' existing understandings and the new knowledge being taught. To study this issue, we have developed an easy-to-use instrument, the in-class Conflict and Anxiety Recognition Evaluation (iCARE), for monitoring the status of students' cognitive conflicts and anxiety in the context of Physics by Inquiry (PBI) classes. Using iCARE, we investigate what types of cognitive conflict is constructive or destructive in conceptual change when college students are confronted with anomalous situations in PBI classes. In this talk, we will present our results about the relationship between students' types of cognitive conflicts and their conceptual changes and discuss the implications for instruction.

column5: Investigating the Relationship Between Prior Knowledge and Cognitive Conflict*

column18: The constructivist view that students' prior knowledge is a major factor determining learning outcomes has become widely accepted. Cognitive conflict is also known as an important factor for conceptual change. In addition, motivational factors play important roles in leading students to a meaningful conflict in learning process. However, there is little research to investigate the relationship between the prior knowledge and cognitive conflicts in Physics by Inquiry (PBI) classes. In this poster, we will present among students with different levels of motivational beliefs the relationship between the characteristics of students' prior knowledge and cognitive conflicts. We will also discuss the implications for the more effective cognitive conflict strategy in real school setting.

column5: Cognition and Analysis in Determining Center of Mass
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: The ability of subjects to determine the center of mass of a two-body system was investigated in this study. Subjects were shown figures consisting of two filled black circles; they were told that these figures represented spheres or balls. The subjects were asked to indicate, with a mark, the point between the circles where they would balance. There were three subject groups. The first group received only instructions on the exercise. The second group was shown a 15-minute video in which discussed, qualitatively, the topic of center of mass and instructions. The third group was shown a 15-minute video on projectile motion as a control and instructions. None of the groups were given any measurement tools, only a pencil to mark the center of Mass. The results suggest that this visual assessment is made cognitively as opposed to analytically for all of the groups. Additionally, none of the subjects accurately indicated the center-of-mass when it occurred within one of the circles; all marks were made between the two circles regardless of the actual center of mass.

column5: Take (Your) Work Out of (Their) Homework
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Grade more with less effort. With the UT Homework Service, you can assign pedagogically sound and thought-provoking homework problems to your students, then let the Homework Service take over the delivery and grading, all under your control. Problems are both multiple choice and algorithmic (requiring exact numeric answers) in nature, ranging in difficulty from conceptual through AP to college freshman level. The only cost is some printing and minimal connect time for both you and your students. The system delivers unique problems to your students, grades their answers, gives them immediate feedback and a chance to resubmit answers after reworking the problems, then provides complete solutions after the due date. Tests can also be generated. A downloadable module allows in-class submission of quizzes and exams using IR (eventually RF) remotes.

column5: A New Statistical Analysis for Determining Survey Categories
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Wendy Adams, Univ. of Colorado, Boulder
column17: Katherine K Perkins, Carl E. Wieman
column18: Researches have created several surveys to evaluate students' attitudes and beliefs about science. These surveys are usually broken into subgroupings of statements, which are intended to represent various aspects of student beliefs. Previous surveys have validated their statements; however, there is no published statistical analysis of their category selection. While developing the CLASS1,2, we created a method for determining categories which represent students' thinking. We will present two philosophies for category selection and how our methods embrace both of these producing useful and statistically valid categories. A new rating of category robustness will also be presented.

column5: Creating a Physics Problem Solving Survey
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Wendy Adams, Univ. of Colorado, Boulder
column18: Educators devote much of their time to improving their instructional techniques. One of the biggest hurdles to success is evaluating these new methods in consistent ways across the entire community. Researchers have created several tools for evaluating conceptual understanding as well as students' attitudes and beliefs about physics; however, the field of problem solving is sorely lacking a broad use evaluation tool. This missing tool is an indication of the complexity of the field. The most obvious and largest hurdle to evaluating physics problem solving skills is the physics content knowledge necessary to solve problems. We propose tackling this problem by looking for the physics problem solving skills that are useful in other disciplines as well as physics. Once a tool is created that analyzes students' cross discipline problem solving heuristics it will be used in the physics classroom to verify that the evaluation tool is indeed an indication of physics problem solving skills.
