column5: A Short Teacher Development Course Based on Physics Education Research
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: We present a short development course for in-service physics teachers based on Physics Education Research. The main objective of this practical course is to provide the in-service teachers a first contact with an active learning teaching strategy. The strategy chosen for this purpose was Tutorials in Introductory Physics developed by the Physics Education Research Group at the University of Washington. The course was organized so that teachers first experienced, as students, the whole tutorial sequence of activities: pre-test, tutorial and tutorial homework. In the second part they recognized and reflected about their students' difficulties, discussing with their colleagues in small group first and whole class later. This process was carried out in a cooperative learning environment. Finally they read and discussed specific Physics Education Research literature in which these learning difficulties have been studied by experts.

column5: The Role and Place of Imagination in Introductory Physics Teaching
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Marina Milner-Bolotin, Univ. of British Columbia
column18: There is a common view of the division between arts and sciences. While arts people are the ones who often lack mathematical skills, scientists are often considered to be the ones who lack imagination. There is nothing further from the truth that this claim. Imagination plays as big a role in sciences as it does it arts. Imagination is very important in helping students enhance their critical thinking skills, achieve better conceptual understanding, and become more motivated and interested in physics learning. The talk will discuss a case study of an inquiry-based college level introductory physics course (N = 250 students) at a large public university and the ways of helping students develop their scientific imagination and be motivated to use it during physics problem solving. Various teaching methods for achieving these goals will be discussed and student feedback related to these types of activities will be presented.

column5: The Physics of Brewing Beer
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: The brewing of beer, even at the homebrewing level, has a great deal of physics phenomena to consider. These include concepts of density, buoyancy, pressure, fluid flow, and many others. This presentation will give some examples of these physics applications, and how many of these are appropriate for a college classroom, even when homebrewing is not.

column5: Operational View of Quantum Mechanics
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Quantum mechanics has immense importance to modern technologies and is also a subject that most students have traditionally found both difficult and abstract. This research project aimed to isolate key concepts, identify learning and teaching difficulties, and so provide both teachers and curriculum developers with a useful resource. A grounded theory approach allowed the research initially to cast a wide net over a number of data sources providing the foundations on which to build the study. A phenomenological approach was then adopted to conduct 48 interviews involving 35 undergraduate and 15 postgraduate physics students from the University of Sydney. A schematic overview will be presented to provide a model which represents the sampled students' operational view of quantum mechanics within the contextual framework of the discipline. The nature of and the relationships between the five identified themes will then be presented.

column5: Impact of the December 2004 Tsunami on Education in Sri Lanka
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Kandiah Manivannan, Southwest Missouri State Univ.
column18: The massive earthquake measuring 9.3 on the Richter scale triggered the powerful tsunami that ravaged the Indian Ocean region on December 26, 2004, destroying thousands of lives and livelihoods in several countries, including the island nation of Sri Lanka. Approximately 100 schools were damaged, affecting about 200,000 school-aged children. We will discuss the physics of tsunamis and present an overview of the educational system in Sri Lanka; in addition, we will examine the impact of the tsunami on education and suggest ways to offer help. As educators associated with the American Association of Physics Teachers, we could best help by providing long-term assistance with rebuilding their education. Such assistance might include initiating a "Goodwill Ambassador" program that would allow U.S. educators to visit the affected nations to help rebuild their educational programs, or establishing a "Tsunami Relief Scholarship Fund" to be distributed among educators in these nations for their educational or outreach activities.

column5: Uniform (Vertical?) Circular Motion
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: A. John Mallinckrodt, Cal Poly Pomona
column18: Can an object attached to a string be whirled in a vertical circle at constant speed? It isn't hard to see that, in principle, the answer is yes and it is a worthy and amusing exercise to determine the required motion of the held end of the string for various values of three dimensionless parameters describing the speed, the drag force on the object, and the length of the string. The analysis will be supplemented with animations created using the Interactive Physics software.

column5: Bose-Einstein Condensation: Quantum Weirdnes When Flirting with Absolute Zero
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Carl E Wieman, Univ. of Colorado
column18: In 1924 Einstein predicted that a gas would undergo a dramatic transformation at a sufficiently low temperature (Bose-Einstein condensation or "BEC"). In 1995, my group was able to observe this transformation by cooling a gas sample to less than 100 billionths of a degree above absolute zero. The atoms in the BEC lose their individual identities and behave as a single quantum wave function. BEC, although large enough to be easily seen and manipulated, exhibits the nonintuitive quantum behavior normally important only at much tinier size scales. The study and use of the curious properties of BEC has now become an important subfield of atomic physics with many connections to condensed matter. I will discuss how we create BEC and some of the subsequent research we and others have done on it. Interactive applets as a tool for teaching science will be demonstrated.

column5: Physics Teachers' Attitudes and Beliefs About the Teaching of Science and Math
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Kathleen A Falconer, SUNY-Buffalo State College
column17: Joseph L Zawick, Daniel MacIsaac, David Henry
column18: The Science Teaching Efficacy Belief Instrument (STEBI), and the Maryland Collaborative Teacher Preparation (MCTP) Instrument: Attitudes and Beliefs about the Nature of and the Teaching on Mathematics and Science were chosen as ways of measuring teachers' attitudes and beliefs about science and mathematics and the teaching of science and mathematics. A discussion including reliability of measures and validity estimates will be presented. These measures were administered as part of the Physics Teaching Pathways Coalition (PTP) project at Buffalo State College. This study assessed the attitudes and beliefs of teachers participating in four different intensive graduate credit summer courses for physics teachers over two summers. Statistically significant gains in the conceptual physics understanding were found for all courses. However, there were significant decreases in attitudes and beliefs as measured by the STEBI and the MCTP's instruments. These efficacy decreases may reflect better informed participant self-assessment of their understanding of physics content and to their teaching practice by the courses.

column5: Research Experiences with Undergraduates in Materials Preparation, Characterization, and Microfabrication*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column17: David J Lawrence, John A Gotwald
column18: Thermal microsensors have applications in infrared detection and calorimetry. They may also have applications as chemical and bio sensors capable of detecting selected antigens. Examples of interdisciplinary student-faculty research in materials, microfabricated thermopiles and thermistor devices are presented. Vanadium oxide VOx thin films have been prepared by dc and rf magnetron sputtering in an argon-oxygen atmosphere. Films deposited with little oxygen are metallic, while films prepared with 10 to 20% oxygen behave like transparent semiconductors. Some semiconducting VOx films have negative temperature coefficients of resistance which are of interest for thermistor microsensors. Sensitivities as high as 7 mV/-aC (millivolts per degree C) were measured. Recent work has produced thermopiles with antimony-bismuth junctions on polyimide membranes supported by silicon wafers or thin aluminum plates. The sensing regions of these devices have lower thermal mass because they are fabricated on polyimide drumheads. These works are examples of student-faculty research carried out in our Cleanroom Laboratory. During the summer, the laboratory is used for our NSF-funded Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) and related research programs.
column19: *Supported in part by NSF-REU Grant DMR-0353773

column5: The Fruits of Her Work
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: The dedication with which Melba Newell Phillips poured her life into her students, and into the understanding of nature, are enduring monuments to her integrity. The words of Albert Einstein, speaking of Marie Curie in 1935, may be applied to Dr. Phillips today: "At a time when a towering personality has come to the end of her life, let us not merely rest content with recalling what she has given to mankind in the fruits of her work. It is the moral qualities of its leading personalities that are [of] greater significance for a generation and for the course of history than purely intellectual accomplishments. Even these latter are dependent on the stature of character." It is my privilege to review the "fruits of her work," to reflect on Melba Phillips' legacy in writing and research, from the Oppenheimer-Phillips Effect, to "Classical Electricity and Magnetism," to "Principles of Physical Science."

column5: A Course on "Einstein's Ethics"
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: In 1919, Albert Einstein found himself an international celebrity. He used his fame to speak out thoughtfully on matters of justice and human dignity. Einstein was the pacifist who asked President Roosevelt to support nuclear weapons research on the eve of WWII; the Jewish Zionist who urged amity with Arabs; the scholar who wanted solitude but was thrust upon the world stage. In the spring of 2005 we offered a course on Einstein's life, physics, and times. We focused especially on his responses to ethical dilemmas that faced him personally and the world of his time. A study of Einstein's ethics is appropriate today, given the ethical dilemmas that face society in the twenty-first century. The year 2005 marks the centennial of Einstein's five 1905 papers that have set the agenda of physics ever since. Our course may also be seen as part of that celebration of the man and his principles.

column5: Science Festival in Ostrow, Poland, for the World Year in Physics 2005
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Rafal Jakubowski, Gimnazjum Gorzyce Junior H.S.
column18: Science Festivals in Europe have been held for over 10 years. The first was in Edinburgh in Scotland. In Poland the oldest science festivals are in Warsaw, Wroclaw and Poznan and this is the eighth year which they will be held. The principle organizers are the universities. Our small town in Ostrow organized its first Ostrowian Science Festival in the World Year of Physics 2005. Teachers from Ostrow with the help of the community and local governemt including the local community "Prometeusz" want to show ostrowian citizens and students the world of science, especially physics. We have a dedicated website (http://www.festiwal.osw.pl) where abstracts of all the presentations are available and information on and about the festival can be found. Lecturers from numerous universities, including University in Poznan, Technical University in Poznan, Warsaw University in Warsaw, and Wroclaw University participated. Students participated in three competitions. Two of them were competitions using PowerPoint for high school level physics, chemistry or biology on the progress of civilization, with a similar competition for the junior high school level. The third competition was a poster with the theme "Physics and Chemistry Around Us." I will show the results and interest in our science Festival and how it impacts physics education and interst from the perspective of students.

column5: Advances in Ceramic Technology
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Ceramics are lightweight and highly resistant to heat and wear making them ideal substitutes for metals and other structural materials. Advances show that ceramic materials are a long-term, cost-effective solution for a wide range of applications such as fuel cell systems, custom membranes, sensors, and air and water purification. The use of ceramics in the past have been limited because of high fabrication costs and manufacturing defects, but on-going efforts to improve ceramic processing show promising results. Areas of ceramic processing such tape casting, laser cutting, and lamination will be discussed.

column5: International Toys In Space: Freefall Physics Results Are In
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Carolyn Sumners, Houston Museum of Natural Science
column18: On April 12, 1985, the Space Shuttle Discovery carried the first 11 toys into orbit. The STS-54 and STS-77 missions added 29 more to the Toys in Space program. In 2002, the Expedition 5 crew tested 16 international toys and sports activities on the International Space Station where there is more room for sports. A few dozen toys and a few hours of astronaut video bring the experience and the surprises of free-fall to students of all ages. Participants discover how to play soccer, shoot marbles, throw a boomerang, and jump a rope in microgravity. The session includes take home patterns for constructing a boomerang that always returns (except in space), a reproduceable and scalable paper flipper, and a truly chaotic yoyo. Each participant also receives the just-released DVD from NASA showing the video results of all the Toys in Space missions. Dr. Sumners is Director of the Toys in Space program for the Johnson Space Center.

column5: New Technologies to Teach Space Weather*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: We are using two different, engaging technologies to teach Space Weather to students of all ages and their teachers. We use immersive fulldome video in our portable digital theater to immerse the viewers in the science. Animations of Coronal Mass Ejections, terrestrial magnetic fields, and other earth science topics as well as more traditional astronomy and solar system shows have been developed. We were the first to put earth and space physics into a digital planetarium! We also use a ham radio course to teach space weather and introduce students to physics and electronics. Recent disasters such as the tsunami, 911 and the Columbia tragedy point out that ham radio is still a critical means of communication, as well as a great way to teach physics. We have taught students in summer camps as young as 8 years up to teachers in our Master of Science Teaching program, and the smiles when they build their own AM radio (winding their own coils) or pass their technician test is worth it all.

column5: The Power of Symmetry
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: Einstein, Shakespear and Bach tower as preeminent figures in their field, and share several characteristic similarities. All were profoundly aware that man was not the center of the universe. All sought elegance and simplicity as the guiding principals of their work. All sought to isolate the guiding principles, the fundamental constants of nature, and yet, all became popular , timeless icons of society. The first part of my talk will focus on a simple idea Einstein came up with reading a children's book when he was 16 years old. The second part of the talk will focus on an idea that Einstein, a twenty three old married man at the time working in the Swiss Patent Office, entertained where he imagined planets of the solar system as marbles rolling around in a large bowl centered at the sun.

column5: Perimeter Institute's International Summer School for Young Physicists
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Donald Franklin, St. Johns Country Day School
column18: Perimeter Institute in Waterloo, Canada, has set a goal of bringing modern physics to high school students in our world. Last year they were able to bring together 20 Canadian students and 22 students from seven countries. This year they expect to have even more countries send two of their best students to study theoretical physics at the home of "today's Einsteins." This year's program will be from August 6th to the 20th. Please check the website: http://www.youngphysicist.ca

column5: Pneumatic Potato Launcher for Projectile Motion Studies and Discrepant Event
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Don Cameron, Univ. of Denver H.S.
column18: Making use of PVC piping materials, a bicycle pump, potatoes, and measuring devices students safely shoot potato slugs 30 or more meters in distance. Making use of projectile motion equations we are able to accurately calculate the initial velocity from the end of the barrel and the forces necessary to propel the potato. Good agreement with projectile motion models are obtained. Students learn that the critical factor for repeatable projectile motion is not pressure, angle, or acceleration length, but the potato seal and valve turning time. This discrepant result teaches them the value of repeatable procedures, but also the messiness of science. This presentation will cover the Problem Based Learning lab approach. The standard militaristic projectile motion problem has been turned into a benevolent food delivery device challenge to save a dying species. Practical diagrams and parts lists for building your own apparatus for demonstration or classroom use are included.

column5: SPS Chapter Lures 300+ High School Students to Campus with Trebuchet
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column17: Eric Peterson, Nick Koehn, Chris Williams, Ben Morhardt
column18: Enrollments in Engineering Physics have been down considerably over the past decade at our institution. Interest in science and technology seemed to be flagging within the local district. Annually since the mid-90's, the Statics and Dynamics classes have built projectile launchers. This year the class offered to combine their efforts into one large 44 foot behemoth and employ the assistance of the SPS Chapter they were all members of, to: assemble; market; and deliver a very successful program. Details of of this event and the club's role in it will be explored.

column5: GK-12 Instruction in Optics for Middle School
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Steven Green, Univ. of New Mexico
column18: This talk will present the GK-12 Optics related lessons and experiments presented to middle school students. There will be a disussion of what was and was not succesful in the classroom and suggestions for improvement.

column5: Teaching and Learning Physics, Earth and Space Science in a "Kid's Cave"*
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Carolyn Sumners, Houston Museum of Natural Science
column18: Immersive technology brings the experience to the student, surrounding him or her in the science. Our new portable fulldome projection system takes it to their schools. We will demonstrate our portable system, and some of the visualizations that we use to teach space physics, solar system, and earth science (as well as astronomy) in an engaging setting. Our research has shown that three-dimensional topics are better learned in a three-dimensional setting.

column5: Weight-Detecting Capillary Viscometer
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Rafael M Digilov, Israel Inst. of Tech.,
column18: The flow of water from a vertical column through a discharge capillary tube was detected with the force sensor. The measurements showed that the change of the liquid-mass in a column with time is not pure exponentially as follows from Poiseuille's law. Associating observed deviations with the kinetic energy correction, the approximate formula for the decay of a liquid-mass with time has been derived that excellent describes experimental data. The feasibility and accuracy of used approach was tested with viscosity determination of distilled water at room temperature and also excellent agreement with referential value was obtained. As a result, a simple, inexpensive and very suitable for high school and college or university physical-chemistry laboratories, the weight detecting capillary viscometer is proposed.

column5: The Advantages of Your Own Remote Robotic Observatory in Australia
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: We have explored the feasibility and advantages of owning a robotic observatory located in Australia but operated locally. The advantages are that the telescope would be located in a place with dark, pollution free, southern skies, a large number of clear nights and allow real time observing during class time over the internet, because the nighttime hours in Australia are daylight hours in the USA. This would be a powerful tool for hands on Astronomy. Support for such an enterprise requires proof that such a facility will have pedagogical advantages over an observatory that is built locally or over students obtaining astronomical images and data from the web. We plan to investigate these issues.

column5: The Quantum Interference of Particle Waves
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column18: The interference of particle waves lies at the heart of our quantum description of matter. Optical interference patterns observed by Thomas Young were (eventually) accepted as definitive proof that light is a wave and not a particle, as suggested by Newton. Quantum mechanics describes light, electrons and atoms have both wave-like and particle-like. Whenever we detect the minimal unit of light or matter in a modern version of Young?s double slit experiment, we detect a particle, and yet the sum of many particle detections generates an interference pattern that is described by the mathematics of waves. We believe that the quantum description of interference is not merely a mathematical convenience, but is an essential feature of nature. While quantum interference lies at the heart of our inability to intuitively understand quantum mechanics, we have learned to use these phenomena to create the most sensitive measuring instruments we have today.

column5: Reforming Introductory Physics Courses at Research Universities
column7: 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting: Salt Lake City, UT
column15: Gary Gladding, Univ. of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign
column18: In 1995, the Department of Physics at the University of Illinois embarked on a program to systematically reform all of the introductory courses in the calculus-based sequence. By the Spring Semester of 2000, all 2600 students taking introductory courses (both calculus-based and algebra-based sequences) were participating in reformed classes (see: http://www.physics.uiuc.edu/Research/PER/Course_Revisions.html). I will describe our experiences as a case study of reform at research universities. In particular, I will discuss the elements of our reform and offer some reflections on the difficulties of establishing and sustaining reform in the research university environment.

column5: Investigation of the Magnetic Damping on an Air Track
column18: A novel experimental method has been introduced for studying the magnetic damping on a non-ferromagnetic air track. Due to the continuous and persisting interaction between the moving magnets fixed on the air track glider and the horizontal air-track, the experiment can be carried out with low-cost photoelectric detecting techniques. A simple theoretical model has been proposed based on the Faraday's and Ampere's laws, and analytical expression has been deduced to explain the experimental results. A new explaination based on the interaction of eddy current and horizontal component of magnetic field is given for the rotation problem in all moving metal plate and static magnetic field experiment approaches met. Systematic experiments were performed with home-developed apparatus and the results agree well with the theoretical model. The rotation problem is automatically suppressed in our method and provides a simple and instructive platform to teach college physics.

column5: Using Computer Models to Understand Arctic Natural Climate Variability and Climate Change
column18: Computer models are invaluable tools for investigating climate since they allow us to do computer experiments on the climate that are not possible to do with the real climate. These physically based models have strengths and weaknesses, which must be kept in mind as the model output is analyzed. Results from two studies will be presented from two different types of models, a Global Climate Model (GCM) and a Regional Climate Model (RCM). The GCM project examines the impact of reduced summer arctic sea ice on the high latitude atmospheric circulation. The RCM project is an interdisciplinary study where the model is used to provide temperature and precipitation information over the next century to glaciologists so they can estimate expected melt rates of Alaska glaciers in an enhanced carbon dioxide world.

column5: Ecological Manifestations of Climate Change in Alaska
column15: Glenn P Juday, Univ. of Alaska Fairbanks
column18: Alaska has warmed to levels last experienced at least 1,000 years ago based on tree-ring reconstructions. Temperature regimes apparently shift abruptly because of changes in ocean current systems. Permafrost is warming and thawing, leading to tree toppling. Closed basin lakes are shrinking or have disappeared. Many boreal tree populations in Alaska grow best in cold summers and least in warm summers because of temperature induced drought stress. Overall boreal forest photosynthesis has generally declined since the late 1970s. Trees at treeline show threshold temperature effects on growth. Growth of trees on the coolest and moistest sites is increasing. The Alaskan north slope tundra has become greener. Forest fire extent in Alaska and Yukon Territory reached a record high in 2004 and 2005. Several simultaneous forest health problems have appeared, and insect outbreaks have killed trees over large areas. The Arctic Climate Impact Assessment documents warming across the circumpolar north.

column5: Positive Epistemological Change Through Multi-Representational Problem Solving Skills
column15: Andy Buffler, Univ. of Cape Town
column18: A significant proportion of first-time entering university physics students may be characterised as having poor numeracy and problem solving skills coupled with negative attitudes towards learning physics. Their high school experience has often left them with a perception of physics as a formula-driven, mathematical discipline with little or no connection to either their everyday lives or future careers. Such inappropriate epistemologies can hamper life-long learning by precluding students from developing conceptual mastery and from assimilating valuable generic skills such as problem solving. The present work aimed at exploring whether explicit development of multi-representational approaches to problem solving can directly promote positive attitudes towards learning physics. A number of benchmarking instruments were used, including the Maryland Physics Expectations Survey, which revealed a significantly positive shift in the students' views about their own learning. The students' performance in their introductory physics course also improved markedly.

column5: Effective Instructional Strategies for Pre-Service Elementary School Science Courses
column15: Thomas Callaway, Stephen F. Austin State Univ.
column18: The departments of Physics and Astronomy and of Chemistry at Stephen F. Austin State University offer a team taught introductory physical science course for pre-service elementary school teachers which has demonstrated effectiveness in changing student attitude towards science. The course has served as a model for other science courses for pre-service teachers taught at our university. We present the results of pre-/post-course surveys as evidence of our success.

column5: From Alaska to Jupiter: Contributions to the Galileo Mission
column18: The Geophysical Institute was a member of the Energetic Particle Detector Team of NASA's planetary mission Galileo, participating in the study of the plasma and high-energy radiation environment of Jupiter, its moon Io as both source and sink of particles, and the newly discovered "mini-magnetosphere" of moon Ganymede. Beset with a number of initial mishaps, this mission became a milestone in the history of space science and technology. I will briefly review some of the technical features and general scientific achievements of this mission, and then concentrate on the most significant scientific findings with data from our instrument, a complex multiple detector/spectrometer system designed to measure fluxes over a wide range of particle mass, charge, and energy. I will point out how the story of this mission can serve as an excellent tool to develop interest of high school physics students in basic space research with unmanned missions.

column5: The Gender Gap in Physics: Explanations, Data, Analysis
column18: In an address delivered in 2005, Harvard President Lawrence Summers proposed three possible explanations for the gender gap in physics participation, particularly at the highest levels of academic employment: high powered job, different availability of aptitude at the high end, and different socialization and patterns of persistent discrimination. Although acknowledging the possibility of all three, Summers alleged but did not present evidence primarily in favor of the second hypothesis. In this talk I will review the evidence supporting all three possibilities, as well as an extension of the socialization and discrimination hypothesis, i.e., the possibility that the gender gap is the result of the nature of science as it is currently construed. In addition, I will discuss the implications of each of these alternatives in terms of how (and in fact whether) the gender gap can and should be addressed.

column5: The Gender Gap in Physics: Some Research Results
column18: There is still a gender gap in the performance of students in introductory physics courses, particularly on standardized tests such as the Force Concept Inventory. In this talk I will present results from several years of research, done both at the University of Minnesota and Miami University, which illuminate what some of these gaps are. In addition, some research results will point us to possible explanations of why these gaps exist.

column5: Making Sense of Students' Thoughts About a Class's Goals
column15: Gordon J. Aubrecht, Ohio State Univ.
column17: Dedra Demaree, Yuhfen Lin, David Brookes, Xueli Zou
column18: Students intending to become teachers take Physics by Inquiry courses at Ohio State. (The course is open to other nonscience majors as well.) We assess student perceptions of the Physics by Inquiry course using a Q-sort assessment. The assessment forces students to categorize the extent to which they think twenty-five descriptive statements characterize their laboratory class experience. They sort the statements from most to least characteristic of the course into bins of succesive size 2, 6, 9, 6, 2 (forcing a "normal" distribution). We describe how we can glean information about students' perceptions of the class by examining differences from the "average" values. We find significant differences among different classes and between students and instructors.

column5: What Physics Was Involved in the 2003 Midwest Blackout?
column18: The northeast and midwest grid collapsed on 14 August 2003. This postere will describe what happened and discuss the physics involved.

column5: Assessing student perceptions of modeling instruction at a Hispanic-Serving Institution
column15: Priscilla M Pamela, Florida International Univ.
column17: Jeffery M Saul, Laird Kramer, George O'Brien

The CHEPREO community includes high school students and teachers, undergraduate and graduate students, and university faculty incorporating physics modeling instruction, QuarkNet, and Treisman-based study groups. Part of the project includes offering modeling physics sections of calculus-based introductory physics course at Florida International University. The student population in the two-semester sequence for the past few years is 62% Hispanic and 12.6% Black/African American. The male/female ratio is 60%/40%. Students from these modeling classes in the fall 2005 semester were interviewed using the small focus group protocol developed by Morgan & Saul

column5: Modern Physics with Health Applications
column18: We have been teaching an upper division Modern Physics with Health Applications course for several years now at Pacific University. This course seeks to teach the standard Modern Physics curriculum in a framework of projects related to Health Applications. The three projects are related to nuclear medicine, x-ray treatment, and magnetic resonance imaging. Our physics curriculum strives to transition students from the first year physics course to the requirements of independent research for our senior students. This course is a very important first step in that transition. Students keep a laboratory notebook, do project reports, and work from equipment manuals with a minimum of guidance. A report of the successes and challenges of this course will be presented, as well as plans to further improve this course.

column5: A State of the Art Astronomy Laboratory: ASU's GoTo Facility
column17: Joe T Pollock, R. Lee Hawkins, Dan B Caton, Roger O Gray
column18: Providing introductory astronomy labs with observational activities performed locally by the students is challenging. Uncertain weather, long setup times, and bulky equipment all make it difficult to offer observational labs with the same degree of rigor and quantitative analysis as is found in other science labs. Appalachian State University's new state-of-the-art GoTo Astronomy Facility is designed to address these difficulties, allowing a fleet of eighteen 10-inch GoTo telescopes equipped with CCD cameras to be permanently mounted in a large moving roof structure. Since useful data can be now be obtained on marginal nights and those too cold to be outside for extended periods, this facility will allow us to conduct observing on a more consistent basis, while offering realistic observational exercises focused on the analysis of data that students have obtained for themselves. This facility will serve as a test bed and model to encourage construction of similar facilities elsewhere.

column5: Progressing to Inquiry-Based Learning with Cosmic Rays*

column18: Teachers and students across the country are observing cosmic rays using scintillation detectors in their classrooms. They upload the data to our web-based E-Lab portal where they can use their browser to analyze the data to discover the muon lifetime, energetic air showers and flux rate dependencies then share their results with others through on-line posters. The E-Lab portal provides the tools to support inquiry rather than recipes that might constrain it. The cosmic ray E-Lab also provides resources for teachers and students that lack the in-class hardware. Teachers, students, and guests now actively use the QuarkNet E-Lab portal to organize their cosmic ray research. We focus on how a teacher grows their way into this in-depth use of the cosmic ray E-Lab for real, applied physics research. We will showcase examples of several QuarkNet teacher's integration of the cosmic ray E-Lab tools into their teaching and look at the student responses to the open approach of self-guided research.

column5: What's Entropy? Student Understanding of Thermodynamics in an Introductory Physics Course*
column18: Continuing with our previous investigations into student understanding of thermal physics in an introductory calculus-based course, we have probed students' ideas regarding entropy and the second law of thermodynamics. Nearly 90% of students enrolled in the class have had previous exposure to thermodynamics concepts in chemistry and/or high school physics courses, so many have specific ideas about these concepts before instruction begins. We will present free-response and multiple-choice data collected both pre- and post-instruction from the previous three semesters. Evidence suggests that many key concepts, e.g., that the entropy of the universe increases for all non-ideal processes, remain highly resistant to instruction, although students seem to make progress in understanding certain thermodynamic relationships.

column5: Eigenvalue Statistics of Weakly Driven One-Dimensional Quantum Systems
column18: Unlike most integrable quantum systems, the eigenvalues of one-dimensional time-independent systems do not generally follow Poisson statistics. The eigenvalues of periodically driven one-dimensional systems in the limit of zero field strength may exhibit Poisson statistics. We study how the frequency of the driving field and the number of eigenvalues computed affect the eigenvalue statistics for the linear potential well, the harmonic oscillator, and the infinite square well. The weakly driven linear potential well is found to exhibit Poisson statistics regardless of the frequency of the driving field, while the harmonic oscillator never follows Poisson statistics. As the frequency of the driving field becomes more irrational, the eigenvalue statistics for the infinite square well make a transition from statistics that are clearly not Poisson to statistics that are very close to Poisson.

column5: Aurora: A Signature of the Planet
column18: Aurora is a distinctive and characteristic response of the atmosphere of a planet with a magnetic field to bombardment by the solar wind. It displays information about the magnetic and atmospheric environment of the planet as well as providing a wonderful light show that impresses the observer with its beauty and activity. Through a selection of auroral images obtained in the Fairbanks district, covering a full range of different types, the physical processes will be discussed. Using some observations from satellites and simulations of space plasmas shown as movies, the aurora will be shown from the perspective of an astronaut or near-space visitor to Earth, Jupiter, and Saturn. A short survey of radio emissions and ionospheric currents resulting from the aurora will be given. The lecture will end with some speculations on the use of aurora to investigate the atmospheres of planets external to our solar system.

column5: Unleashing Action
column15: Edwin Taylor, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
column18: Newton helps us to predict motion: Will an incoming asteroid miss the earth? Increasingly we also have the power to control motion: Firing a space probe from earth orbit to moon orbit. The action principle is the tool of choice when initial and final conditions are specified. Because action manages motion using scalar energy, it is easily generalized to three dimensions, multi-particle systems, and motion under constraint. Historical giants and current textbooks: 1) make errors, which we are gradually correcting, and 2) speak in advanced formalism, which we are progressively simplifying to skirt equations of motion entirely. Fundamental principles embodied directly and transparently in interactive computer displays empower students to explore motion in ways heretofore unavailable to them. See for yourself at http://www.eftaylor.com/software/ActionClockTicks.

column5: Modeling of Magnetically-Coupled Rotors
column15: Tiara Norris, California State Univ., Chico
column18: An intriguing oscillatory system can be created using small magnets fixed on the edge of parallel rotating planes. This investigation began by examining the behavior of such an oscillator constructed with "Geomag" magnetic toys. In attempting to model the system, a simplified version of the problem was considered: two magnetic dipoles separated along a common axis of rotation. The observed effect is an oscillation in velocity between the sections of the toy. The model's predictions were compared to data collected from a simplified oscillator apparatus and match surprisingly well.

column5: Moving from Transfer to Discovery: Social Networking Software for Education
column15: Curt Madison, Univ. of Alaska Fairbanks
column18: The power of electronic communication to build ad hoc community is facilitated by social networking software. As the challenges for participation get reduced, students, researchers, and professors are finding many new ways to engage learners. Social networking software allows information to be exchanged in new timely and nuanced ways never before seen. People are engaging in ways similar to remote sensing with remote interpretations. Social networking software allows an aggregation of queries to a knowledge base that uncovers additional ironic juxtapositions. Naturally there is controversy. Should we trust Wikipedia? Why not? Should we trust a folksonomy of categorization? Why not? Finally, what is amenable to worthwhile uses of social networking software in the service of education?

column5: Over the Moon with Carbon Nanotubes
column15: Nadya Mason, Univ. of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
column18: Tiny cylinders of carbon, termed carbon nanotubes, have become a highlight of nanotechnology research. With diameters as small as a billionth of a meter, and lengths up to a millimeter, these unique structures can be stronger than steel, as flexible as drinking straws, and more conductive than copper. Their amazing electrical and mechanical properties give nanotubes enormous potential for both fundamental physics and applications. Current research ranges from studies of quantum interference in individual tubes to the creation of a nanotube-based space elevator. In this lecture, I will discuss the synthesis, properties, and applications of carbon nanotubes, and show their potential to revolutionize science and technology.

column5: How I Learned To Stop Worrying About Schrodinger's Cat
column15: Hans Christian von Baeyer, College of William and Mary
column18: Anxiety about quantum weirdness, symbolized by Schrdingers cat, has been with us for eighty years, but the last forty have brought promise of relief. Theoretical and experimental progress has inspired many different schemes for making sense of the counterintuitive rules of quantum mechanics<0x2014>but one concept comes up repeatedly. As mediator between the objective reality of the atom, say, and its subjective understanding by the human brain, the slippery concept of information suggests itself. The word was used in connection with the meaning of quantum mechanics by Schrdinger himself, and seems particularly appropriate in our computer age. Nevertheless, one hunts in vain for the word in the indexes of introductory physics books. Introducing information into the study of the foundations of quantum mechanics has the advantage of bringing new tools, such as information theory and Bayesian thinking, to the task. It has cured my quantum felinophobia.

column5: A Tale of Two Universes
column18: Over the last forty years, cosmologists have converged on a story of the universe that begins with a big bang followed by eternal expansion and cooling. At present, the universe is accelerating towards a vacuous oblivion. Recently, a radically different story has been proposed that revives the old idea of a cyclic universe and challenges nearly every aspect of the standard tale. The historic problems with earlier cyclic models are finessed using imaginative new ideas emerging from string theory. According to the cyclic story, the universe evolves from big bang to big crunch about once every trillion year, and the events that shaped the large scale structure of the cosmos today took place a cycle ago, before the last big bang. This talk will introduce the two divergent views of cosmic history, showing how each can explain current astronomical observations and how they may be distinguished by future measurements.

column5: Space Science in American High School Classrooms: The TeachSpace Experience*

We received over 100 nominations to our announcement and 37 awardees completed the workshops. The program consisted of 12 sessions during which developed lesson plans were examined, hands-on exercises were provided, and low-cost/no-cost demonstrations were explored. A website and a Blackboard-based, online classroom were established for participants. An exit survey was administered and analyzed. In the second year, the program was expanded to Arizona and Washington states. A mentoring program has been initiated to insure that the TeachSpace is propagated to other teachers and schools. The third year activities are being planned.

column5: Some of the Interesting Physics of the Polar Ozone Hole
column15: David Newman, Univ. of Alaska Fairbanks
column18: Turbulence is nearly ubiquitous in nature and turbulent transport is the fundamental transport mechanism (for example the spreading of pollutants) in many complex dynamical systems, from astrophysical plasmas to geophysical fluids (such as the atmosphere and ocean). In addition to such turbulent fluctuations, mean flows often exist in these systems. Because the turbulence is often the primary mechanism for transport, the interaction between the sheared mean flows and the turbulent fluctuations is of fundamental importance in understanding the dynamics of that transport. This talk will explore some of the basic interactions between turbulence and sheared flows in the context of the Polar Ozone Holes. We will present some simple models that capture much of the important dynamics. On the way to understanding the dynamics of these important structures we will look at a number of simple but fascinating models of the nonlinear system, including a simple phase transition model and a cellular automata sandpile model.

column5: Sliding Below the Melting Point: Environmental Effects of Premelting Ice
column18: Water and ice are powerful agents of erosion, molding the natural landscape through the action of rivers, waves and glaciers.The transformation of water to ice also causes massive weathering, familiar on small scales as frost damage to roads and brick work. Deformations of the ground surface, known as frost heave, are driven by powerful forces within premelted liquid films. These are thin (typically nm-scale) layers of melt that separate the ice surfaces from foreign substrates. Premelting dynamics have impressive macroscopic consequences for such diverse phenomena as the sliding of glaciers, chemical uptake on atmospheric ice particles, the scintering of snow fields, the electrification of thunder clouds, and frost heave itself. The physics of premelted films and their influence on the natural environment are the focus of this talk.

How do students select and evaluate what they find on the Internet? To prepare the millennial generation for successful academic and professional careers, teachers at all levels need to integrate in the curriculum ways to help students develop critical thinking skills that question the information that they intend to use. Physics teachers have an even more difficult task in addressing this need, because of the nature of the subject being taught. Working with our students, we have developed several IMMEX problems for high school physics as part of National Science Foundation grant #ESI-0323036. Each problem set begins with a context rich scenario and a specific question to answer. Students are free to explore a wide range of data and information related to the problem; some of these data are relevant while others may be extraneous or repetitious. The IMMEX tracking tools keep a tally of the information students access, whether they ultimately solve the problem, and even their problem-solving efficiency. column5: Sea, Ice, and Snow: Agents of Climate Change
column15: John Walsh, Univ. of Alaska Fairbanks
column18: Sea ice and snow cover are characterized by high reflectivities and by their ability to insulate the underlying land or ocean from extreme temperatures of the lower atmosphere. The loss of snow and ice cover accelerates warming of the land and ocean, thereby enhancing the retreat of snow and ice. This process represents a positive feedback of climate change. The spatial patterns of greenhouse warming in global climate models contain a strong signature of this feedback. The signal extends to projected changes of sea-level pressure and precipitation. In addition, the upper soil layers are prone to permafrost degradation as the longer snow-free season enhances the depth and warming of the summer thaw (active) layer. Global climate model results now being used in climate change assessments will be used to illustrate the effects of snow and sea ice on scenarios of future climate change.

column5: Climate Variability and Change in Alaska

However, an underlying characteristic that complicates the determination of trends, particularly at high latitudes, is the low frequency variability that is observed in climate records. For Alaska, we have reliable climate data dating back to the beginning of the 20th century, with the most homogeneous records dating to about 1950. A short discussion of Alaska climatology will be given along with observed variability and long-term change of various climate parameters, highlighted by changes in extreme events such as low winter temperatures, summer droughts, wildfires, and erosive storms.

column5: A Causal Approach to Teaching Introductory Physics
column18: The purpose of this research is to develop a more intuitively sound "Forces First" curriculum to teach high school level introductory physics. The course is to be taught in two passes. This approach is used to prevent students from learning only how to arrive at answers without learning the actual physical concepts, and also to protect the students from feeling overwhelmed by information. Key features of this curriculum are: emphasis on and student participation in the learning and teaching process, writing skills, physics lingo, and experimental skills; separating the model from the concept; and teaching kinematics based on forces.

column5: Computation Across the Physics Curriculum
column18: A key part of doing science is building models. At the undergraduate level these models are expressed primarily in terms of differential equations. However, most realistic models cannot be solved analytically and computation becomes essential. In addition, many models can be better posed as cellular automata or in terms of an algorithm such as a Monte Carlo simulation. Also, much of experimental physics depends on the computer control of instruments and the numerical analysis of data. The present undergraduate curriculum is too formal and includes few of these computational approaches. We argue that computation in its various forms should be a much more significant part of the curriculum along with a return to a greater emphasis on laboratory work. In this way students will be able to do physics in a way that is much closer to how actual research is done, will be able to consider more qualitative and conceptual issues, and will be able to consider a broader range of systems including those found in biology.

column5: Teaching Magnetic Forces and Magnetic Field Topics in Physics Laboratory
column15: Roman Kezerashvili, New York City Technical College
column18: We propose a list of designed experiments that could be presented at the laboratory class in the second semester of college and university physics courses to study magnetic forces, the magnetic field, and the electromagnetic induction. In the first experiment, students study the dependence of the magnitude of the magnetic force on the current-carrying wire on the current, the length of the wire, and the angle between the current direction and the direction of the field, and verify the right-hand-rule. The purpose of the second experiment is to analyze a magnetic interaction between two parallel current-carrying conductors and to show that the force of interaction is directly proportional to the currents and varies inversely with the distance of separation of the wires. The other experiment is designed to study Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction when a permanent magnet is moved through a coil, determine the dependence of induced emf on the rate at which the magnetic flux of the permanent magnet changes, and to verify Lenz's law. The objectives of all experiments are to show the real action of physics laws, help students better understand and visualize the subject of the lecture.

To prepare the film, we first had to find a working recipe for photolithographic patterning, which includes spinning on photosensitive chemicals, evaporating a thin layer of metal, and removing the metal in the unwanted pattern areas. We will discuss the detail of our fabrication process and present electrical transport measurements for our junctions.

column5: Kepler's Astronomia Nova in the Classroom
column18: "The Copernican Revolution," a new general-education science course at Berry College, gives special attention to Johannes Kepler's Astronomia Nova. This work contains not merely the statements of Kepler's so-called first and second laws of planetary motion, but an intimate account of his struggle to discover them. To persevere, Kepler had to question centuries-old assumptions and face multiple blind alleys, miscalculations, and self-deceptions. Numerous themes are evident in the study of the Astronomia Nova: the scientist's faith in a comprehensible universe, the roles of assumptions and "common sense," the nature of scientific models, and the interplay between observation and theory, among others. Kepler's idealistic personality and vivid life narrative provide a colorful context for these ideas. The hope is that by hearing such a story, students may come to understand the process of science which is so well-hidden in today's popular press and scientific literature.

column5: Physics, Physiology and Technology
column18: Physics, Physiology & Technology is a physics first course designed for all high school students by the University of Hawai'i's Curriculum Research and Development Group. When the principles of physics in a unit are investigated they are followed by the corresponding human physiology topics. The program is based on the principles of constructivism and inquiry with many opportunities for students to handle, build and ponder the equipment they will use to investigate the physical principal under investigation. Students many times will use the POE (predict, observe, explore) model to investigate a problem. Mathematically, the students develop models from the qualitative to the quantitative with data they have collected. The course is comprised of 14 units from Inertia to Light with the corresponding physiology topics following the physics. A cadre of about 20 teachers, trained in the program, is collecting data from pre and post tests using the Force Concepts Inventory.

column5: Vehicular Emissions of VOC and NOx: Present Trends
column17: Jewel Gomes, Peter Wiesen, Ralf Kurtenbach, David L Cocke
column18: Road traffic emissions produced by the combustion of fossil fuels are one of the most significant sources of primary air pollutants. Despite the successful implementation of catalytic converters in gasoline vehicles and other pollutant reduction systems for diesel vehicles, road traffic emissions still remain highly relevant as a major emission source of air pollutants. Volatile organic compounds (VOC) and nitrogen oxides (NOx) are precursors of tropospheric ozone and secondary aerosols causing air pollutant problems of photochemical smog (summer smog) in the outflow of most large cities. In this review, we discuss the present vehicular emission situation of these species in different regions of the world.

column5: On the Distinction of Auroral Events in the Infrared Spectrum.
column18: A method for distinguishing between auroral events and non-auroral phenomenon in the infrared spectrum is described. The distinction is made by looking at phase differences in varying sectors of a series of night-sky CCD images taken from the Geophysical Institute at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. The method was validated by comparing the observed phase shifts to the phase shifts in a synthetic model. The method successfully reduced the amount of time necessary to sort through the infrared data. In the next year we are planning on using this method to evaluate auroral data for a study on daylight aurora.

column5: Atmospheric Aerosol Analysis Using Alaskan LIDAR Data
column15: Jason McDonald, Univ. of Alaska Fairbanks
column18: Using ten channel data taken at the Poker Flats Research Range (PFRR), aerosol structure and makeup for the lower atmosphere (0-30 km) was analyzed. A brief period of the project consisted of taking LIDAR measurements of the lower atmospheric boundary layer using an eye safe LIDAR system on the roof of the Geophysical Institute. The final period of the project involved a four-day period in which height measurements of noctilucent clouds (NLC) were made using the LIDAR systems and PFRR. From the data taken at PFRR we were able to place some NLC heights at 83 km, and we found evidence of possible gravity wave induced motions of the clouds.

column5: Construction of an Aurora Detector*
column18: We are building a working aurora detector from an existing design of Mark Haun's (Haun, Mark A. http://kolonia.keteu.org/~haunma/aurora/aurora.html). The detector monitors the intensity level of visible light at the wavelength of 557.7 nm<0x2014>a common emission line of auroras. To do this, a bandpass filter centered at 557.7 nm is placed in front of a lens and avalanche photodiode (APD), allowing light at the auroral wavelength to be detected. This signal from the APD is compared to that of another photodiode measuring the level of ambient light to determine the aurora's visibility. This comparison is done via a microcontroller circuit, which also enables the detector to interface with an external computer. The resulting detector is able to send alerts by email when an aurora of significant visibility is present. The entire package is housed in a compact, weatherproof box.

column5: A "Great Books" Approach to Teaching the Natural Sciences
column18: The Great Ideas program at Carthage College is a series of courses is based on the close reading and discussion of primary texts in a seminar format. I agreed to develop and teach "Foundations of the Natural Sciences," one of the requirements for a major in Great Ideas. The course, delivered for the first time this past spring, is organized thematically rather than chronologically. Questions such as the finititude of the universe, the laws of motion, and the divisibility of matter arise in context as students read selections from Plato through Einstein. I will discuss how to present Aristotle, Galileo, Newton, Einstein, and others as participants in a "great conversation" that continues today. I will also present in-class activities, student feedback, and assessment results for this approach to teaching a heterogeneous group of students including business, religion, and physics majors.

column5: PMC Variation as Observed by SNOE and SME
column18: Polar Mesospheric Clouds were observed by a limb-scanning ultraviolet spectrometer on the Student Nitric Oxide Explorer (SNOE) through the years 1998 to 2003. The Solar Mesosphere Explorer (SME) observed PMCs from 1981 to 1986 with similar instrumentation. We discuss the seasonal and long-term behavior of PMCs using data from both the SNOE and SME missions.

column5: Overview of the Math and Science Partnership of Southwest Pennsylvania
column15: Joseph Taylor, BSCS Center for Research and Evaluation
column18: One of the primary goals of the Math and Science Partnership (MSP) of Southwest Pennsylvania is to impact student learning in more than 40 area school districts by enhancing the content knowledge, pedagogical knowledge, and leadership capacity of their respective science teachers. In the high school science portion of the partnership, a professional development team consisting of MSP coordinators, higher education faculty, and expert consultants provides a comprehensive program for more than 60 science teachers. The higher education faculty contribute to the content deepening, leadership, and pedagogical aspects of the program. The pedagogical aspects of the program include teaching with curriculum materials that incorporate inquiry-based teaching strategies and learning cycles. An ultimate goal of the partnership is that teachers will lead collaborative professional development structures, such as lesson study, to help colleagues develop deeper understandings of content and pedagogy.

column5: Teaching Relativity to Students Who Don't Like Math
column15: Derek Weisel, William Penn Charter School
column18: Can your students calculate a square root? Do they know what the Pythagorean theorem is? Then your students can understand Einstein's special theory of relativity and get some insight into general relativity. Students who do not like math should not be excluded from learning about amazing physics. A course in relativity can be offered as an elective or as part of a "topics in science course." A course like this can be effective for advanced middle schoolers, all levels of high schoolers, and nonscience majors in colleges. Teaching techniques and resources (textbooks, videos, cheap labs, assessments, and interactive websites) will be discussed.

column5: Using a Blogsite for High School Physics
column15: Donald Franklin, St Johns Country Day School
column17: James Fowler, J G Lantigua, Michael Grove, Michael Potts
column18: Students at St. Johns Country Day School have developed a "student-2-student" program which can help any student with computer access learn Physics. Using the Saxon Physics textbook, the students have all their notes converted to electronic media. Students located in other areas or schools can follow the class notes and ask questions about the notes. The textbook uses a continual review which makes it easier for the student to grasp the concepts. The electronic notes are in color and can be added in sequence when drawing vectors. Peer teaching is a powerful tool, and allows our students to review their skills in the process of teaching other students physics. Any student anywhere should have access to a class in Physics. This system can deliver on that premise.

column5: The Problem with Faculty Problem-Solving Discussion: It's the Language
column17: John T Demel, Richard J Freuler
column18: Faculty teaching physics, mathematics, and engineering courses as part of the Fundamentals of Engineering for Honors (FEH) program at the Ohio State University meet on a weekly basis to discuss ways in which they might better coordinate their classes. Recently we began an effort to coordinate the ways in which problems and problem-solving are discussed in FEH courses, with the hope of making students more effective at approaching and solving problems. A first step was faculty interviews, which revealed differences in the ways individual instructors describe problems and problem solving. We describe these differences, as well as some steps we have taken to develop a common language for future interdisciplinary faculty discussions.

column5: Materials Science and the Nanoworld
column18: Introducing students to the field of materials science and engineering requires an understanding of the interrelationship between the processing of a material, the material's microstructure, and the resulting properties. A series of activities have been developed to demonstrate these relationships as well as introduce the student to materials applications including nanomaterials. Activities explore the relationship between the processing and properties of high carbon steel, model the stability, motion, and interaction of defects and dislocations within a solid, and study the effect of grain growth on the strength and hardness of various metals. Activities also introduce the student to the world of nanotechnology by looking at the mechanical, electrical, and magnetic properties of nanomaterials and their role in technology today and by modeling the various imaging techniques used to study and manipulate the nanoworld.
