column15: Laura M Nickerson, Wright Center for Science Education
column18: Over the last few years, I have redesigned my sections of the Calculus-Based Physics (AP Physics C) courses at the Illinois Mathematics and Science Academy. This course is quite popular at the Academy, with 80-100 students enrolled in both semesters, and about 60 students taking the AP Physics C exam. This course was traditionally taught in a lecture format with instructor-led problem-solving sessions. In my redesign, I used whiteboarding techniques inspired by Modeling, many ideas from

column5: Meeting the Challenges of Student Diversity: My South African Lesson
column18: Students with different scientific backgrounds are posing challenges for instructors teaching introductory and intermediate level physics courses. This presentation will offer a reflection on the educational demands and solutions for an intermediate undergraduate level Mathematical Methods in Physics class in U.S., based on the presenter's South African experience. The approach is based on The Foundation Physics, a one-semester course part of the Science Foundation Program (now known as the General Entry Program in Science) has been successfully running at the University of Cape Town, in South Africa, for 13 years. The course was designed to maximize the chances for success of educationally disadvantaged students in studying for a B.S. degree. Theoretical, laboratory-based experimental, and communication skills components have been designed to equip South African students coming from disadvantaged backgrounds to meet the cognitive demands of a first year university calculus-based physics course.

column5: Conceptual Knowledge Change After a Short Teacher Development Course
column18: Many research reports objectively indicate that active learning methodologies based on the results of PER are by far more effective than traditional teaching in developing the conceptual knowledge of basic physics. Despite these results, very little of new curricular developments have been translated to the classrooms of different educational systems. To facilitate this school transformation it is mandatory to improve teacher preparation in two fundamental aspects: content knowledge and pedagogical knowledge. We advocate that both objectives should always be present in an integrated form in development courses for in-service teachers. We report here on the improvement that can be obtained in the conceptual understanding of basic mechanics principles by in-service teachers attending a 3-day short development course held in Monterrey, Mexico. Using the FCI as the measuring instrument, we analyze the gain in understanding of the different dimensions of the concepts of force and motion, and how these gains can be related to "Tutorials in Introductory Physics," the teaching strategy proposed in the course.

column5: Dynamical Symmetries in Even-Even Nuclei
column18: In the framework of the interacting boson approximation (IBA), the symmetries behind harmonic vibrators, gamma-unstable nuclei, and deformed symmetric rotors have been codified in terms of the U(5), O(6), and SU(3) limits. While symmetries represent stable limits of structure, most nuclei are placed in regions of structural change. A new class of symmetries describes systems undergoing phase transitions between dynamical symmetries, which are related to exactly solvable problems through analytic solutions expressed in terms of the zeros of the special Bessel functions. This work presents our theoretical search for an E(5) symmetry example.

column5: Investigating the Relationship Between Epistemological Beliefs and Cognitive Conflicts
column18: Students are influence by the beliefs they hold about knowledge and knowing, when encountering new information in classrooms. Students enter classrooms with strongly held ideas that conflict with scientific explanations of the world. Cognitive conflict has been known to be a starting point in the process of conceptual change. To start the process of change, this conflict has to be meaningful for the individual. When students are confronted with a discrepant event to arouse cognitive conflicts, they may approach the learning process of change quite differently depending on their epistemological beliefs. However, there is little research to investigate the relationship between epistemological beliefs and cognitive conflicts in introductory physics classes. In this talk, we will present among students with different levels of motivational beliefs the relationship between epistemological beliefs and cognitive conflicts. We will also discuss the implications for the more effective cognitive conflict strategy in real school setting.

column5: Love Them To Death
column18: My teaching odyssey has extended from graduate students to 7th-graders. At every level, I have loved the physics and the teaching and the students. Real affection for students, I suggest, goes a long way toward ensuring their success, and your own. When you really want them to share some of your excitement, they will. Along the way, I have acquired a few convictions. One is that we need to work harder at overcoming our still too-common priesthood syndrome. Another is that teaching physics to 9th-graders makes great good sense.

column5: The Evolution of Vibrational to Rotational Structure in Nuclei*
column18: For more than 25 years, phase and shape evolution that are ultimately related to the mechanisms by which atomic nuclei generate angular momentum have been major themes in nuclear structure research. In certain circumstances, the motions of the individual protons and neutrons making up the nucleus couple, give rise to collective vibrations or rotations of the nucleus as a whole. This presentation focuses on a new method to discern the nuclear evolution from vibrational to rotational structure in nuclei, as a function of spin. The E-GOS (E-Gamma Over Spin) plot is an empirical approach that describes the structure of the nucleus circumventing all of the parameters and model dependencies that had to be assumed in past research. The work was completed in collaboration with groups from the Wright Nuclear Structure Laboratory at Yale University, and from the University of Surrey, Guildford, England.
column19: *Supported by the NSF grant #PHY0204811 and Research Corporation grant no. CC5494

column5: Teaching Introductory Physics to Technical Theater Professionals and Students
column18: Technical Directors and other technical theater professionals use physics concepts on a daily basis, but frequently do not have a basic understanding of the principles involved. Instead, they rely on word of mouth, web searches, and pocket handbooks, and then try to use results which might not even be applicable to the situation at hand. Undergraduate students in these fields, while often at universities which require a science course, are not encouraged to take physics, even though it is directly applicable to their field. Workshops on how to use Newton's laws to calculate the size of a motor needed to move an object have already been presented to theater students and professionals. I will discuss what's been learned so far and where the project goes next, specifically the development of workshops, lecture materials, and eventually a text to be used in a Physics of Theater course.

column5: The 1964 Alaska Earthquake: Underlying Geology and Resulting Landslides in Anchorage
column18: The 1964 Alaska Earthquake was felt heavily in Anchorage when the 9.2 event produced four minutes of ground motion, thus causing building collapse and land offset. By far, the greatest destruction was due to the failure of the Bootlegger Cove Fm., a 13,000 year-old glaciomarine deposit that underlies portions of the city. When this thixotrophic silty clay failed, it produced translatory slides that carried homes into the ocean and split a school apart. Several slides occurred along the ocean bluffs and the slopes of Ship Creek. The slides had similar characteristics of an upper scarp, pull-apart grabens, stepped surfaces, lateral slope motion, and distal pressure ridges. While a few slide areas were not reoccupied, many have been rebuilt since 1964. Earthquake Park has been left in its original state as a reminder of the event. Only the 4th Avenue slide was stabilized with an earthen buttress and monitored for additional displacements. Studies suggest with only minor movement has been measured since 1964.

column5: Spherical Rare Earth Magnets Rolling in Inclined Channels
column15: Alois Adams, Univ. of Arkansas at Little Rock
column18: Rare earth magnetic spheres (REMS) rolling on conductor and nonconductor surfaces demonstrate interesting torque affects that are, presumably, due to their interaction with the magnetic field of the earth and (for conductors) Faraday induction and Lenz's Law. Modeling motion in a plane is quite difficult, given the number of degrees of freedom open to the rolling REMS. To begin the process of theoretically modeling the general motion of the magnetic spheres a more limited case will first be considered: the rolling of REMS down inclined channels. The various empirical observations for this motion, e.g., the incline angle must exceed a certain value before rolling begins, the minimum angle depends on dipole orientation, an uneven, jerky motion down the incline is typical for REMS with the degree of jerkiness also dependent on the overall orientation of the dipole. All these and others will be addressed assuming the dipole interaction with the earth's field and (for metal channels) the retarding force due to Lenz's Law.

column5: Characterizing and Assessing Affective Goals of the Introductory Physics Laboratory Experience
column18: Much of the value of the introductory laboratory experience resides in the affective objectives. Yet we have difficulty reliably measuring the outcomes of these goals. The paper describes a sample set of these affective objectives for the introductory laboratory experience (the level of self-directed inquiry, the amount and quality of the communal interaction developed among the students, the level of satisfaction of the students with the laboratory environment, and the self-image of the students as effective and capable researchers), the behavior indicators that were used to develop assessment instruments, and the three assessment surveys that were developed. Additional assessment strategies were used both to test the validity of the newly developed assessment instruments and to gain a more complete description of the laboratory outcomes.

column5: Deciduous Structures & Interfacial Processes of Atmosphere Species Studied by MIS
column18: Matrix Isolation Spectroscopy (MIS) is an evolving method of examining highly reactive or ephemeral species by trapping them in inert matrices at near liquid helium temperatures. These are then probed by various energy sources. In addition, our work is showing the potential of studying interfacial species and their reactions on such surfaces as ice. Here the dangling OH will be emphasized and its potential to unravel complex ice surface reactions will be highlighted. Weak interactions between molecules are very important as they influence many phenomena. These weak forces or van der Waals forces include dispersion forces, electrostatic interactions, and hydrogen bonding. Weak intermolecular interactions are responsible for solvation and complexation. They affect optical properties and reaction dynamics of molecular systems. They also influence protein folding and relative positions of enzymes and substrates in biochemical reactions. Clustering of water molecules and water complexes in the upper atmosphere lead to droplet and cloud formation and enhanced greenhouse effects. They also influence many solution and interfacial reactions. In this presentation, we discuss the infrared spectroscopic studies of troposphere reactions of NO2, oxygen bi-radical, NO and O3. Stratospheric 1:1 complexes of water and NO, NO2, CO2, Cl2, O2, and N2, have been made, their vibrational frequencies determined and their energetically most favorable structures predicted with the theoretical calculations using the Gaussian program at the MP2/6-311++G(2d,2p) level of theory. The solid inert rare gas matrix will be discussed in terms of a radical micro-reactor.

column5: Physics Teacher SOS Program
column18: In 1996, as an effort to reach out to new teachers in a meaningful way, a group of veteran teachers began putting on a New Teacher Workshop at the section meetings here in Northern California. Although done at first as an experiment, the 3-hour sessions were very popular and became a regular part of our Saturday programs. Teachers are paired up with a mentor "buddy." We also have a list so teachers can ask questions and network with other new teachers. Several years ago the workshops were expanded to an all-day format the day before our regular meeting. Issues addressed were how to do and devise successful demonstrations, how to do labs with little or no lab equipment, how to use existing equipment, as well as curriculum matters like content standards and teaching at a variety of level. Last year year our efforts were funded by the Karl Brown Foundation enabling us to expand our workshops to three day-long workshops during the year. Athough we cannot offer stipends for participation, we do give away about $15,000 worth of demonstration equipment and supplies (i.e, goodies").

column5: Bringing the Excitement of Physics to the Community: UBC Physics Public Outreach
column15: Marina Milner-Bolotin, Univ. of British Columbia
column17: Andrzej Kotlicki, Chris Waltham, Peter Newbury
column18: What is the right time to bring the excitement of physics to children and inspire their interest in science? At the University of British Columbia (UBC), we believe (and we have evidence to support this claim) that elementary as well as high school students can benefit significantly from such an early exposure. Faculty members, graduate and undergraduate students at UBC organize various outreach events to bring physics to children and their families: Faraday Christmas Lectures, Open Houses, Summer Science Camps, Summer Robotics competitions, physics lessons, and demo shows at local elementary and high schools, Science Fairs, Physics Olympics, and High School Contests, Public Nights at our Observatory, guided tours of Canada's National Lab for particle and nuclear physics (TRIUMF), public physics lectures and many more exciting activities. To learn more see: http://www.physics.ubc.ca/links/outreach.php http://www.triumf.info/ and http://www.physics.ubc.ca/~milnerm/Faraday/

column5: Writing-Intensive Quantum Mechanics
column18: In this talk I will describe a sequence of writing assignments that I have used to supplement traditional instruction in a junior/senior-level course in quantum mechanics. The course focuses on the mathematical formalism of quantum mechanics, but the writing assignments focus on conceptual difficulties and interpretation. Students read about several important experiments and are then asked to write about how those experiments illustrate various important concepts in quantum mechanics. In writing their papers, students are forced to think about different interpretations of quantum mechanics and how those interpretations relate to the results of real experiments. This approach exposes students to some of the exciting conceptual debates in quantum mechanics, but does so in a way that is intimately tied to experiment.

column5: Modelling the Cockcroft-Walton Voltage Multiplier
column18: The accelerator that Cockcroft and Walton used in 1932 to accelerate protons toward a lithium target employed a voltage-multiplying circuit to reach a potential of 250 KV. The original experimenters had to build everything from scratch and evacuate their vacuum rectifiers each day. Today this circuit can be modeled using non-lethal sinusoidal signals provided by a standard laboratory function generator, and low-voltage capacitors and diodes.

column5: Role of Content Deepening Seminars in the MSP of SWPA*
column18: Content Deepening Seminars are opportunities for educators to develop content knowledge expertise in a particular area in order to become a resource for their district colleagues. General criteria for the goals and format of all Content Deepening Seminars will be defined and discussed, as will qualifications of the Resource Partners (seminar presenters). The talk will then focus on the goals and content of a particular seminar (recently co-facilitated by the author) "Physics of Fusion and Fission for the HS Classroom." This seminar utilized the two teaching charts developed by the Contemporary Physics Education Project: "Nuclear Science" and "FUSION-Physics of a Fundamental Energy Source," as the primary content resources. One or two inquiry based hands-on activities will be demonstrated (hopefully enticing audience participation). A limited number of the CPEP charts (43 cm x 28 cm) will be available for distribution.

column5: The Physics Foundation Course at the University of Cape Town, South Africa
column15: Saalih Allie, Univ. of Cape Town
column18: The majority of the population of South Africa is still underrepresented at many levels of society including post secondary education. This is particularly acute in the STEM area and special access programs at universities play a vital role as a redress measure. The Physics Foundation Course is part of such a programme that was started over two decades ago to assist students embarking on a B.S degree. The course was designed with a "forward looking" philosophy to equip students with the tools and skills to enable them to participate meaningfully in the academic environment. We discuss aspects of the course with regard to content and experimental work (including language intervention) as well as elements of the teaching and learning environment such as small group tutorials with a large class and peer assessment. The impact of both the course and the access programme as a whole will also be touched upon.

column5: Teacher Thinking About Elementary Student Thinking About Motion*
column15: Emily van Zee, Oregon State Univ.
column18: Elementary and middle school teachers collaborated with university researchers in developing case studies of student inquiry in physical science. During bi-weekly seminars, they showed and discussed video "snippets" of their students talking about physical phenomena such as a swinging pendulum or two falling objects. Each semester they wrote case studies that discussed their own and other possible interpretations of their students' thinking. Each summer they refined their best case studies after further analysis with colleagues and staff. They also learned physics as recreation in the afternoons after the hard work of writing in the mornings. Some of the case studies are now available for use in courses for prospective and practicing teachers. In this paper, we interpret the responses of various groups, both prospective and practicing teachers, who have viewed and discussed some of these case studies of student thinking about motion.

column5: Computer-Based Ranking Tasks for Introductory Astronomy
column17: Andrew A Frederick, Christopher M Siedell, Adam N Davis
column18: Ranking tasks require students to place graphical icons into some ranked order and have been widely used for several years in physics. Ranking tasks are valued for their capacity to elicit students' natural ideas about the behavior of a physical system which in turn often helps students to recognize any misconceptions that they may have. This presentation will describe the development of computer-based ranking tasks in FLASH for introductory astronomy. These ranking tasks can conveniently be incorporated into web pages, powerpoint slides, FLASH-based delivery systems, and web-based assessment engines such as EDU. Computer-based delivery offers many advantages over pencil and paper versions such as assigning scores, incorporating feedback, and using color and animation in the icons. The ability to randomize the question and icons encourages students to repeat a task until they master the concepts involved. A number of these ranking tasks are publicly available at http://astro.unl.edu.

column5: Alaskan Tsunamis
column18: Due to the convergence of the Pacific and North American lithospheric plates, the south Alaska and Aleutians Islands coasts are some of the world's most likely regions to be impacted by large tsunamis. Even though Alaska's recorded seismic and tsunami history is only about 200 years, the record shows many tsunamis which have caused severe destruction along the local coastlines as well as at distant shores. The first recorded tsunami occurred in 1788 in the Kodiak Island and Alaska Peninsula region. A sequence of large tsunami occurred between 1946 and 1965. The 1946 tsunami was the second largest Pacific-wide tsunami of the century. This was followed by significant tsunamis in 1957, 1958, 1964, and 1965.

column5: The Emeritus State: Some Critical Points in a Phase Transition
column18: The establishment of an Emeritus College at Arizona State University has met with, in the author's experience, unprecedented approval and support, both from the university community and from ASU's emeriti and emeritae. The possible reasons are speculated upon, with special attention given to the professional scientist who undergoes abruptly a bureaucratic phase transition while retaining most of the characteristics of the prior state.

column5: Do What You Love. No One Can Stop You
column15: Edwin F. Taylor, Massachusetts Inst. Of Tech. (retired)
column18: On the pedestal of a statue in front of Boston's Faneuil Hall an inscription reads "Samuel Adams, 1722-1803, A Patriot, He organized the revolution and signed the Declaration of Independence." The key for us is to organize retirement and declare independence of everything we do not love. Virginia Woolf and others in the Bloomsbury group wrote seriously from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. every day of their lives, and changed the face of literature. Four hours a day sounds about right, but not every day. Possibly from reflective involvement "Some work of noble note may yet be done,/Not unbecoming [those] that strove with Gods."

column5: Life of a Physicist After Retirement
column18: Retirement could be scary, but it is just the next stage in the long career of being a physicist. We chose physics for the challenge of understanding the workings of nature. We passed through the stages of student, researcher, teacher, and perhaps, writer, speaker, leader, and overseer. We carry each of these experiences into this next part of our life. With the new-found freedom and independence to act on our accumulated knowledge and passions, we are the wizened student now in an ever-changing world of problems and new applications. This is the time to explore our desires, set goals and plunge into new journeys.

column5: Aristarchus of Samos: His Life and Times
column15: Frederick J Wolf, Keene State Coll.
column18: Like Euclid, his contemporary, little is known about Aristarchus of Samos, "The Copernicus of Antiquity." It is doubtful whether more will be known about him or his works. However, we do have enough to assess him in a historical context with respect to his abilities, accomplishments and place in history. A brief survey of Hellenistic history includes Athens, Alexandria, its scientists, the heliocentric and geocentric theories, the works of Aristarchus, and we end with a discussion of Copernicus.

column5: Force Distribution on Surface of Accelerated Block
column15: Stein Ahlqvist, Univ. of Central Florida
column18: In introductory physics courses, one of the most common problems encountered is that of a box stuck in front of an accelerating car. The students learn how to deal with the forces involved assuming that the object is a point mass. However, we have found no work that examines the problem under realistic conditions. In this talk we shall revisit the problem from exactly this perspective and we will argue that the equilibrium conditions are not sufficient to provide a unique solution. However, using additional information that can be derived from the deformation of the object and the car, a solution can be obtained.

column5: The CHEPREO Project: Building a Support Community for Physics Modelers*
column17: Laird Kramer, Priscilla Pamela, George O'Brien, Pete Markowitz
column18: The Center for High-Energy Physics Research Education and Outreach (CHEPREO) Project is an NSF-supported project that is building a learning, teaching, and research community centered around high energy physics, grid computing, and high speed networking. CHEPREO's goal is to generate excitement about physics and science in general, support inquiry-based instructional methods in the classroom, and increase physics enrollment at both the high school and college level. For the high schools, CHEPREO's efforts are based on Hestenes et al. physics modeling, QuarkNet, and building a support community of high school teachers in South Florida, supported by Florida International University faculty and other resources. This talk will describe our initial efforts working with high school physics teachers and local school districts in building a physics modeling support community.

column5: Testing Your Teaching: Goals, Methods, and Assessment in Intro Astronomy
column15: Matthew Craig, Minnesota State Univ, Moorhead
column18: An instructor of an introductory astronomy course faces three challenges: identifying the concepts students are to learn, choosing an effective method for teaching those concepts, and measuring what students have learned. I will address each of these challenges and share how I approach them in my teaching. The first two challenges do not have one-size-fits-all answers. I will suggest ways of clarifying which concepts the students are to learn and choosing effective instructional strategies. The emphasis will be on measuring what students are learning using the Astronomy Diagnostic Test (ADT) 2.0. The test is particularly effective when analyzed question by question rather than looking simply at aggregate results.

column5: Problem-Solving as an Anchor for Self-Efficacy in Physics
column15: Kimberly Shaw, Southern Illinois Univ. Edwardsville

Since student success does not always correlate with the instructor's perception of student ability in physics classrooms, self-efficacy offers a window on the issue. Self-efficacy is often strongly correlated with performance on that same task. In the physics literature,

It revolutionized earth sciences in the 1960s, and its basic principles have passed numerous tests over the years. However, one original prediction of the theory clearly has failed

column5: The Mysterious Sound of the Aurora
column18: Observers of the aurora have occasionally reported of audible noise that is closely associated with the visual impression of auroral displays. This phenomena is very difficult to measure and almost all reports are from subjective sources. I will discuss and evaluate several explanations that have been brought forward over the years. These explanations are from the areas of psychology, neurology, and physics. However, no satisfying explanation for these observations of the sound of the aurora exists.

column5: Use of VideoPoint in high school sports biomechanics research
column15: Robert J. Mackenzie, Webb School of California
column18: Introductory physics classes at the Webb Schools of California regularly use VideoPoint software to illustrate concepts with real-life examples. In the second semester of each year, students are expected to perform original research as a part of the class and most of them choose topics in sports biomechanics. Some examples of the student research in the areas of track and field, weightlifting, and volleyball will be presented along with tips on effective use of the software for research.

column5: Hierarchical Learning Ensembles: A New Pedagogy for Undergraduate Engineering Education
column15: Gregory A. DiLisi, John Carroll Univ.
column18: Employers of science and engineering college graduates seek candidates who have some experience in the commercial sector. As teachers of undergraduates, we cannot provide such experience for our students. However, we can ask: What skills are learned on the job that we are not currently instilling in our students? One skill developed on the job, but not taught at academic institutions, is the ability to effectively work in heterogeneous groups. Thus, a gap exists in the training of undergraduate scientists and engineers: The curriculum fails to cultivate realistic team-skills like those developed at the workplace. We describe the design and implementation of our Hierarchical Learning Ensemble (HLE) model, a pedagogy that assembles interdisciplinary teams of graduate, undergraduate, and secondary-level students to solve science and engineering problems. Our goal is to sensitize undergraduates to working in heterogeneous groups and thus better prepare them for the workplace.

column5: Research on Student Understanding of Linear and Angular Momentum Conservation*
column17: Hunter G Close, Peter S Shaffer, Lillian C McDermott
column18: Results from research indicate that many introductory students misunderstand the definition of angular momentum and the relationship of the conservation of angular momentum to that of linear momentum. The problem is especially acute in cases of combined translational and rotational motion. Examples drawn from quizzes and exams will be used to illustrate some specific tendencies in student reasoning. The findings have guided the development of a tutorial that helps students better understand the purpose and functions of the angular momentum concept.

column5: The Practice of Physics in the Context of China*
column17: Elon Candea, Ricky DeVoe, Jason Marmon, Cionne Wolfe
column18: Five students and one faculty member spent a month during the summer of 2005 investigating aspects of physics in the context of China and Chinese culture. Projects were as diverse and included aspects of music, weaponry, and martial arts. Students conducted on-site interviews, analyzed actual weapons and instruments, and prepared video for frame-by-frame analysis. Not only valuable as a research experience, the students were provided with the opportunity to learn that science does not occur in a cultural vacuum.

column5: Strengthening Outreach in Urban Empowerment Zones Through GK12
column18: The GK12 program at Old Dominion University is a partnership with ODU, neighboring Hampton University, CHROME (Cooperating Hampton Roads Organizations for Minorities in Engineering), and the public school districts of the cities of Norfolk, Portsmouth, and Hampton. Graduate Fellows work as "role model-experts" with Teacher Fellows in the fourth- and fifth-grade levels with at-risk students. Professional development seminars are presented throughout the school year to help Graduate Fellows with the classroom environment, engage university faculty in teacher professional development, and provide professional development opportunities that would not otherwise be available. One of the underlying themes of our GK12 project is to begin transforming the university's culture to view outreach to public schools not only as an integral part of graduate education, but as an essential step in ensuring that the nation produces a well-trained and educated population for excellence in science, engineering, and mathematics.

column5: Mathematics and Science Partnership at El Paso Community College
column15: Emil Michal, El Paso Comm. Coll.
column18: The Mathematics and Science Partnership (MSP) is a project funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) to enhance the classroom experience of students and teachers. Involving educational partners from local K-16 schools, the MSP brings together educators to development and align curriculum, implement innovative teaching approaches and improve students learning in science and mathematics courses for all K-16 classes. At El Paso Community College, one of the more exciting activities has been the development of concept frameworks for mathematics, physics, geology, chemistry, and biology based on cognitive demands that provide instructors with opportunities for improving classroom instruction. Copies of the frameworks for physics will be provided and as well as discussions and examples on how instructors can use the frameworks.

column5: Expert-Novice Studies Using a Web-Based Socratic Tutor
column17: Young-Jin Lee, David J Palazzo, David E Pritchard
column18: In the web-based Socratic tutor, MasteringPhysics, over 90% of the students eventually reach the correct solution to a given physics problem using hints and spontaneous wrong answer responses. In such an environment the traditional use of "right" and "wrong" scoring will not allow to identify students who behave as experts or novices. Using a difficulty measuring algorithm [hints + 0.248*(incorrect responses) + 0.025*Ln(time to completion)] optimized for the split-half reliability we find that the average difficulty that a student experiences in doing a problem correlates with their "expertise" measured by the CLASS (Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey) at 0.36. We find that most problems are easier for experts and others much less so (or are even easier for novices). We will exhibit examples of each type of problem and will suggest that teachers avoid the use of problems that are easier for novices to solve since this can not encourage expert behavior.

column5: Biodiesel: A Future "Green" Fuel
column18: With higher prices of gasoline and a future decline in world wide oil production, Americans are looking at alternative sources of energy. Biodiesel has been promoted as a renewable source of energy. Most biodiesel fuel produced in the United States uses crops such as soybeans, from which the biodiesel fuel is produced. A smaller percentage of biodiesel fuel is produced from recycled vegetable oil. Some of this production uses solar energy as the input energy source. Pros and cons of ?green? biodiesel will be presented.

column5: Interactive Simulations for Teaching Motions in the Sky
column17: Christopher M Siedell, Adam N Davis
column18: This presentation will showcase a suite of simulations for demonstrating motions in the sky and for investigating seasons. Astronomy education research has consistently shown the presence of tenacious student misconceptions regarding understanding the causes of seasons and new visualization tools are needed to combat these misconceptions. The simulations also effectively demonstrate coordinate systems and many other horizon system concepts such as star trails and declination ranges. This work is part of the Nebraska Astronomy Applet Project (NAAP), which is developing high-quality astrophysical simulations accompanied by a variety of supporting resources including assessments. NAAP materials are appropriate for use in both college and high school introductory astronomy courses. NAAP materials may be found at http://astro.unl.edu.

column5: My Undergraduate Research Experience and Presentation at ICPS 2005*
column18: A variety of molecular species have been investigated using several experimental systems. The initial research involved the discovery of new optically pumped laser emissions from a variety of stable molecular species, including hydrazine and methanol isotopes. New laser emissions were discovered in the short-wavelength portion of the far-infrared region. A three-laser heterodyne system was then assembled to measure the frequencies of these laser emissions to fractional uncertainties of a few parts in ten million. Once measured, these laser lines can be used as sources of far-infrared radiation for the investigation of unstable molecular species with the laser magnetic resonance (LMR) spectroscopic technique. LMR systems at the University of Wisconsin<0x2013>La Crosse as well as Oxford University, England, have been used to investigate such species. Along with these research experiences, I will also discuss the opportunity I had to present my findings at the ICPS 2005 conference in Coimbra, Portugal.

column5: Can Writing About Problem Solving Improve Self-Awareness About Physics Understanding?
column17: Catherine Gubernatis, Gordon Aubrecht, Scott Franklin, Lisa Hermsen
column18: Studies show a low correlation between a student's ability to solve a problem correctly and self-awareness of their ability to solve it. It is often presumed that there is a correlation between the ability to explain information and one's understanding of that information, as giving an explanation may require reflection on content knowledge (this presumption is being challenged by the authors as part of an ongoing study). The question thus arises: If a student explains his or her solution to a problem, will this affect his or her ability to judge the correctness of the solution? Will students know whether their solution is correct if writing an explanation forces them to reflect upon that solution? A preliminary experiment that studies the effect of writing on students' ability to self-assess their understanding in the context of problem solving is presented in this poster.

column5: Student Approaches to Science Writing: Case Studies from Physics 367
column15: Dedra N Demaree, Ohio State Univ.
column17: Catherine Gubernatis, Gordon Aubrecht, Scott Franklin, Lisa Hermsen
column18: As part of an ongoing study to assess the effects of explicit writing activities in the physics classroom, it is important to understand how students approach science writing. Physics 367 is a second course in writing at the Ohio State University, for both physics and non-physics majors. Student volunteers were interviewed during the writing process, and both drafts and final papers from all students were analyzed to gain an understanding of their approach to science writing. Questions considered were: How does instruction engender expertise? What is a student's mental state when writing? How do they process instructors' suggestions? Are they being reflective of their work when writing and using feedback from drafts? Do they consider writing as a continual process? This poster will present our preliminary results, and discuss how the answers to these questions will help us assess the effectiveness of writing as a tool for learning physics content.

column5: Improving Cognitive Environment for Science Education in Middle & High Schools
column18: Our preliminary study reveals that physical and mathematical sciences inherently require a level of abstract reasoning that can only be acquired through special, targeted training for many people. This implies the necessity for a more profound educational reform than direct replacement of the traditional lecture component with hands-on activities. Our research project addresses for middle and high school students and suggests the study of physics, along with development of abstract reasoning, from an early age. The augmented learning methods to be employed in the research are derived from Information Theory and Artificial Intelligence Theory. Parallel work is being done to characterize the process of science education and determine those psychological factors that will help young people improve their achievement in science. It applies the outcomes from fields like Information Acceptance, Pattern Recognition, Knowledge Representation, Human and Computer Vision, and Human-Computer Interaction. Additionally, it folds the insights gleaned from scientific research in these fields into the realities of human educational processes, with the goal of producing a sustainable improvement in the cognitive environment for science education.

column5: On Selecting Physical Science Texts at the State Level
column15: John L Hubisz, North Carolina State Univ.
column18: Certain states pretty well determine what textbooks will be used across the country. Other states use those selections as a starting point for their own adoptions. What advice can you give to folks on the selection committee? After many years of considering the problem of bad selections, I offer some suggestions that you might pass on to your local school boards.

column5: Extreme Teaching: The Universal Lessons from Physics Education in Africa
column18: Consider the major issues confronting physics education in the United States. There is a warranted discussion on how the failure to meet these challenges will affect both economic growth and national security. Intensify the very same problems and ramifications by at least one order of magnitude. The results depict the current state of physics education in African countries. Though by no means preferable, the urgency of conditions in Africa has offered a unique opportunity. By partnering with their African colleagues, Americans teachers are forced to do more than merely discuss the common problems but to focus on finding solutions. From the experience new insights are emerging on shared concerns such as the shortage of qualified teachers, professional development, insufficient resources, the role of technology, gender disparities, language barriers, high-stakes testing, and ill-prepared students.

column5: Exploring Alternative Medicine with Introductory Physics
column18: The scientific literature of alternative medicine therapies often proposes mechanisms which have an electromagnetic or other accessible physics basis, suitable as interesting examples for introductory physics students, especially life/health science majors. Several examples will be presented.

column5: Using Atmospheric Muons To Test Relativity in the Introductory Lab
column18: At Pomona College, we spend three weeks of our fall-semester introductory course exploring special relativity in the classroom. For many years we have wanted a laboratory exercise to complement this portion of our course. Last summer, we developed a three-week introductory laboratory that uses the readily-available TeachSpin muon decay apparatus to perform a test of special relativity, and we ran the laboratory with introductory students this fall. In this talk, I will describe how I and my collaborators adapted this upper-level experiment for the introductory lab, the challenges and pitfalls we encountered in getting the experiment to work, and the interesting physics behind our version of the experiment. I will also assess the success of this laboratory exercise for our students.

column5: Birefringence of the Cornea and the Individual Perception of Haidinger's Brushes*
column18: Haidinger's brushes are an entoptic phenomenon of the human visual system, which enables us to detect polarized light. The mineralogist Wilhelm Haidinger (1844) discovered the effect, and Helmoltz (1866) related the perception of the brushes to the concentric alignment of the dichroic pigment around the fovea. However, the individual perception of Haidinger's brushes can vary significantly, and many subjects report they can not perceive them at all. So far no explanation for these differences exists. We suggest that the birefringence of the cornea influences the formation of Haidinger's brushes and may offer an explanation for individual differences. We devised an experimental setup to simulate the various phase shifts and orientations of the cornea and recorded the forming brush pattern. We also modeled the transmission of light through this system on the Poincare sphere, and were able to quantify the influence of the cornea on the pattern of Haidinger's brushes.

column5: The Physics of Athletic Movement: An Analysis of Vaulting Events
column18: The application of physics to athletic events can be useful in identifying flaws in technique, revealing sources of injuries, and discovering beneficial modifications to equipment. The aim of this study is to understand the physics involved in two vaulting events, specifically the pole vault in track and field and the vault in gymnastics. In both events, the takeoff is a critical aspect of the full vault; therefore, it is extremely difficult during the later phases of the vault to compensate for errors made during takeoff. For this study, the VideoPoint software package was used to track the center of mass positions as a function of time. The effects of initial speed, takeoff angle, takeoff speed, and percentage of speed (at takeoff) converted from horizontal to vertical on the "push height index" of each vaulter were investigated. We also investigated the energies of the vaulters; these quantities follow expected patterns.

column5: Constructing Your Own Formative Assessments
column18: In this session, we will be looking at three formative assessments: the background knowledge probe, defining features matrix, and the minute paper. Attributes of these three assessments will be discussed and examples of how these assessments can be implemented in the classroom. We will also be examining the importance of these various strategies and how they guide assessment. We will discuss how classroom assessment tools such as CPS can be used in conjunction with these formative assessments. But this technology is not necessary to use these formative assessments. Upon completion of this workshop, you will have all the tools to begin using these formative assessments in your classroom.

column5: Venus and How Research Evolves After the Big Mission
column18: Magellan concluded operations in 1994, and was the last spacecraft mission to study the geology of Venus. Magellan's radar imagery revealed about 900 impact craters distributed randomly about the globe, and most of those craters appeared to have been unaltered since formation. Scientists use the distribution and post-impact geologic modification of craters to reconstruct a planet's global history. The initial interpretation of the craters suggested to most researchers that the planet was geologically active and then rapidly shut down. Wild hypotheses were developed to explain this highly unusual planetary behavior. Later, more detailed investigations have shown that most of the craters have been modified by later geologic processes, and much of the world view that was collectively held during the mission is proving to be in error. Such post-mission research occurs out of the spotlight and can take a long time to be known by the general population.

column5: University of Washington's GK-12 Project: Developing Elementary School Mathematical Understanding
column18: The NSF GK-12 project at the University of Washington works with schools in the Seattle School District to place graduate fellows in elementary classrooms to aid the teaching of inquiry based mathematics. The curriculum supported by the fellows is Terc "Investigations in Number, Data, and Space." The objective of the project has two main focuses: first, to help promote stronger mathematical understanding of elementary school teachers to help them be more effective in teaching mathematics, and, second, the graduate fellows develop their own understanding of how mathematics are taught and understood in elementary schools. We have seen some exciting growth in the teachers and schools we have worked with and will share the challenges and successes we have experienced.

column5: Physics Education in Asia: The New Delhi and Hangzhou Conferences
column15: E. L. Jossem, OhIo State Univ.
column18: The International Conferences on Phyisics Education held in New Delhi, India, and Hangzhou, China, last August and September provided a window on physics education in the world's two most populous countries. An account of the conferences and of the contexts in which they were held will be provided along with some comparisons of physics education in the two countries and that in the U.S.

column5: Squiggle Ball Capture: A Novel Visual Thermodynamics Experiment
column17: Ken Rathbun, Kiril Simov, Blair Reynolds
column18: The capture of particles by low-energy traps is an important physical phenomenon that can be understood in the framework of statistical mechanics. For example, when electrons or holes are trapped by localized deep states in semiconductors, device performance can be significantly impaired. The capture mechanism depends on the average thermal velocity of the particles and the cross-section and distribution of the participating traps. We have designed a macroscopic system for exploring this process. Squiggle Balls, which use a battery-powered motor and asymmetric rotor to roll and tumble "randomly," move on a bounded, elevated platform with several circular holes. We measure the average "capture time" as a function of hole size and density, and examine our results in the context of a simple probabilistic model. We also tilt the platform to simulate an applied field, and analyze the results using Boltzmann statistics.

column5: Five Inexpensive Ways to Involve More Women in Undergraduate Physics
column18: Everyone knows that not enough women study physics. Low representation of women in undergraduate physics begins a trend of decreasing participation that continues through graduate school into university faculty. There are plenty of expensive ways to study the problem and there are equal numbers of expensive solutions to reverse the trend. But there is only so much money to go around at any university. This talk proposes five ways to involve more women in undergraduate physics without breaking your budget. Each tactic focuses on taking advantage of existing resources to create an environment conducive to the recruitment and retention of women.

column5: The Enjoyment and Relevance of Old Science Textbooks: Three Case Studies
column18: Over the past few years I have centred my science education research around the collection and study of old science textbooks. This paper will bring out some aspects of this work that I believe to be relevant to today's science education by looking at the lives and writing of three men, who worked in different centuries, who influenced science education in different ways and who are largely forgotten today.

column5: Discussion of Documentary Video
column18: After the documentary video, this time will be used for questions, answers, and discussion. Attendees will be asked to comment on the video in terms of its effectiveness and message; they will also be asked to discuss how it might be used in the classroom or in professional development here in the United States. The speaker will act as a discussion facilitator along with the filmmaker and at least one other member of the COSM-Zambia team.

column5: Characteristic Misrepresentations in Physics Education: Their Danger and Origin
column15: Courtney Willis, Univ. of Northern Colorado
column17: Alexander Kazachkov, John C Moore, Alexander G Anders
column18: Origins of some characteristic misrepresentations of the basic physical phenomena in textbooks and class practice are analyzed. They range from seemingly minor mistakes in the presenters' body language to gross overstretching of the limits of the explanatory models. Most regretfully, educational misrepresentations undermine the whole picture of physical world which students are supposed to acquire in the process of learning. What is especially dangerous is the fact the majority of "subconsciously" misinstructed students will have no second chance to get their knowledge improved through more fortunate teaching or self-education since they will be taking physics only once. Ways to correct or evade the reviewed misrepresentations will be proposed.

column5: Deciphering the Sky's Icy Halos
column18: For centuries many beautiful sky displays were either known or strongly suspected to be the result of sunlight interacting with tiny ice crystals in the atmosphere. In the 1960s we used the new computer technology to predict the appearance of sky effects that would be caused by sunlight incident on a large group of ice crystals of a particular shape and with a particular set of orientations. This approach, with its subsequent improvements, has led to the understanding of the mechanisms responsible for the majority of well-documented ice-crystal halos. The illustration of this method will be accomplished using a comparison of computer simulations with photographs of Nature's own displays.

column5: Research-Based Strategies in Upper-Division Undergraduate Physics Classes
column15: N. Sanjay Rebello, Kansas State Univ.
column18: The use of research-based interactive engagement techniques in upper-division physics classes is relatively rare. We report here on reform and action research within the context of two upper-division undergraduate physics courses at Kansas State University. A course in electronic instrumentation and another in solid state physics were modified to incorporate and adapt strategies that facilitated active learning by students. We describe the modifications to these courses and the effectiveness of these strategies in promoting student learning. We will also present the reactions of students to the modified pedagogy of these courses, our own reflections as well as lessons learned.

column5: Alaska: A Natural Laboratory To Learn Physics and Geophysics
column18: Learning physics and geophysics is learning about ourselves and about the physical world we live in. Memorizing facts and formulas and crunching numbers does not make one a physicist. Learning physics involves refining our everyday thinking, and seeking answers to why and how about the world we live in. Alaska, the vast northern most state of U.S., is strategically located and is an ideal place to see some of the wonders of nature and learn about the underlying physical and geophysical processes shaping these wonders. The fascinating northern lights, the nations highest mountain peak, the volcanic chain, the glacial movements, the polar caps, all convey physical/geophysical concepts is a fascinating and unique way. This talk will take you through a virtual tour of the State of Alaska along with a discussion on how the state serves as a natural laboratory to learn the concepts of physics and geophysics.

column5: Probing the Ice Cap and Deeper Mysteries of Mt. Wrangell, North America's Largest Active Volcano
column15: Daniel Solie, University of Alaska Fairbanks
column18: Mt. Wrangell is a 4,300 meter ice covered, active volcano, eight times larger than Mt. Rainer in volume located in Wrangell Mountains of Alaska. This talk will describe the current multi-disciplinary research effort on Mt. Wrangell to determine the thickness of the ice cap in the Caldera, as well as give a broad overview of the over 50 years of research that have occurred on the mountain. These investigations include glacier/volcano interactions, ice coring, climate change, and cosmic rays.

column5: E-learning in the Context of Kazakhstan Society: Did We Miss the Information Train?
column18: E-learning stands for learning through electronic applications and processes, which transfers information and knowledge through time and space. In Kazakhstan today it seems that e-learning is mostly successful among youth familiar with computer technologies, understanding advantages of the information age. The rest of the society seems to stay away from new trends, demonstrating no reaction at all. We explain this from two positions. Firstly, e-education is not applicable for those who have no knowledge of information technologies. And secondly, there is a complex combination of distrust to current education system due to decreasing quality of it, and initial ignorance of e-learning. In a flash, universities were among the first who adapted e-learning. Trying to copy international teaching practices, but with limited resources, they basically helped to create an economic gap and polarize Kazakhstan society into those who have access to information versus non-users, as in the H.G. Wells' futuristic novel about society represented by "hunters" and "victims." The questions here are: Is the effectiveness of e-learning correlated to the access to information? Would its effectiveness increase, if e-learning were introduced on a wide scale? Specific steps should be taken so e-learning will not become another political idea. Will Kazakhstan society, which started its globalization process almost twelve years ago, accept e-learning and be able to solve questions that the 21st century is putting in front of it?

column5: Information Computer Technologies in Creative Hands-On Activities and Physics Tricks*
column15: Alexander Kazachkov, Univ. of Northern Colorado
column17: Courtney Willis, John C Moore, Terry Scott, Tetyana Ignatova
column18: A series of educational activities are presented as practiced with high school through college students in the Summer Research Programs at the MAST Institute at the University of Northern Colorado. The focus was to enforce the instructive impact of engaging experimental problems by advanced measurements and virtual experiments. Technologies involved included GPS units, Vernier sensors, digital video cameras, etc. Obtained experimental results were computer-processed by the student, who also contributed into design of computer animations to explain the intriguing observed phenomena ("motional" visual illusions and other).

column5: Student-Activating Exercises in Teaching Electromagnetic Field Theory
column15: Ari Sihvola, Helsinki Univ. of Tech.
column18: The basic electromagnetic field theory forms a part of the core of engineering education in the Electrical Engineering department of the Helsinki University of Technology, Finland. Around 250 students yearly take these classes. Being in charge of the courses is obviously challenging. Abstract concepts, heavy mathematics, difficulties in visualizing electromagnetics and large classes force the teacher to revise his/her educational methods and teaching strategies. In this discourse, we will share experiences in field theory teaching, using various methods where the students have more active and independent role in the learning process. Students' learning processes are activated by homework which aims to develop problem-solving abilities, problem-based group projects and providing computer-aided learning materials, i.e., animations and simulations to support learning.

column5: Stimulations for Students To Learn through the Study Record Cards
column15: Takuyuki Uragami, Okayama Univ. of Science
column18: Students individually record every time they attend the lecture class on physics on the Study Record Cards their studies, how they got the ideas, what they associated with, which fact they found intriguing, where they wished to review, when they felt to check it more closely, and so. While they fill in the cards individually, the lecturer reads some of the encouraging contents for all of the class to find sometimes most of students nodding to and confirming the situations of physics learning and study attitudes of others described in the contents. As a result of process from individual response to public resonance, students involved were stimulated to study, and they showed good results for the final at the end of the semesters. The conditions for occurrence of the class resonance have been drawing our attention. When they learn physics, they do the laws, equations, experiments, observations, interpretations, presentations, and applications; at the same time, we tried to lead them to devise individually the strategy and tactics for how to study.

column5: All the Data in the World
column15: Michael J Raddick, Johns Hopkins Univ.
column18: We will describe how teachers can access all the world's astronomy data through the tools of the National Virtual Observatory. The NVO is providing online services to share data across the Internet<0x2014>data from many different instruments, at all wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum. The NVO's scientific plan has focused on making research easier and better by giving scientists easy access to more data than ever before. Similarly, the NVO's education and public outreach (EPO) plan focuses on improving existing EPO projects by providing them with free access to exactly the same high-quality data. We will describe the NVO's EPO partner projects, and demonstrate existing lesson plans that use NVO's tools and services to provide data. We will also provide suggestions and technical contacts for EPO developers who want to include NVO tools and services in their programs.

column5: Curricular Transfer of Tribocharging of Sand in Zero-g (WYP)
column18: An electrostatics experiment designed by students was flown on the NASA C-9 microgravity laboratory as part of the World Year of Physics observance. This experiment examined triboelectric partical interactions and can be applied to basic electrostatic phenomena. Classroom transfer of activities arising from this project in electrostatics will be discussed.

column5: Successes with Polynesian Conceptual Physics University Students
column18: First-year Polynesian students at BYU-Hawaii encounter many culture-based challenges, some of which lead to poor academic performance. In order to help our first-year Polynesian students succeed academically, in 2003 BYU-Hawaii instituted the Freshman Learning Community (FLC) program. In each FLC, the students take three linked classes, one of which is conceptual physics. I will discuss the FLC, and the results achieved by the Polynesian conceptual physics students.

column5: Results of Tribocharging of Sand in Microgravity (WYP)
column18: Frictional charging of small particles has been well documented in forest fire ash plumes, volcanic eruptions, dust devils, and other small particulate phenomena. Applications of this experiment extend to interstellar dust, protostars, dust in low gravity environments such as Mars, and protoplanetary processes. The behavior of these particles in smaller than one-g environments is not well understood. An experiment was designed by students and flown on the C-9 as part of the World Year of Physics. Triboelectrically charged quartz particles were placed in a uniform electric field to study their interactions. Concept, design, fabrication, flight, and results will be discussed in this session.

column5: Teaching Science Online: Challenges and Opportunities
column18: Colleges and universities have turned to online education to meet the demands imposed on higher education by non-traditional students, technology, capacity, and workforce development. This shift to online education has resulted in changing curricula, pedagogical strategies, and teaching and learning modalities. Teaching science online presents a unique set of challenges and opportunities for both students and faculty. This paper will discuss the barriers to teaching and learning science online, as well as the co-existing opportunities for students, faculty, and institutions. This paper will also describe the University of Maryland University College's (UMUC) experiences since 1998 with 22 online science courses and over 33,000 online science enrollments. This includes an overview of UMUC's lessons learned with regard to the unique needs of online science students, and an integrated approach to online course development, student support, assessment, faculty training and mentoring, and security and quality assurance.

column5: The Windy Auroral Atmosphere
column18: Observers of colorful auroral displays in Alaska may bask in the local ambiance of the moment, but more than the creation of light is happening within the auroral atmosphere. It is not the simple, static thermosphere of diffusive equilibrium, but a place of strong horizontal winds and impressive gradients in flow direction with increasing altitude. And there are vertical winds that mix the various constituents to alter their fractional contributions to the local density. One mechanism for pushing air upwards is buoyancy, from auroral heating by energetic particle precipitation (the primary auroral electrons) and Joule dissipation. Detection of the winds with sounding rockets will be demonstrated and how these data can be incorporated in mathematical tests via the continuity equation will be discussed.

column5: Hawaii Students' Comet Tempel 1 Research Projects
column15: Mary Ann Kadooka, Univ. of Hawaii Institute for Astronomy
column18: The NASA Deep Impact mission provided the perfect opportunity for our students to conduct authentic astronomy and astrobiology research. The students have used the professional 2.0 meter Faulkes Telescope North (FTN) located on Haleakala, Maui, to investigate the comet's properties before, during, and after the impact. Prior to the actual July 3, 2005, encounter between the impactor and the comet, the students learned about comets and telescope images. During the Maui workshop at encounter, they were taught how to develop observing plans and to hone their image processing skills. Subsequently, the follow up has been crucial to provide students with the necessary resources to continue working on their projects. The process of learning to do remote observing with FTN, to use software for image processing, to assist students with analysis of images, and continuous mentoring will be described. Exciting project results will be shared.

column5: Can Writing and Writing Instruction Aid Learning in Physics?
column17: Catherine Gubernatis, Gordon Aubrecht, Scott Franklin, Lisa Hermsen
column18: Members from both the Physics and English departments at the Ohio State University and Rochester Institute of Technology are involved in an ongoing study addressing issues related to writing activities in the physics classroom. These activities are unique in that they include explicit writing instruction in the physics classroom since writing is context-dependent. Some of the questions that we attempt to answer are: How do writing exercises compare to traditional activities (such as labs) in terms of helping students gain content knowledge? Is there a difference in the quality of physics content in student writing between those who have explicit writing instructions and those who do not? What can we say about the correlation between the quality of physics content and the quality of writing from an English perspective? This talk will discuss some specific studies aimed at addressing these questions and present an overview of our most recent findings.

column5: Noctilucent Clouds: Ice Clouds in the Alaskan Summer
column18: Noctilucent clouds are the highest clouds on Earth. Noctilucent clouds form in the summer near 80 km in the polar regions. The clouds form in a region of the atmosphere that is colder in summer than winter. These clouds have been studied since the late 1800s, and were one of the first indicators that the atmosphere extended to such heights. More recently they have attracted attention as an indicator of global change. This talk will present an overview of these clouds and discuss laser radar (or lidar) observations that have been made in Alaska by faculty and students at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. The talk will cover the physics of the clouds, the observational methods and challenges, and the environmental science questions associated with these clouds.

column5: Physical Science Professional Development Programs for K-12 Teachers*
column17: Kathleen M. Koenig, Don Axe, Patricia Witson
column18: Physical Science by Inquiry programs have been conducted at the University of Cincinnati for inservice K-12 teachers during each of the past 10 summers. More than 300 teachers have successfully completed a four-week, 120-hour summer workshop for grades 5-12 teachers or a two-week, 60-hour summer workshop for grades K-5 teachers. The summer workshops consist of intensive graduate courses using modules from Physics by Inquiry.
column19: * Supported by The Improving Teacher Quality Program administered by the Ohio Board of Regents. 1. L.C. McDermott and the Physics Education Group at the University of Washington,

column5: Development of a Computer-Based Resource for Inclusion Science Classrooms
column18: Current instructional issues necessitate educators start with curriculum and determine how educational technology can assist students in achieving positive learning goals, functionally supplementing the classroom instruction. Technology projects incorporating principles of situated learning have been shown to provide effective framework for learning, and computer technology has been shown to facilitate learning among special needs students. Students with learning disabilities may benefit from assistive technology, but these resources are not always utilized during classroom instruction: technology is only effective if teachers view it as an integral part of the learning process. The materials currently under development are in the domain of earth and space science, part of the Arizona 5-8 Science Content Standards. The concern of this study is to determine a means of assisting inclusive education that is both feasible and effective in ensuring successful science learning outcomes for all students whether regular education or special needs.

column5: Cosmic Ray Research Project
column18: The earth is constantly bombarded from tiny particles called Cosmic Rays. These tiny particles are naked to the eye but can be detected from sophisticated detectors. The search for where these little particles originate will help us study the universe. The following project gives an overview of setting the experiment up using the computer board developed at FERMI-Lab. The process in collecting and analyzing cosmic rays is very time consuming, but the ultimate goal is to discover their energies an origin. The detector's used in this experiment are briefly explained in this but can be further researched on the website. The following equipment was used in this experiment: DAQ Card from FERMI Lab, HyperTerminal on the computer, and the website Cosmic Ray e-Lab developed at FERMI. This experiment is still a work in progress and hopefully will be fully developed by the end of summer 2006.

column5: Trust Me. I am a Physics Teacher
column18: I served as the "Teacher-in-Residence" (TIR) in the physics department on the Western Michigan University campus during the 2002-03 school year. After returning to my high school classroom during the fall of 2003, I have continued my involvement with the NSF funded PhysTEC (Physics Teacher Education Coalition) project through mentoring both beginning and crossover physics teachers. The mentor work centered on planning and sequencing instructional activities utilizing the available school and personal resources. Showing the mentee how the equipment worked, explaining how lab activities should be sequenced, discussing how students can be assessed, answering difficult mentee questions and having the mentees share in conference presentations were major components of this mentoring process. I will outline our shared challenges, solutions, successes and failures. Specific mentee comments will summarize their feelings on the value of this trusting, collegial relationship in the physics education community.

column5: A Physics Conceptual Mentoring Model
column18: This presentation will describe a model for mentoring novice physics teachers that was developed through the PhysTEC project using components from Indiana Certified Mentor training. This form of conceptual mentoring is carried out by Teachers in Residence while they are on leave from their school districts for a year on a university campus and continues when they return to their classrooms the following year. The impact of this mentoring addresses the issues of recruitment of new physics teachers as undergraduates and provides a supportive structure for their retention as classroom teachers after graduation.

column5: The Extinction of the Calculator in the High School Physics Classroom
column15: Michae D Wolter, Muncie Central H.S.
column18: Calculator and even graphing calculators are becoming obsolete just like the slide rules that we all loved not so long ago. The implementation of math engine software greatly enhances problem solving strategies for high school physics students. Examples from high school physics classes that have been using StudyWorks software routinely for the last six years will be provided.

column5: Are Students Understanding Science or Memorizing Pieces of Information?*
column15: Quinona Mack, City College of New York
column18: Many students are able to pass high school science classes by merely memorizing what is presented without understanding the underlying concepts. In a high school summer science enrichment program held at the City College of New York we were able to explore this issue as well as try to help the students look at learning science in a different way. We used surveys, in classroom observations, and interviews in order to look at epistemological dimensions such as approaches to learning science and the importance of concepts in solving problems. This helped us gauge how the students viewed learning science and scientific thinking. The program focused on observational astronomy. By the end of the program some of the students began to change their overall epistemological beliefs, others were better able to verbalize their beliefs, while others were able to question better what they had learned and whether they really understood it.
column19: *Sponsored by Richard N. Steinberg. Supported in part by NSF.

column5: Starting a Dialogue: The Potential of Vicarious Learning*
column18: Electronic resources are increasingly available to students in tertiary physics education, but the principles of best practice underlying the design and use of such materials are still being established. Can resources that employ modelled dialogue encourage the generative processes required for meaningful learning? This question was investigated in the area of quantum tunneling. Students' conceptions of the topic were surveyed after lecture and computational laboratory instruction. The uncovered alternative conceptions were then used to create a dialogue that was viewed by students in a lecture setting. A control group viewed the same material presented in a direct expository fashion. Students also participated in focus groups to explore their perceptions of the two treatments. The results demonstrate the potential of "vicarious learning" and suggest ways to improve both electronic and lecture teaching and learning.

column5: The Origin of Students' Difficulties in Learning Lagrange's Equation: Based on New Definition of Students' Difficulties
column18: By now a great deal of research has been carried out on student difficulties with a variety of physics concepts, much of it related to mechanics. To teach students well, we should understand what students' difficulties are and how students perceive difficulties. However, even though my researchers have used the term "students' difficulties," there is little literature which proposes well-defined explanation about students' difficulties in learning physics. In this research, we began to define the terminology "student difficulty." After we analyzed students' difficulties in learning Lagrange's equation, we found the origin of students' difficulties and different types of difficulties.

column5: A Self-Orienting Robot for Zero Gravity Environments
column17: Eric Muhs, Eric Muhs, Eric Muhs, Eric Muhs
column18: One aspect of the World Year in Physics Centennial was an invitation for experiment proposals to ride aboard NASA's "vomit comet" zero gravity airplane. In the fall of 2004, I successfully submitted a proposal for an experiment: Our robotics team would construct a spherical free floating robot that would sense its spin by means of light sensors. In a textbook display of Conservation of Angular Momentum, the robot would spin flywheels to control its spin in 3 axes. Genesis, construction, testing, and results will be presented, along with a bit of microgravity fun.

column5: Using an Engineering Context To Foster Inquiry-Based Approach for Teaching Physics
column18: This talk describes a series of seven inquiry-based educational applied physics and engineering Technical Activity Modules (TAMs), which have been developed, taught, and refined over the past nine years. The TAM objectives are to expose students to substantive, challenging physics content in a fun and relevant context, and to motivate students to continue studying mathematics and science. The TAM design integrates factors that are recognized to affect motivation, such as the appropriate level of challenge and sensory feedback (such as sound, light, motion). In this talk we discuss the use of an "engineering context," or "scenario" to motivate the activities. The engineering "scenario" makes explicit the approach intended to be used, which is not only inquiry and investigation of a scientific concept, but using new knowledge of science concepts to solve an engineering problem.

column5: Changes in Undergraduate Teaching and Learning Within the MSP-SWPA*
column18: The four Institutes of Higher Education (IHEs) within the Math and Science Partnership of Southwestern Pennsylvania (MSP-SWPA) are small, private, regional schools. The science, mathematics, and education faculty of the IHEs are involved in a variety of activities to enhance the content-knowledge, pedagogical practice, and leadership development within the 48 partner school districts. Symbiotically, K-12 teachers (Teacher Fellows) are granted sabbatical leave to return to IHEs and assist faculty in the revision of undergraduate courses. In this way, the MSP-SWPA works to enhance student performance in science and mathematics by improving the quality of the educator workforce and implementing research-based curricular materials and pedagogical best practices at all levels of instruction. Our report gives a brief overview and then focuses on the impact on undergraduate physics and mathematics courses at Saint Vincent College.
column19: *Supported by NSF grant #EHR-0314914 and Title II Part B MSP GRANT CFDA #84.366B (Pennsylvania Department of Education)

column5: The Dialect of Learning Physics in Hands-on Versus Mind-on Context
column18: There is a strong belief by some current education experts that for a proper teaching-learning process at high school level, physics should be taught hands-on. Nevertheless there is supporting evidence to the contrary that the hands-on approach does not facilitate student problem solving skills as much as it does on conceptual understanding and technical skills. Physics education in Africa and in most Asian countries, unlike in the United States is mostly focused on principles and theories, problem solving, and everyday observations rather than being activity or laboratory based. The history of physics supports the mind-on approach as simple observations of natural phenomenon followed by profound abstraction, logical thinking and mathematical formulations lead scientist to better understanding and discovery of the laws of nature. The discoveries of Newton's Universal Law of Gravity, Maxwell's Electromagnetic Theory, Einstein's Theory of Relativity are some of the leading examples.

column5: An Activities-Based Curriculum To Teach Light and Color
column15: Jack Glassman, Southern Illinois Univ. Edwardsville
column18: At Southern Illinois University Edwardsville, an initiative is underway to redevelop the distribution-level course "Light & Color" as an activities-based course.
