Teaching optics to students without a technical background lends itself particularly well to these activities-based methods. Restricting the discussion to a lecture format, even if demonstrations are included, misses the opportunity to have students directly investigate something which is, quite literally, right before their eyes. Using hardware purchased specifically for this purpose, we have developed a set of student activities which are integrated into the syllabus. As part of this initiative, a systematic evaluation of the effectiveness of the different activities has been undertaken. This course has been taught under the new paradigm with encouraging results. In this poster, the activities developed and preliminary results of the evaluation will be described and discussed.

column5: Involving Families in Homework Using Make & Takes
column18: The ultimate indication of successful physics instruction is the ability of the student to apply what they learn to their everyday lives. To help accomplish this goal, I have my student construct simple pieces of "apparatus" that they can easily take home with them. Once they get them home, they are required to explain them to a family member. This method of instruction seems to increase student understanding of physics and parental interest in the Physics class. In this talk, I will discuss my methodology and share several of the "make & takes" I use throughout the school year.

column5: ASISTing New Teachers To Survive the Early Years
column15: Julia K Olsen, Univ. of Arizona
column18: The first years of teaching are a huge challenge and it is generally understood that support systems are needed for beginning teachers. Research shows that well designed induction programs are essential to develop of new teachers and to retain them in the profession. A full year program focusing on the unique needs of early-career, middle school science teachers was framed and implemented by a team of formal and informal educators under the leadership of the author. The overarching intention of this program was helping the new teachers to develop the skills and practice for effective inquiry science instruction. Monthly guided-discussion sessions where the participants could interact with each other and share ideas on relevant topics focused on student learning were an integral part of this program. I will share some of the lessons we learned along the way.

column5: Teaching Physics in Alaska
column18: This will be a presentation based on experiences, both good and bad, during eight years of teaching physics/science in Alaska. These experiences encompass teaching in villages, small communities, and the largest city in Alaska.

column5: AIP's Science Writing Award for Children's Books
column15: Bea Uusma Schyffert, c/o Chronicle Books
column18: Title of book for which she is receiving award: "The Man Who Went to the Farside of the Moon."

column5: Combining Modern Technology and Traditional Lecturing in an Introductory College Physics Course
column18: Modern technology allows the instructor to enhance visual contest of the course tremendously. It also allows for immediate feedback of the students understanding of the important concepts and thus to better judge on what would be the best course of action: to repeat the material or to go forward. However, modern technology cannot completely substitute traditional lecturing. Physics is a very logical subject which is based on very few fundamental laws. It is very important for the students to know and to understand the fundamental laws and how a particular equation could be derived from a general law. Traditional lecturing is still the best way to introduce the general laws, to illustrate the derivations of particular equations, and to emphasize important concepts. The best results can be achieved not by total declining of traditional lecturing, but by combining the best of the well established methods of the past and modern teaching methods. I would like to share my experience of combining a fast response system, PowerPoint presentations, video demonstrations and traditional lecturing in an algebra based general college physics course at Barry University.

column5: Speedskiing and Physics
column18: Video of speedskiing made during a World Cup meet in British Columbia discusses physics issues faced not only by speedskiers but also by skiers in general. The aerodynamic force, ski geometry and design, body suit design, tuck position, waxing, etc. are discussed. Footage of skiers breaking speeds of 160 km/h is also shown.

column5: Assessment of Using the Clickers
column18: At the Ohio State University, clicker, an in-class polling system, was assessed in the electromagnetism quarter of a year-long introductory class. Two lecture sections were taught, only one of which used clickers. Assessment of the effectiveness of clicker usage was conducted in various ways. Normalized gains of the Concept Survey of Electromagetism (CSEM) and common exam results were compared between the clicker section and nonclicker section. Both the clicker section and the nonclicker section lectures were observed. The number of questions by various type of students during each lecture were compared between these two sections. In this talk, we will discuss the some preliminary results of this assessment.

column5: Assessment of Using an In-Class Polling System in Lectures
column15: Pengfei Li, The Ohio State Univ.
column18: At the Ohio State University, use of an in-class polling system (clickers), was assessed in the electromagnetism quarter of a year-long introductory class. Two lecture sections were taught, but only one of them used clickers. Clicker and non-clicker lectures were observed to determine relative class interactivity. In this talk, we will discuss preliminary results that include a comparison of normalized gains from pre and post testing with the Concept Survey of Electromagetism (CSEM), common exam questions, and digesting observations to assess relative class interactivity.

column5: Teaching Laboratories Featuring Medical Physics
column18: We have developed a suite of experiments on topics in medical physics appropriate for inclusion into the physics teaching laboratory at a variety of levels. Some of the experiments have been assembled from existing sources and some have been developed de novo. Most of the equipment is readily available from commercial sources, and the new laboratory manuals are available to other interested faculty. Modules include experiments on ultrasound imaging, x-ray imaging and computed tomography, emission tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, ionizing radiation, and applications of optics in medicine. We discuss our early experiences integrating medical physics topics into our sophomore and higher laboratories, and into an introductory course for premedical students.

column5: WebCT, Physlets, and LabPros, Oh My!
column18: Various forms of technology are currently used in the algebra-based introductory course at Appalachian State. These technologies are used to complement the on-going curricular changes to the Modeling Instruction materials and approach developed by D. Hestenes & M. Wells (Arizona State University). WebCT serves as the main "warehouse" for course materials, including Physlets, while LabPros are used during various in-class activities. The impact of these technologies on instruction and student attitudes will be presented and discussed.

column5: Near-Surface Composition of Mars Revealed Using Gamma Rays
column15: John M Keller, Univ. of Arizona
column17: William V. Boynton, GRS Science Team
column18: The Mars Gamma Ray Spectrometer (GRS) aboard the Mars 2001 Odyssey spacecraft collects gamma rays given off from the top meter of the surface of the planet. Using this data, we have detected large amounts of buried water ice in the arctic regions of Mars (

column5: Probing Student Understanding of the Atmospheric Greenhouse Effect
column17: John M Keller, Timothy F. Slater
column18: The flow of energy through our atmosphere and the atmospheric greenhouse effect are central to our current scientific understanding of climate and climate change. However, students and members of the public commonly hold weak and inaccurate conceptual understandings of these processes. We present both survey and interview results obtained over the past two years from 3,300 undergraduate non-science majors. We discuss concepts fundamental to effectively addressing student misconceptions on this topic, including the following: differences between solar and terrestrial spectra; light processes of reflection, absorption, and emission; wavelength dependent interactions between light and greenhouse gases; radiative equilibrium between space, the atmosphere, and the surface; and distinctions between the atmospheric greenhouse effect, ozone depletion, global climate change, and environmental pollution.

column5: Physics in the Mekong Delta*
column18: We present here preliminary results of a study of physics education in the Mekong delta region of Vietnam. Based on a series of interviews and observations, the intent of this study is to develop insight into how physics is learned in Vietnam, and then to collaboratively develop pedagogical tools that are appropriate to the region. This study has already yielded surprises ranging from resource challenges to unique approaches used in teacher training programs.
column19: *Funded in part by grants from the Freeman Foundation and the Keefer Fund

column5: Documentary Film About Science Teachers in Zambia
column18: In spite of all the problems that Africa faces today, it is neither pitiful nor hopeless. In this film the audience meets math and science teachers that are making serious contributions to education in Zambia. Andy Chimwanga teaches his students to make lab materials out of waste products; Edith Chimoka challenges her female students to overcome the obstacles to women in science. These and other teachers talk about education and development in the context of the COSM-Zambia teacher workshops of August 2004. Zambian and American teachers worked together to design simple, effective lab exercises that can reach both Zambian and American students. This 30-minute documentary will be followed by Q and A.

column5: Making Quantum Mechanics Visual and Interactive with Physlet- and OSP-Based Curricular Material*
column18: The teaching of quantum mechanics has remained relatively frozen in time since its inception, despite recent work assessing and improving the conceptual understanding of students and despite availability of computer simulations. Students, therefore, often see quantum mechanics in terms of misleading or incomplete visualizations, as one dimensional and time independent, and devoid of almost any connection with classical physics. To address this situation, we have produced and class-tested interactive Physlet- and Open Source Physics-based curricular material in support of introductory, intermediate, and advanced courses in quantum mechanics. These exercises address both quantitative and conceptual difficulties encountered by many students in such topics as wave function shape, momentum space, time evolution, and classical/quantum correlations. The materials are adaptable and can be used at a variety of levels with a variety of pedagogies. Examples of the curricular materials, the results of our preliminary assessment, and future directions of this project will be discussed.
column19: *Physlets and Open Source Physics are supported by the NSF grant DUE-0442581.

column5: Project IBEAM: Integrative Biology Experimental Activity Modules
column18: Project IBEAM is an interdisciplinary effort to increase biology majors' knowledge, understanding, and application of physics to issues in biology. This is done through the use of multi-week activity modules that can be used within both introductory physics and upper-division biology courses that allow students to investigate the connections between physics and biology. The modules used in the introductory physics courses consist of a set of standard physics labs done in the traditional weekly fashion that provide the background information for the biological concept under investigation, such as metabolic energy utilization, heart defibrillation, and magnetic navigation in animals. The modules finish with a capstone activity that uses a hybrid mixture of hands-on and computer simulations to apply the information learned in the other activities directly to the biological issue. This material is reinforced in later biology courses with module activities that refer back to what is previously learned.

column5: Empirical Scaling Laws of Rocket Exhaust Cratering
column17: Philip T Metzger, Christopher D Immer
column18: When launching or landing a space craft on the regolith of a terrestrial surface, special attention needs to be paid to the rocket exhaust cratering effects. If the effects are not controlled, the rocket cratering could damage the spacecraft or other surrounding hardware. The cratering effects of a rocket landing on a planet's surface are not understood well, especially for the lunar case with the plume expanding in vacuum. As a result, the blast effects cannot be estimated sufficiently using analytical theories. It is necessary to develop physics-based simulation tools in order to calculate mission-essential parameters. In this work we test the scaling laws of the physics in regard to growth rate of the crater depth. This will provide the physical insight necessary to begin the physics-based modeling.

column5: Photon Gun Experiments and the Measurement of Light Pressure*
column18: We demonstrate the effect of light pressure on microspheres suspended in a liquid. The Reynolds number of such a configuration is low, therefore the drag force of the surrounding liquid dominates and the inertia of the particle does not play a role. The velocity is therefore a direct measure of the instantaneous photon flux. We shot the microspheres with HeNe Laser light exiting a lensed fiber and recorded their motion. From these data we modeled the motion and calculated the initial acceleration which can reach up to 3800 m/s2. After the sphere has reached its terminal velocity it moves at constant velocity as long as the beam waist does not expand, i.e., as long as the light pressure on the sphere remains constant. These measurements are therefore a method to map the intensity distribution in a Gaussian beam.

column5: High School Students Can Do Scientific Research: Survey Results
column15: Beth Marchant, Univ. of Notre Dame
column18: In Summer 2005, more than 50 high school students were involved in real research in university and national laboratory physics labs across the country through QuarkNet.
column19: 1. QuarkNet is funded by NSF and DOE.

column5: Bringing University Expertise into the Classroom To Enhance STEM Education
column18: The Lehigh Valley Partnership for STEM Education partners professors, graduate fellows, and undergraduate fellows from Lehigh University as well as industry members from firms such as Binney and Smith with teachers and students from two local public school districts in the neighboring cities of Allentown and Bethlehem. The program has found itself with a mission to excite students from fourth grade through high school about science, technology, engineering, and math, as well as hopefully exciting college students about future careers in teaching these fields. While still early in our partnership, progress has been made in changing the attitudes students have towards these typically unpopular classes. We look to continue this work in our home schools and broaden our impact by incorporating more school districts into our program.

column5: The Arctic's Changing Cryosphere and the International Polar Year
column18: Computer models have long predicted that the effects of global warming would be observed earlier and be greater in the polar regions than elsewhere on Earth. In the late 20th century, significant physical and biological changes became apparent in the lands, seas, and atmosphere of the Arctic. These changes continue, and some of the most profound are occurring in the cryosphere<0x2014>snow, ice, and permafrost (e.g., decreasing sea ice and glacier volume), thawing permafrost, decreasing duration of snow cover, freshwater and sea ice. This paper will describe some of these cryospheric changes and discuss their broader implications, including social and economic effects, and the importance of the impending International Polar Year (IPY) of 2007-2009. The observed Arctic changes and their potential consequences lend impetus to the need for IPY, a coordinated effort to better understand the role of the polar regions in global processes, and engage the public in the excitement of polar research by creating opportunities for education, training, and outreach for all age groups.

column5: Model Comets with Dry Ice Chunks Floating on Warm Water
column18: At the Exploratorium we have an exhibit called "Icy Bodies," in which dry ice is used to model comets. Dry ice is denser than water and yet small pieces of dry ice will "float" on water supported by surface tension. If a bowl of warm water is used, then the dry ice will sublime rapidly expelling cold gas jets that propel the ice chunks across the water. The cold jets condense clouds from water vapor creating "tails" that are reminiscent of comets. The bits of ice often spin due to off-axis outgassing. Other interesting behaviors can be observed; the dry ice chunks seem to attract each other and stick together, yet they bounce off the rim of the water bowl.

column5: Melting the Frozen Curriculum with Information Fluency
column18: In order to make intelligent decisions, a person must know how to find and evaluate information and then incorporate good information in their decision-making process. A person who is capable of doing this demonstrates information fluency. Educational standards require students to demonstrate information fluency skills, and the bodies that are responsible for accrediting institutions of higher learning are setting standards for ensuring that college educated people have attained information fluency. Studies indicate that the most effective way to teach information fluency skills is in conjunction with specific subject matter. Over the summer, I collaborated with a physics faculty member to incorporate some information fluency assignments into a physics class. Here I will present some ideas for incorporating information fluency skills into physics curriculum at various levels.

column5: Reform of Introductory Laboratories: Baseline Data*
column18: At Miami University, we are planning to redo our entry-level physics lab course. To confidently make a change for the better, we must first establish what the problems are. To do so, we are conducting an extensive survey to all 500+ students taking the course, and then following up with extensive interviews of volunteers. The purpose will be to define what about the lab needs to be improved from a student perspective. Continuing research could include graduate student and professor interviews to identify, on a more academic level, what needs to be improved. This is the start of a multi-year project.

column5: Static or Dynamic: The Current Status of Women in Physics
column18: Are women still underrepresented in physics? Is this a problem? This talk will explore the current status of women in physics: classes, degrees, jobs, and lives. Looking at data from a variety of sources, I will discuss the participation rates of women in our field, and what work has been done on discovering how to make physics more welcoming to women. I will also discuss the gender gap in the physics classroom and the belief that interactive teaching strategies are particularly helpful to women.

column5: Geologic Overview of the 1964 M9.2 Great Alaska Earthquake
column18: The 1964 magnitude 9.2 earthquake in southern Alaska remains the largest recorded earthquake in our nation's history and it is the third largest in the world. The rupture lasted for about 4.5 minutes and caused widespread damage from ground shaking, landslides, and tsunamis. The earthquake was the first to be interpreted as a subduction zone "megathrust" earthquake, and played an important role in the acceptance of the then nascent theory of plate tectonics. Horizontal movements of up to 66 feet and subsidence of six feet reveal the elastic nature of the earth's crust. A splay off of the megathrust resulted in local uplift of up to 23 feet. Movement of the crust during fault rupture generated far-travelled tsunamis, and submarine landslides generated local tsunamis with wave run up heights of up to 170 feet.

column5: Ds9: It's Not Just for X-rays
column15: John Kolena, NC School of Science and Mathematics
column18: Ds9 is a FITS image processor that was originally designed for Chandra X-ray Observatory images. Even though ds9 has been used primarily by research astronomers, it can also be employed as a teaching/learning tool with optical images in high school or college astronomy courses. Classroom-ready image processing activities and results using optical images will be presented. Examples include measurement of the parallax of (and distance to) an asteroid, determination of the mass of Jupiter from observations of its satellites, and discovery of supernovas and analysis of their light curves. Ds9's direct connectivity to the Chandra image database and its ability to analyze x-ray spectra, light curves, and power spectra remotely via the Chandra servers also can facilitate student research projects.

column5: Exploring the Possibility of a Scenario-Based Instructor Book as an Inquiry Teaching Material in Secondary-Level Physics Classes*
column17: Sungmuk Lee, Kyungwoon Nam, Jaebong Lee, Mihee Kim
column18: Inquiry has been a central concept not only in physics education but also in other education areas for decades and has been extensively researched. However, there are still many questions about inquiry methods in schools. For instance, what is inquiry teaching? How can teachers be helped in using inquiry teaching? Many secondary school science teachers have less practical experience about inquiry learning and teaching. Even though there are many teaching materials for inquiry teaching, usually they do not have detailed information how to teach physics by inquiry in a specific contextual setting. Thus, the purpose of this study was to develop a scenario-based instructor book as a inquiry teaching material for secondary school science classes. In this talk we will discuss its effects and educational implications.

column5: The Chandra X-Ray Observatory Data Analysis Software and Classroom Activities
column15: Donna L Young, The Wright Center/Chandra EPO
column18: Educators, students, amateur astronomers and the general public can download and install a set of sophisticated tools, and access the public archive of observational data to investigate and analyze supernovae, binary stars, pulsars, black holes, galaxies, and galaxy clusters. The DS9 image and data analysis software tools can be downloaded into a Mac, Windows, or Linux environment. The analysis commands are executed at a dedicated server farm at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory in Cambridge, Massachusetts -- transforming any operating system into a virtual Linux machine. Any FITS file can be dropped into the DS9 imagining software, which allows comparisons among visible, IR, UV, radio and x-ray emissions for the same object. Besides basic tools -- color, scales, contrast, bias, and pixel values, the analysis tools include radial profiles, light curves and period folding, energy and spectra distribution plots and histograms. The archived data can be used for original research projects.

column5: Students, the Virtual Physics Classroom, and the Web
column18: The Modeling methodology developed by Wells, Hestenes, Dukerich et al. has been ported to an online environment to facilitate distance learning in the sciences. Modeling demands intensive, highly interactive and guided laboratory investigations. Has the creation of a virtual laboratory environment to emulate Modeling in a physical classroom been successful or is it an oxymoron? Students at high school and university levels have used various parts of the Learn Anytime Anywhere Physics project
column19: 1. Supported in part by Ded FIPSE grant #P339B990329

column5: Star Properties Concept Inventory: Design, Development, and First Results
column17: Edward E Prather, Bruce Johnson, Timothy F Slater
column18: The Star Properties Concept Inventory has been developed to investigate students' understanding of the properties of stars prior to instruction. It can then be used post-instruction to document gains in student understanding on the same topics. Distractors used with the multiple-choice questions are based on known student difficulties. Questions were tested by being presented to participants in three different formats, with responses compared; written responses were also compared to those provided by participants in interviews. Modifications were made to questions as needed, based upon student responses in earlier versions. Preliminary analysis from spring 2005 data indicates that statistically significant gains were observed over the course of instruction. Analysis on fall 2005 data to test the validity of the instrument will be reported.

column5: New Insights into Student Understanding of Basic Electric Circuits Concepts*
column17: Peter S. Shaffer, Lillian C. McDermott
column18: New insights into student understanding of basic concepts in electric circuits have emerged from an ongoing investigation by the Physics Education Group at the University of Washington. We have been examining the effectiveness of various types of pretest and post-test questions in probing student thinking about the concept of a complete circuit. The results indicate that successful performance on any single question does not necessarily reflect a robust, functional understanding of complete circuits. The use of complementary companion questions may therefore be required to probe student understanding in greater detail. Results will be presented from questions administered to a range of populations, including undergraduates in introductory calculus-based courses and pre-service and in-service K-12 teachers.

column5: Impact of Technology-Rich PET Curriculum on Future Elementary Teachers
column18: The PET (Physics for Elementary Teachers) curriculum makes extensive use of CPU simulators, digital-video clips, and computer-based motion detectors. Are pre-service K-8 teachers comfortable enough in such an environment to envision themselves using technology in their future classrooms? Students write and post an element of their web-based science education portfolio that is a grant proposal to purchase equipment for their future classroom. They are asked to make claims about the student learning that would result and back these claims with evidence from the literature. I will sumarize the proposals of the 70 students who have completed the assignment to determine what technology they believe is most useful in the K-8 classroom and why they believe this.

column5: Teaching Physics the Last Ten Days of High School
column18: One of the most difficult times to teach physics is 10 days before high school graduation. Seniors are busy with senior pictures, signing year books, senior assembly preparation and all that goes with this important time of their lives. They have been accepted to their schools and some may have mentally "checked-out." Even with all of the stresses of this busy time, Issaquah High School students are still engaged in doing and learning physics. The reason is the traditional IHS Physics "Scavenger Hunt." It is a time tested unit that allows flexibility for the teacher and students. When seniors still come into the class after their last required day to "finish up" or "check a few things over," I knew the lesson was a keeper. This low stress take home final exam project may be just what you are looking for to finish up their high school education.

column5: Exploring the Invisible Universe with NASA: Activities To Study the EM Spectrum
column18: As an Educator Ambassador for NASA's Swift Mission and as a Resource Agent for the Chandra, I have several different activities that will assist middle and high school students in researching and learning more about the EM spectrum using materials developed thru NASA resources to study and understand the various wavelengths of energy in our universe. I will explain the various free materials available to teachers, including the GEMS guide

column5: Catalyzing an Interest in Science and Engineering Careers
column15: Herb Schroeder, Univ. of Alaska Anchorage
column18: In Alaska, the Alaska Native Science & Engineering Program (ANSEP) is a collaborative effort between the National Science Foundation (NSF), the US Department of Education, the oil industry, philanthropic organizations, Alaska Native communities and regional corporations, and the professional engineering and construction industry. Beginning when they are high school sophomores, structured programs lead students each step of the way through high school, into the undergraduate years, on to graduate school, and into professional life. At each level the goal is to create empowerment and excitement around engineering and science. More than 300 Alaskan, Hawaiian, and Washington state high school students in 32 schools and 260 university students at 4 institutions in the three states are currently actively engaged as developing engineers. Program life retention rates in engineering are above 70% on each campus. This compares to the national average of 27% for Indigenous engineering students as published by the National Center for Education Statistics.

column5: Projecting a Community Image
column18: This poster will coalesce last year's SPS project, the 44-foot tall trebuchet (one of the biggest in the country), and this year?s projects: 1) a fully operational, mechanical model of the skull of the recently discovered T-Rex "Jane," and 2) a B-modified racecar that our SPS chapter is building, including elucidation of numerous procedures and materials required in order to construct these structures. A variety of pictures, captions, and articles will be utilized to highlight the positive impact the Highland Community College chapter of SPS has had on the community and the Physics/Engineering enrollment at Highland Community College.

column5: Search for E(5) Symmetry in Rare Earth Nuclei
column18: For even-even nuclei one can obtain approximate analytic solutions for the Bohr Hamiltonian. The E(5) symmetry, at the phase transition between spherical and gamma-soft limits, is not fully explored yet and only two experimental examples have been proposed so far. A theoretical search for examples of E(5) was conducted in the rare-earth using the existing level schemes. We carried out Interacting Boson Approximation calculations to explore the transition region for a finite number of valence nucleons, and to study the perturbations to E(5) at the transition point.
column19: Mirela Fetea - faculty mentor, AAPT member

column5: Practical Relativity
column18: Technology developments, particularly continuing improvements in clocks, have led to numerous applications in which both special and general relativity are important, even crucial. The Global Positioning System is one example in which constancy of the speed of light, breakdown of classical synchronization, time dilation, gravitational frequency shifts, the Sagnac effect, and the weak equivalence principle are significant, testable, and provide numerous real examples that can be used in teaching and testing relativity. This lecture will focus on demonstrations of fundamental relativity concepts and their practical applications in navigation, astronomy, and other fields (e.g., meteorology).

column5: Using Digital Signal Processing in the Advanced Laboratory
column15: Frank L Wolfs, Univ. of Rochester
column17: Wojtek Skulski, Megan Alexander, Daniel Miner
column18: During the last few years we have gained significant experience using Digital Signal Processors (DSPs) in the undergraduate laboratory through various independent-study projects using DSPs developed by SkuTek Instrumentation. We are now in the process of developing several applications of DSPs that are suitable for the Advanced Physics Laboratory. In this presentation we will use the muon lifetime experiment as an example of the power of DSPs. In our setup, we use a relative small plastic scintillator. The scintillator signals are digitized and the DSP triggers when the captured waveform contains both the stopping and the decay signal within about 10 microseconds. The digitized waveforms are written to disk for off-line analysis. The waveforms will not only contain information about the time between stopping and decay, but can also be used to extract information about the energy deposited by the stopping muons and the energy released when they decay.
column19: This project was partly supported by SkuTek Instrumentation and by the NSF (PHY-0242483).

column5: An Undergraduate Low-Mass Balloon-Borne Cosmic Ray Experiment
column15: Robert Walch, Univ. of Northern Colorado
column17: Richard Dietz, Patricia Mills, Julie Smith, Ryan Marshall
column18: A balloon-borne cosmic ray detection experiment built, tested and mainly designed by undergraduate students will be described. Two photomultiplier tubes were encased in sealed PVC tubes each vacuum epoxied to a piece of scintillator material sensitive to charged cosmic ray secondaries. The pressure inside the PVC tubes was kept at 1 atm. This novel approach eliminated possible coronal discharge. Output signals went to a coincidence counting circuit board then to a data logger. The data showed the expected count profile throughout the 2.5 hour flight which reached an altitude of around 100,000'. The total mass of the experiment was only 2.43 kg. The project provided not only an outstanding learning opportunity for the students involved but also experience in teamwork and problem-solving.

column5: Physics is ePort-able
column18: Both my students and I are using Electronic Portfolios (ePorts) to communicate with each other and the rest of the world. My use is primarily as a learning management system (replacing Blackboard) while my students use it to present their major work in the class. Come hear how we also use blogs, wikis and podcasting in our ePorts to improve student learning. I will show my ePort along with selected student sites. I will also entertain questions concerning various ePort platforms as well as why and how I migrated from Blackboard after 5 years of use.

column5: QUANTUM MECHANICS: Is it really difficult to understand by the college students or??
column18: The objective of this research is to study the potential solutions of the common misconceptions, insufficient teaching techniques and other instructional or conceptual significant problems encountered while teaching/learning an important branch of physical science, quantum mechanics (QM), at the freshmen college year. The study reported in this paper was conducted both in the US and followed by in Turkey. The aim of the study was to elaborate and analyze the difficulties of teaching and learning Quantum Mechanics (QM) in the college level. An effective answer to the corresponding instructional problem might allow the basic ideas of QM to be comprehended by the students better. Although the foundation of QM goes to the beginning of 19th century, unfortunately, studies about its difficulties encountered by the students were limited and far away from finding solutions to them.

column5: Creating a Whorl with an Optically Driven Helical Bacterium
column18: A left handed helical bacterium is optically tweezed with a 633nm Helium-Neon Laser. The forces from the laser cause the bacterium to rotate clockwise and thus create a whorl surrounding it. This whorl causes the surrounding bacteria to rotate around the tweezed bacterium. The path of these rotating bacteria can be tracked and from this data the curvature of the path and the angular velocity of each of the rotating bacterium can be found.
column19: Funded by the Cottrell Research Corporation

column5: The initiation of TA-student interactions in tutorials
column15: Rachel E Scherr, Univ. of Maryland
column17: Rosemary S Russ, Tom Bing, Ray Hodges
column18: At the University of Maryland we videotaped several semesters of tutorials as part of a large research project. A particular research task required us to locate examples of students calling the TAs over for assistance with a physics question. To our surprise, examples of this kind of interaction were difficult to find. We undertook a systematic study of TA-student interactions in tutorial: in particular, how are the interactions initiated? Do the students call the TA over for help with a particular issue, does the TA stop by spontaneously, or does the worksheet require a discussion with the TA at that point? The initiation of the interaction is of particular interest because it provides evidence of the motivation for and purpose of the interaction. This talk will present the results of the study.
column19: Supported in part by NSF REC 0440113.

column5: Reaching Out: Physics Outreach to High School Students
column15: John D. Lorenz, Univ. of Louisville
column17: Alyssa Cramer, Blakesly Burkhart, Scott Boyd
column18: One goal of the University of Louisville Society of Physics Students (SPS) chapter is to promote public interest in physics through outreach activities. Most of this outreach is to high school physics classes. We visit local high schools to encourage students to explore careers in physics, to teach physics, and to show that physics is fun. We have developed several presentations designed to achieve these aims. This poster will detail two programs: demonstrations of wave properties and outreach at all-girls' schools. We will discuss student and teacher responses to our visits.

column5: Functional Equations in the Two-Year Curriculum
column18: Over the centuries, many scientific discoveries involved the solution to a functional equation. Some of these may be introduced in calculus and calculus-based physics courses. In particular, I discuss applications to special relativity.

column5: Parallels between the Dine? Philosophy of Learning and traditional physics teaching
column15: Carlon G Ami, Univ. of New Mexico
column18: Teaching the way we were taught, typically a formal lecture with limited student interaction, has not been an uncommon practice for many of us physics teachers. In the early 90's the board of regents at Dine' College, a two-year college owned and operated by the Navajo (Dine') tribe, adopted the Dine' Philosophy of Learning (DPL) model which incorporated traditional Navajo philosophies of teaching and learning as a guide for instruction at the college. DPL is cyclonic beginning with Nitsahakees (thinking), Nahata (planning), Iina (implementation), and Sihasin (stage of reassurance). Implementing these steps in addressing situations, individuals lead themselves toward Sa'ah naaghai bik'eh hozho, the Dine' traditional living system that places life in harmony with the natural world. This typifies the traditional mode of teaching/learning of most American Indian tribes, parallels the preferred method for problem-solving techniques in physics education, and thus is important for teachers of American Indian students.

column5: Science Museum (Interpretive Center) at Principia College
column18: The Science Interpretive Center (museum) at Principia College opened in April 2004. It occupies space provided by a vacated chemistry laboratory. Thematically developed around local sky, prairie, forest, and wildlife, the museum presents live displays of the natural environment. Concept areas displayed include biology, archeology, chemistry, and astronomy. Being a retiree liberated from regular teaching duties, the presenter volunteered to devote time to developing the museum. The presentation shares the museum planning process, means of implementation, and views of the current displays.

column5: Modeling of Laser Frequency Noise Suppression in LIGO
column15: Alyssa J. Cramer, Univ. of Louisville
column18: In 1916 and 1918, Einstein postulated that, just as accelerating point charges produce electromagnetic wave, accelerating masses produce gravitational waves. The Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) employs three detectors and a process of very precise distance measurement to observe gravitational waves produced by distant massive objects. LIGO uses nested control loops to stabilize the frequency of the laser light used in this distance measurement. We consider the inner servo, the Frequency Stabilization Servo (FSS), used in the Hanford four-kilometer interferometer.

column5: Service Learning in Physics
column18: Students in the Marquette University introductory physics classes participate in service learning activities. They are challenged to find a way to represent physics concepts in a way that is fun and informative for kids. At the same time, the students must master the topics themselves so that they are able to teach them. Typical topics include Newton?s laws, rotational motion, and simple harmonic motion. The students present to the first through fifth grade students at the United Community Center and other after school programs in Milwaukee, WI. Post-introductory physics students are encouraged to continue their outreach efforts through the Society of Physics Students. The club sponsors High Interest Days, targeting underprivileged elementary school audiences. A variety of demonstrations are used, the most recent addition being a bed of nails. Students enjoy working with hands-on physics and learning new concepts in building the equipment. They also learn how to teach.

column5: A Research Plan for Enhancing and Evaluating Students' Proficiency in Electromagnetics
column15: Johanna Leppvirta, Helsinki Univ. of Technology
column18: Electromagnetics is a part of the engineering curriculum in the Electrical Engineering department of the Helsinki University of Technology. Electromagnetics is often viewed as a most abstract and conceptually difficult area of engineering education. This poster describes experiences and perceptions the researcher has made while participating in two basic electromagnetic field theory courses as a participant observer. The aim has been to understand what is difficult for the students, what are students' attitudes towards electromagnetics and what is preventing students from learning the topic more sufficiently? In this poster, the researcher will also introduce a research plan for studying how cooperational learning and teaching methods could enhance students' mathematical proficiency and understanding of the fundamental concepts in electromagnetics.

column5: CoMPASS: Integrating Digital Text in Design-Based Science Classrooms: Scaling-Up
column15: N. Sanjay Rebello, Kansas State Univ.
column17: Sadhana Puntambekar, Ann A. O'Connell, Roland Hbscher
column18: Our poster describes CoMPASS (Concept Mapped Project-based Activity Scaffolding System) a five-year project funded through the National Science Foundation and currently being implemented within two very different school systems in Connecticut. CoMPASS is an inquiry-based approach that integrates hands-on science investigations and the use of digital text to help middle school students learn science. Our collaborative research team includes the implementing teachers, educational psychologists, physicists, and measurement specialists. In our poster, we will describe the student learning goals of CoMPASS and its implementation across diverse classrooms and schools, with an eye to the future challenges inherent in its potential wide-scale implementation and use.
column19: Supported by the U.S. National Science Foundation Grant IERI # 0437660.

column5: Effect of Homework Cheating in Introductory Physics
column18: From a class of ~430 MIT freshman using the electronic homework tutor MasteringPhysics, ~9% were categorized as Quick Solvers - students who answer 50% or more of their electronic homework problems in less than 2.5 minutes. We argue that such quickness results from academic dishonesty. As a group, Quick Solvers performed lower on all exams as compared to the real-time and delayed solvers. More importantly, their relative performance as the semester progressed diverged farther from the real-time and delayed solvers. On the course final exam, Quick Solvers averaged 1.5 standard deviations below all other students. Quick Solvers had a course failure rate that was 4 times higher than all other students, ~31% to 7%. Disturbingly, this means that ~70% of the Quick Solvers managed to attain the C or higher required for advancement into Electricity and Magnetism, the follow-on subject at MIT. Quick Solvers also performed lower on the E&M; final exam the following semester. We will also discuss behavioral patterns associated with Quick Solvers which illuminate why, when, and how students are cheating. These results suggest ways to eliminate cheating in order to improve overall learning, thereby reducing course failures and better preparing students for academic and post-collegiate success. We will contrast our results from Fall '03 with the most recent results from Fall '05 and gauge the effectiveness of our preventative measures.

column5: Mentoring through Catastrophe: A New Orleans Perspective
column15: Kathleen McCloud, Xavier Univ. of Louisiana
column18: The disaster in New Orleans is well documented. In this presentation, we will describe on-going efforts in the Physics Department at Xavier University of Louisiana to provide support and mentoring to K-12 teachers displaced by hurricane Katrina. These efforts are spearheaded by the Teacher in Residence (Remonda Edmond), a position which is provided through the Physics Teacher Education Coalition (PhysTEC). One focus has been locating displaced teachers and setting up a network of teachers in similar geographic areas for mutual support. We have now located most of the members of the Xavier Teacher Advisory Group, who will be able to serve as mentors in their areas, and are gathering suggestions for further ways to aid displaced teachers. Some of the challenges we have faced have implications for all institutions. Problems such as communication when the infrastructure is destroyed and access to records and resources is unavailable will be presented.

column5: Physics Workshop Project for the Twenty-First Century*
column15: Curtis J Hieggelke, Joliet Junior Coll.
column18: We will report on the workshops offered by this project for two-year college and high school physics teachers. The goal of this project has been to help TYC and HS physics students develop a stronger understanding of science, with an emphasis on physics and its applications in industry. This program addressed these issues by providing faculty development workshops for teachers who teach core physics courses for technology programs and other programs. These workshops have been designed to acquaint the participants with the integration and implementation of emerging technology and active learning strategies. These workshops provided extensive and intensive, collaborative experiences for participants with workshop materials that made it possible for participants to implement the workshop ideas in their classrooms.

column5: Design and Construction of an Electron Diffractometer for Thin Film Studies
column15: Erick Blomberg, Bradley Univ. Dept. of Physics
column18: This talk will discuss the physics behind the study of epitaxial growth of thin films through analysis of the intensity variations of features diffracted from a growing surface, and an analysis of the diffraction spot profiles. Details of the authors' design and construction of a medium energy electron diffractometer (MEED) will be presented.

column5: Applicability of the MPEX Survey in Japanese Introductory Physics Class
column15: Michi Ishimoto, Kochi Univ. of Technology
column18: The MPEX Survey translated into Japanese has been investigated as to whether it is applicable in probing Japanese students' expectations toward learning physics. The participants in this survey were Japanese students (majoring in material science, biology, or chemical engineering) in an introductory physics course. The survey results show a large gap between the expectations of the "experts" and the students in comparison to the results obtained with U.S. students. When the results of this survey were compared with those in the U.S., three differences were apparent. First, the ratios of the neutral answers, which cannot be classified in either the favorable or unfavorable category, were considerably larger. Second, the change in answers from the beginning and from the end of the course was quite small, especially in the "reality" cluster, in which a large drop was shown in the U.S. Third, the results exhibit a low favorable ratio in the "coherence" and the "math" cluster.

column5: Force Distribution on Surface of Accelerated Block
column15: Pontus Ahlqvist, Univ. of Central Florida
column18: In most introductory physics classes, one is taught to deal with contact forces. However, a great simplification is often introduced. Rather than treating forces as distributions which they in fact are, students are taught to replace this rather complicated approach with that of single forces acting from some geometrically sound point. In this project we have tackled a relatively common problem of determining the forces involved when a truck accelerates a homogeneous box at a high enough rate in order to make it seemingly stick to the truck?s front. However, rather than taking the approach normally taken (i.e. point forces), we shall consider the forces being described as distributions.

column5: Setup for Creating White-Light Holograms in the Undergraduate Laboratory
column18: A laboratory setup for making white-light holograms will be presented along with details of a method to reliably make holograms in a single laboratory period. This setup has been used as one component of an experiment in the Light and Color course at Towson University for a number of years. Recent changes in the developing technique have greatly reduced the time required to complete the experiment.

column5: The initiation of TA-student interactions in tutorials
column15: Rachel E Scherr, Univ. of Maryland
column17: Rosemary S Russ, Tom Bing, Ray Hodges
column18: At the University of Maryland we videotaped several semesters of tutorials as part of a large research project. A particular research task required us to locate examples of students calling the TAs over for assistance with a physics question. To our surprise, examples of this kind of interaction were difficult to find. We undertook a systematic study of TA-student interactions in tutorial: in particular, how are the interactions initiated? Do the students call the TA over for help with a particular issue, does the TA stop by spontaneously, or does the worksheet require a discussion with the TA at that point? The initiation of the interaction is of particular interest because it provides evidence of the motivation for and purpose of the interaction. This talk will present the results of the study.

column5: Elliptical Orbit: 1/r^2 Force
column15: Maria L Mazzino, Univ. of Louisiana at Lafayette
column17: Jeffrey Prentis, Bryan Fulton, Carol Hesse
column18: Newton's proof of the connection between elliptical orbits and inverse-square forces ranks among the "top ten" calculations in the history of science. This time-honored calculation is a highlight in an upper-level mechanics course. It would be worthwhile if students in introductory physics could prove the relation, elliptical orbit -> 1/r^2 force, without having to rely on upper-level mathematics. We introduce a simple procedure - Newton's Recipe - that allows students to readily and accurately deduce the algebraic form of force laws from a geometric analysis of orbit shapes. Newton's Recipe is based on a hidden gem in Newton's Principia - the force formula F QR/(SPxQT)2. Given any kind of orbital curve (elliptical, spiral, ?) students deduce the force simply by measuring the orbital shape parameters (QR, SP, QT) with a ruler. In our "Orb Lab", students solve the celebrated Kepler Problem: Given an ellipse, find the force. The class draws a large elliptical orbit. The orbit is cut into small pieces - orbital arcs. Each student gets his or her own arc and measures the force responsible for the shape of their arc. Students uncover a simple pattern in the variation of the force along the ellipse. In essence, the class discovers one of the most fundamental laws of nature - the law of gravity - using string, tacks, and a ruler, along with a little help from Galileo, Newton, and Kepler.

column5: Investigation of the Magnetic Damping on an Air Track
column18: A novel experimental method has been introduced for studying the magnetic damping on a non-ferromagnetic air track. Due to the continuous and persisting interaction between the moving magnets fixed on the air track glider and the horizontal air-track, the experiment can be carried out with low-cost photoelectric detecting techniques. A simple theoretical model has been proposed based on the Faraday's and Ampere's laws, and analytical expression has been deduced to explain the experimental results. A new explaination based on the interaction of eddy current and horizontal component of magnetic field is given for the rotation problem in all moving metal plate and static magnetic field experiment approaches met. Systematic experiments were performed with home-developed apparatus and the results agree well with the theoretical model. The rotation problem is automatically suppressed in our method and provides a simple and instructive platform to teach college physics.

column5: Using Computer Models to Understand Arctic Natural Climate Variability and Climate Change
column18: Computer models are invaluable tools for investigating climate since they allow us to do computer experiments on the climate that are not possible to do with the real climate. These physically based models have strengths and weaknesses, which must be kept in mind as the model output is analyzed. Results from two studies will be presented from two different types of models, a Global Climate Model (GCM) and a Regional Climate Model (RCM). The GCM project examines the impact of reduced summer arctic sea ice on the high latitude atmospheric circulation. The RCM project is an interdisciplinary study where the model is used to provide temperature and precipitation information over the next century to glaciologists so they can estimate expected melt rates of Alaska glaciers in an enhanced carbon dioxide world.

column5: Ecological Manifestations of Climate Change in Alaska
column15: Glenn P Juday, Univ. of Alaska Fairbanks
column18: Alaska has warmed to levels last experienced at least 1,000 years ago based on tree-ring reconstructions. Temperature regimes apparently shift abruptly because of changes in ocean current systems. Permafrost is warming and thawing, leading to tree toppling. Closed basin lakes are shrinking or have disappeared. Many boreal tree populations in Alaska grow best in cold summers and least in warm summers because of temperature induced drought stress. Overall boreal forest photosynthesis has generally declined since the late 1970s. Trees at treeline show threshold temperature effects on growth. Growth of trees on the coolest and moistest sites is increasing. The Alaskan north slope tundra has become greener. Forest fire extent in Alaska and Yukon Territory reached a record high in 2004 and 2005. Several simultaneous forest health problems have appeared, and insect outbreaks have killed trees over large areas. The Arctic Climate Impact Assessment documents warming across the circumpolar north.

column5: Positive Epistemological Change Through Multi-Representational Problem Solving Skills
column15: Andy Buffler, Univ. of Cape Town
column18: A significant proportion of first-time entering university physics students may be characterised as having poor numeracy and problem solving skills coupled with negative attitudes towards learning physics. Their high school experience has often left them with a perception of physics as a formula-driven, mathematical discipline with little or no connection to either their everyday lives or future careers. Such inappropriate epistemologies can hamper life-long learning by precluding students from developing conceptual mastery and from assimilating valuable generic skills such as problem solving. The present work aimed at exploring whether explicit development of multi-representational approaches to problem solving can directly promote positive attitudes towards learning physics. A number of benchmarking instruments were used, including the Maryland Physics Expectations Survey, which revealed a significantly positive shift in the students' views about their own learning. The students' performance in their introductory physics course also improved markedly.

column5: Effective Instructional Strategies for Pre-Service Elementary School Science Courses
column15: Thomas Callaway, Stephen F. Austin State Univ.
column18: The departments of Physics and Astronomy and of Chemistry at Stephen F. Austin State University offer a team taught introductory physical science course for pre-service elementary school teachers which has demonstrated effectiveness in changing student attitude towards science. The course has served as a model for other science courses for pre-service teachers taught at our university. We present the results of pre-/post-course surveys as evidence of our success.

column5: From Alaska to Jupiter: Contributions to the Galileo Mission
column18: The Geophysical Institute was a member of the Energetic Particle Detector Team of NASA's planetary mission Galileo, participating in the study of the plasma and high-energy radiation environment of Jupiter, its moon Io as both source and sink of particles, and the newly discovered "mini-magnetosphere" of moon Ganymede. Beset with a number of initial mishaps, this mission became a milestone in the history of space science and technology. I will briefly review some of the technical features and general scientific achievements of this mission, and then concentrate on the most significant scientific findings with data from our instrument, a complex multiple detector/spectrometer system designed to measure fluxes over a wide range of particle mass, charge, and energy. I will point out how the story of this mission can serve as an excellent tool to develop interest of high school physics students in basic space research with unmanned missions.

column5: The Gender Gap in Physics: Explanations, Data, Analysis
column18: In an address delivered in 2005, Harvard President Lawrence Summers proposed three possible explanations for the gender gap in physics participation, particularly at the highest levels of academic employment: high powered job, different availability of aptitude at the high end, and different socialization and patterns of persistent discrimination. Although acknowledging the possibility of all three, Summers alleged but did not present evidence primarily in favor of the second hypothesis. In this talk I will review the evidence supporting all three possibilities, as well as an extension of the socialization and discrimination hypothesis, i.e., the possibility that the gender gap is the result of the nature of science as it is currently construed. In addition, I will discuss the implications of each of these alternatives in terms of how (and in fact whether) the gender gap can and should be addressed.

column5: The Gender Gap in Physics: Some Research Results
column18: There is still a gender gap in the performance of students in introductory physics courses, particularly on standardized tests such as the Force Concept Inventory. In this talk I will present results from several years of research, done both at the University of Minnesota and Miami University, which illuminate what some of these gaps are. In addition, some research results will point us to possible explanations of why these gaps exist.

column5: Making Sense of Students' Thoughts About a Class's Goals
column15: Gordon J. Aubrecht, Ohio State Univ.
column17: Dedra Demaree, Yuhfen Lin, David Brookes, Xueli Zou
column18: Students intending to become teachers take Physics by Inquiry courses at Ohio State. (The course is open to other nonscience majors as well.) We assess student perceptions of the Physics by Inquiry course using a Q-sort assessment. The assessment forces students to categorize the extent to which they think twenty-five descriptive statements characterize their laboratory class experience. They sort the statements from most to least characteristic of the course into bins of succesive size 2, 6, 9, 6, 2 (forcing a "normal" distribution). We describe how we can glean information about students' perceptions of the class by examining differences from the "average" values. We find significant differences among different classes and between students and instructors.

column18: We have been teaching an upper division Modern Physics with Health Applications course for several years now at Pacific University. The three projects are related to nuclear medicine, x-ray treatment, and magnetic resonance imaging. column5: A State of the Art Astronomy Laboratory: ASU's GoTo Facility

column18: Providing introductory astronomy labs with observational activities performed locally by the students is challenging. Uncertain weather, long setup times, and bulky equipment all make it difficult to offer observational labs with the same degree of rigor and quantitative analysis as is found in other science labs. Appalachian State University's new state-of-the-art GoTo Astronomy Facility is designed to address these difficulties, allowing a fleet of eighteen 10-inch GoTo telescopes equipped with CCD cameras to be permanently mounted in a large moving roof structure. Since useful data can be now be obtained on marginal nights and those too cold to be outside for extended periods, this facility will allow us to conduct observing on a more consistent basis, while offering realistic observational exercises focused on the analysis of data that students have obtained for themselves. This facility will serve as a test bed and model to encourage construction of similar facilities elsewhere.

The E-Lab portal provides the tools to support inquiry rather than recipes that might constrain it. The cosmic ray E-Lab also provides resources for teachers and students that lack the in-class hardware. Teachers, students, and guests now actively use the QuarkNet E-Lab portal to organize their cosmic ray research. We focus on how a teacher grows their way into this in-depth use of the cosmic ray E-Lab for real, applied physics research. We will showcase examples of several QuarkNet teacher's integration of the cosmic ray E-Lab tools into their teaching and look at the student responses to the open approach of self-guided research.

column5: What's Entropy? Student Understanding of Thermodynamics in an Introductory Physics Course*
column18: Continuing with our previous investigations into student understanding of thermal physics in an introductory calculus-based course, we have probed students' ideas regarding entropy and the second law of thermodynamics. Nearly 90% of students enrolled in the class have had previous exposure to thermodynamics concepts in chemistry and/or high school physics courses, so many have specific ideas about these concepts before instruction begins. We will present free-response and multiple-choice data collected both pre- and post-instruction from the previous three semesters. Evidence suggests that many key concepts, e.g., that the entropy of the universe increases for all non-ideal processes, remain highly resistant to instruction, although students seem to make progress in understanding certain thermodynamic relationships.

column5: Eigenvalue Statistics of Weakly Driven One-Dimensional Quantum Systems
column18: Unlike most integrable quantum systems, the eigenvalues of one-dimensional time-independent systems do not generally follow Poisson statistics. The eigenvalues of periodically driven one-dimensional systems in the limit of zero field strength may exhibit Poisson statistics. We study how the frequency of the driving field and the number of eigenvalues computed affect the eigenvalue statistics for the linear potential well, the harmonic oscillator, and the infinite square well. The weakly driven linear potential well is found to exhibit Poisson statistics regardless of the frequency of the driving field, while the harmonic oscillator never follows Poisson statistics. As the frequency of the driving field becomes more irrational, the eigenvalue statistics for the infinite square well make a transition from statistics that are clearly not Poisson to statistics that are very close to Poisson.

column5: Aurora: A Signature of the Planet
column18: Aurora is a distinctive and characteristic response of the atmosphere of a planet with a magnetic field to bombardment by the solar wind. It displays information about the magnetic and atmospheric environment of the planet as well as providing a wonderful light show that impresses the observer with its beauty and activity. Through a selection of auroral images obtained in the Fairbanks district, covering a full range of different types, the physical processes will be discussed. Using some observations from satellites and simulations of space plasmas shown as movies, the aurora will be shown from the perspective of an astronaut or near-space visitor to Earth, Jupiter, and Saturn. A short survey of radio emissions and ionospheric currents resulting from the aurora will be given. The lecture will end with some speculations on the use of aurora to investigate the atmospheres of planets external to our solar system.

column5: Unleashing Action
column15: Edwin Taylor, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
column18: Newton helps us to predict motion: Will an incoming asteroid miss the earth? Increasingly we also have the power to control motion: Firing a space probe from earth orbit to moon orbit. The action principle is the tool of choice when initial and final conditions are specified. Because action manages motion using scalar energy, it is easily generalized to three dimensions, multi-particle systems, and motion under constraint. Historical giants and current textbooks: 1) make errors, which we are gradually correcting, and 2) speak in advanced formalism, which we are progressively simplifying to skirt equations of motion entirely. Fundamental principles embodied directly and transparently in interactive computer displays empower students to explore motion in ways heretofore unavailable to them. See for yourself at http://www.eftaylor.com/software/ActionClockTicks.

column5: Modeling of Magnetically-Coupled Rotors
column15: Tiara Norris, California State Univ., Chico
column18: An intriguing oscillatory system can be created using small magnets fixed on the edge of parallel rotating planes. This investigation began by examining the behavior of such an oscillator constructed with "Geomag" magnetic toys. In attempting to model the system, a simplified version of the problem was considered: two magnetic dipoles separated along a common axis of rotation. The observed effect is an oscillation in velocity between the sections of the toy. The model's predictions were compared to data collected from a simplified oscillator apparatus and match surprisingly well.

As the challenges for participation get reduced, students, researchers, and professors are finding many new ways to engage learners. Social networking software allows information to be exchanged in new timely and nuanced ways never before seen. People are engaging in ways similar to remote sensing with remote interpretations. Social networking software allows an aggregation of queries to a knowledge base that uncovers additional ironic juxtapositions. Naturally there is controversy. Should we trust Wikipedia? Why not? Should we trust a folksonomy of categorization? Why not? Finally, what is amenable to worthwhile uses of social networking software in the service of education?

column5: Over the Moon with Carbon Nanotubes
column15: Nadya Mason, Univ. of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
column18: Tiny cylinders of carbon, termed carbon nanotubes, have become a highlight of nanotechnology research. With diameters as small as a billionth of a meter, and lengths up to a millimeter, these unique structures can be stronger than steel, as flexible as drinking straws, and more conductive than copper. Their amazing electrical and mechanical properties give nanotubes enormous potential for both fundamental physics and applications. Current research ranges from studies of quantum interference in individual tubes to the creation of a nanotube-based space elevator. In this lecture, I will discuss the synthesis, properties, and applications of carbon nanotubes, and show their potential to revolutionize science and technology.

column5: How I Learned To Stop Worrying About Schrodinger's Cat
column15: Hans Christian von Baeyer, College of William and Mary
column18: Anxiety about quantum weirdness, symbolized by Schrdingers cat, has been with us for eighty years, but the last forty have brought promise of relief. Theoretical and experimental progress has inspired many different schemes for making sense of the counterintuitive rules of quantum mechanics<0x2014>but one concept comes up repeatedly. As mediator between the objective reality of the atom, say, and its subjective understanding by the human brain, the slippery concept of information suggests itself. The word was used in connection with the meaning of quantum mechanics by Schrdinger himself, and seems particularly appropriate in our computer age. Nevertheless, one hunts in vain for the word in the indexes of introductory physics books. Introducing information into the study of the foundations of quantum mechanics has the advantage of bringing new tools, such as information theory and Bayesian thinking, to the task. It has cured my quantum felinophobia.

column5: A Tale of Two Universes
column18: Over the last forty years, cosmologists have converged on a story of the universe that begins with a big bang followed by eternal expansion and cooling. At present, the universe is accelerating towards a vacuous oblivion. Recently, a radically different story has been proposed that revives the old idea of a cyclic universe and challenges nearly every aspect of the standard tale. The historic problems with earlier cyclic models are finessed using imaginative new ideas emerging from string theory. According to the cyclic story, the universe evolves from big bang to big crunch about once every trillion year, and the events that shaped the large scale structure of the cosmos today took place a cycle ago, before the last big bang. This talk will introduce the two divergent views of cosmic history, showing how each can explain current astronomical observations and how they may be distinguished by future measurements.

The program consisted of 12 sessions during which developed lesson plans were examined, hands-on exercises were provided, and low-cost/no-cost demonstrations were explored. A website and a Blackboard-based, online classroom were established for participants. An exit survey was administered and analyzed. In the second year, the program was expanded to Arizona and Washington states. A mentoring program has been initiated to insure that the TeachSpace is propagated to other teachers and schools. The third year activities are being planned.

column5: Some of the Interesting Physics of the Polar Ozone Hole
column15: David Newman, Univ. of Alaska Fairbanks
column18: Turbulence is nearly ubiquitous in nature and turbulent transport is the fundamental transport mechanism (for example the spreading of pollutants) in many complex dynamical systems, from astrophysical plasmas to geophysical fluids (such as the atmosphere and ocean). In addition to such turbulent fluctuations, mean flows often exist in these systems. Because the turbulence is often the primary mechanism for transport, the interaction between the sheared mean flows and the turbulent fluctuations is of fundamental importance in understanding the dynamics of that transport. This talk will explore some of the basic interactions between turbulence and sheared flows in the context of the Polar Ozone Holes. We will present some simple models that capture much of the important dynamics. On the way to understanding the dynamics of these important structures we will look at a number of simple but fascinating models of the nonlinear system, including a simple phase transition model and a cellular automata sandpile model.

column5: Sliding Below the Melting Point: Environmental Effects of Premelting Ice
column18: Water and ice are powerful agents of erosion, molding the natural landscape through the action of rivers, waves and glaciers.The transformation of water to ice also causes massive weathering, familiar on small scales as frost damage to roads and brick work. Deformations of the ground surface, known as frost heave, are driven by powerful forces within premelted liquid films. These are thin (typically nm-scale) layers of melt that separate the ice surfaces from foreign substrates. Premelting dynamics have impressive macroscopic consequences for such diverse phenomena as the sliding of glaciers, chemical uptake on atmospheric ice particles, the scintering of snow fields, the electrification of thunder clouds, and frost heave itself. The physics of premelted films and their influence on the natural environment are the focus of this talk.

column5: Sea, Ice, and Snow: Agents of Climate Change
column15: John Walsh, Univ. of Alaska Fairbanks
column18: Sea ice and snow cover are characterized by high reflectivities and by their ability to insulate the underlying land or ocean from extreme temperatures of the lower atmosphere. The loss of snow and ice cover accelerates warming of the land and ocean, thereby enhancing the retreat of snow and ice. This process represents a positive feedback of climate change. The spatial patterns of greenhouse warming in global climate models contain a strong signature of this feedback. The signal extends to projected changes of sea-level pressure and precipitation. In addition, the upper soil layers are prone to permafrost degradation as the longer snow-free season enhances the depth and warming of the summer thaw (active) layer. Global climate model results now being used in climate change assessments will be used to illustrate the effects of snow and sea ice on scenarios of future climate change.

column5: Computation Across the Physics Curriculum
column18: A key part of doing science is building models. At the undergraduate level these models are expressed primarily in terms of differential equations. However, most realistic models cannot be solved analytically and computation becomes essential. In addition, many models can be better posed as cellular automata or in terms of an algorithm such as a Monte Carlo simulation. Also, much of experimental physics depends on the computer control of instruments and the numerical analysis of data. The present undergraduate curriculum is too formal and includes few of these computational approaches. We argue that computation in its various forms should be a much more significant part of the curriculum along with a return to a greater emphasis on laboratory work. In this way students will be able to do physics in a way that is much closer to how actual research is done, will be able to consider more qualitative and conceptual issues, and will be able to consider a broader range of systems including those found in biology.

column5: Teaching Magnetic Forces and Magnetic Field Topics in Physics Laboratory

column18: We propose a list of designed experiments that could be presented at the laboratory class in the second semester of college and university physics courses to study magnetic forces, the magnetic field, and the electromagnetic induction. In the first experiment, students study the dependence of the magnitude of the magnetic force on the current-carrying wire on the current, the length of the wire, and the angle between the current direction and the direction of the field, and verify the right-hand-rule. The purpose of the second experiment is to analyze a magnetic interaction between two parallel current-carrying conductors and to show that the force of interaction is directly proportional to the currents and varies inversely with the distance of separation of the wires. The other experiment is designed to study Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction when a permanent magnet is moved through a coil, determine the dependence of induced emf on the rate at which the magnetic flux of the permanent magnet changes, and to verify Lenz's law. The objectives of all experiments are to show the real action of physics laws, help students better understand and visualize the subject of the lecture.
